componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2015 Tesoro Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Mark, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to Sam Ramraj. Please proceed.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss the fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.The earnings release, which includes financia
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss the fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP financial measures should help you in analyzing the results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings release, which says statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and our future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions of the Securities Act as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from expectations.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial performance, then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results. 2015 was a record for E
componenttext:
Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial performance, then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results. 2015 was a record for EBITDA and earnings for Tesoro. This performance demonstrates the value of our highly integrated business model and successful execution of our annual improvement plans. Fourth quarter net earnings from continuing operations were $54 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared to $172 million or $1.34 per diluted share last year. Reported results for the quarter include an inventory charge due to a lower cost to market valuation adjustment of $167 million after-tax or $1.38 per diluted share. This adjustment is a result of the decline in crude oil and product prices relative to our LIFO carrying values. Excluding this item, adjusted net earnings for the fourth quarter were $221 million or $1.83 per diluted share. Reported results in the quarter include the following 3 items: $30 million or $0.15 a share from the impact of additional RIN cost accruals following the recently announced EPA requirements under the renewable fuel standard program; $24 million or $0.07 a share representing an increase in the expected remediation costs associated with the 2013 crude oil pipeline release at Tioga, North Dakota; and $15 million or $0.07 per diluted share of asset impairments due to the current crude oil price environment. Total corporate and unallocated costs for the fourth quarter were $97 million, which was higher than our guidance of $75 million. The increase was primarily due to higher-than-expected accruals for some corporate expenses. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $665 million, an increase of 29% from $570 million a year ago. For the full year 2015, net income's -- net earnings from continuing operations was $1.5 billion or $12.39 per diluted share versus $872 million or $6.67 per share a year ago. Excluding special items, net earnings for 2015 was $1.7 billion or $13.91 per diluted share compared to $911 million or $6.97 per diluted share for 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 was $3.9 billion, up 71% from $2.3 billion a year ago. 
Turning to our business segment results. Refining adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $414 million, an increase of 119% from $189 million a year ago. Total refinery throughput for the fourth quarter was 807,000 barrels a day or 95% utilization. The Tesoro Index for the fourth quarter was $15.60 per barrel with the realized gross refining margin of $12.76 per barrel or 82% for the Tesoro Index. This quarter's capture rate was primarily impacted by narrowing crude oil differentials. For instance, Bakken differences in the quarter narrowed over $2 relative to WTI and almost $6 relative to ANS. Manufacturing costs in the fourth quarter increased $0.08 per barrel over last year to $5.62 due to unclaimed repairs and maintenance during the quarter. For full year 2015, adjusted EBITDA for refining was $2.7 billion, a year-over-year increase of 68%. Total refinery throughput for 2015 was 787,000 barrels a day or 93% utilization. The realized gross refining margin for 2015 was $16.22 a barrel or a capture of 84% of the Tesoro Index. 2015 capture rates were impacted by the labor disruptions in the first quarter, narrowed crude oil differentials, refinery downtime, inventory impacts related to falling crude oil prices and running more intermediate feedstock in refineries during turnarounds and maintenance. 
Moving to logistics. This segment's adjusted EBITDA was $155 million in the fourth quarter compared to $94 million a year ago. These results include a charge of approximately $24 million for expected future remediation costs for the 2013 Tioga, North Dakota crude oil pipeline release. The substantial year-over-year increase in EBITDA was primarily driven by contributions from our Rockies natural gas business, which delivered $285 million of EBITDA in 2015, and increased volumes through all TLLP's business segments. Total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $42 million during the fourth quarter and $148 million for the year. This is an increase of $61 million or 70% versus full year 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 was $636 million, up from $318 million last year.
For our marketing segment, adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $187 million compared to $273 million last year. The decline is largely attributed to lower marketing margins. Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 was a record $945 million, a year-over-year increase of 59% and was driven by strong growth in consumer demand that led to higher fuel volumes. Marketing integration increased to 94% for the year versus 86% a year ago. As a result of strong operational performance, annual improvements and favorable market conditions, Tesoro generated $1.3 billion of free cash flow in 2015. 
Turning to uses of this free cash flow for 2015. We invested $550 million in high-return capital projects, repurchased approximately 6.9 million shares for $644 million, paid dividends of $228 million and repaid $398 million of secured debt at Tesoro. We remain committed to delivering strong free cash flow and allocating capital to create long-term value for our shareholders. Looking ahead, you could find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing costs and other elements related to our first quarter outlook in our earnings release issued yesterday.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steven, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was a strong year for the company with several accomplishments and significant progress on our growth plans despite the challenges that we experienced during the year -- in the year. We achieved record EBIT
componenttext:
Thanks, Steven, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was a strong year for the company with several accomplishments and significant progress on our growth plans despite the challenges that we experienced during the year -- in the year. We achieved record EBITDA in all business segments, supported by strong consumer demand, favorable market conditions and our annual improvement program. In 2015, the Tesoro Index was $19.31 per barrel as a result of some of the unplanned operating issues in the industry on the West Coast. For 2016, we expect a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel, which is an improvement of $1.50 to $2 per barrel versus 2014. The lower crude oil price environment is supportive to product demand. For 2015, U.S. clean product demand was up approximately 2% year-over-year, and PADD V clean product demand was up 2.5%. Vehicle miles traveled in PADD V has continued to outpace the U.S. average. In November, California miles traveled had a robust year-over-year growth rate of 6.7% compared to the U.S. growth rate of 3.4%. 
Turning to our operations for the fourth quarter. Overall, we had a challenging December in our refining segment due to some unplanned downtime. In our West Coast region, the Los Angeles refinery experienced problems with both of the fluid catalytic crackers and this impacted our clean product yield. Our operations in the Mid-Con and the Pacific Northwest had high utilization in the quarter. However, capture rates were impacted primarily by narrowing crude oil differentials. We were able to optimize our operations and achieved 90% -- 95% utilization, which was in line with our guidance. During the quarter, we completed the projects to install flare gas recovery systems at our Salt Lake City, Mandan and Anacortes refineries. The $217 million in combined projects were delivered under budget and on time, and these recovery systems allow us to reduce the amount of emissions and potential of flaring events at these refineries. 
Moving to our logistics segment. During 2015, we continued to execute our strategy to grow TLLP's integrated full-service logistics business. Volumes in all of our business segments continued to grow in the face of a challenging and difficult commodity price environment. During 2015, our crude oil gathering volumes were up 37% year-over-year; natural gas gathering volumes increased approximately 5% year-over-year; fee-based processing and NGL processing throughput increased approximately 8% and 20%, respectively; and terminaling volumes were up 4%; transportation pipeline volumes were up 3% year-over-year. We are very pleased with the performance of our Rockies natural gas business in 2015. For the full year, the Rockies natural gas business contributed $285 million of adjusted EBITDA, exceeding its target of $275 million. Based on the combined value of the acquisition of the Rockies natural gas business for $2.5 billion and the approximately $400 million value for the QEPM merger, TLLP realized an implied multiple of approximately 10x EBITDA in our first full calendar year of ownership. This was basically 1 year ahead of our original goal. Because of the successful integration, we were able to capture approximately $30 million of synergies in the full year 2015, exceeding our $25 million target. TLLP also announced several new organic growth projects that should position TLLP for future growth. Additionally, TLLP continued to grow our portfolio of logistics assets through the acquisition of a Los Angeles storage and pipeline asset acquisition from Tesoro in November of 2015. We remain committed to growing a full-service logistics business to our focus on 4 things: growing and optimizing our stable fee-based business; expanding our backlog of high-return organic growth projects; pursuing strategic third-party acquisitions; and finally, providing future drop-down opportunities. 
Now turning to marketing. This segment contributed significantly to our performance for 2015. EBITDA was a record $945 million, and the fuel margin was $0.14 per gallon. In the fourth quarter, we improved our integration to 94% from 86% a year ago, increased same-store sales by about 1% and signed a strategic supply agreement with a key customer to sell fuel at 55 high-volume retail stations in the greater Los Vegas, Nevada area.
Shifting to our annual improvements. We successfully executed our plans and estimate improvements of approximately $670 million versus our $550 million to $670 million goal. We delivered approximately $350 million in West Coast improvements in capturing margin improvements. These include pipeline connections between the Los Angeles refinery; new cargo sharing between our California refineries; the completion of a second phase expansion of the waxy crude project at our Salt Lake City refinery; improved crude blending processing at our Mandan refinery; and operating expense reductions. We also delivered approximately $320 million of logistics growth in 2015 against our target of $325 million to $375 million. Tesoro expects to deliver between $400 million and $500 million of annual improvements in 2016 through refining improvements of $200 million to $250 million from better flexibility and yields, optimization and cost management; logistics improvements of $175 million to $200 million through acquisitions and organic growth projects; and marketing improvements of $25 million to $50 million through small acquisitions and organic growth. 
Additionally, we are making strategic investments that should add long-term value and are currently progressing well in the permitting process. These include the Los Angeles integration and compliance project, the Clean Product Upgrade Project on the West Coast and the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC released the Draft Environmental Impact Statement in November of 2015 and the public comment period closed January 22. Once EFSEC completes its final environmental impact statement and completes an adjudicative phase, we expect EFSEC to submit its recommendation to the governor of Washington. We are very committed to the proposed 360,000 barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe, environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the state of Washington and the West Coast. 
Let me conclude by saying that we remain focused on strong operating performance for 2016 and executing our annual improvements. And with that, we'll now take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I've got 2, if I may. First of all, on the retail numbers, were obviously pretty astonishing for the whole year. But we've had a year where we had a couple of major pullbacks in oil prices. One at the start, I guess, one in the middle, and I guess,
componenttext: Greg, I've got 2, if I may. First of all, on the retail numbers, were obviously pretty astonishing for the whole year. But we've had a year where we had a couple of major pullbacks in oil prices. One at the start, I guess, one in the middle, and I guess, you could say 3 at the end, which obviously helps the retail lag effect. So what I'm kind of wondering is, as you see it, what do you think mid-cycle -- a good mid-cycle number is absent those kind of effects, given the otherwise strength of the retail market in California? And I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The answer to the question about how we see the marketing environment for Tesoro is that when we -- in our analyst meeting in December, we stated that on kind of on a mid-cycle basis, we estimate that EBITDA contribution for marketing at around $650
componenttext: Yes. The answer to the question about how we see the marketing environment for Tesoro is that when we -- in our analyst meeting in December, we stated that on kind of on a mid-cycle basis, we estimate that EBITDA contribution for marketing at around $650 million a year, and that's kind of the base that we said as we continue to make improvements in the marketing business.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's before acquisitions, right?
componenttext: And that's before acquisitions, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's just kind of a base with the current business that we have under how we see the market environment going forward -- marketing margin environment going forward.
componenttext: Right. That's just kind of a base with the current business that we have under how we see the market environment going forward -- marketing margin environment going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is really just more of a micro-comment to the West Coast margins. Obviously, we're in, I guess, we're in a low-demand period this wintertime, I suppose. It's not terribly cold, I suppose. But the point is that West Coast margins have come off
componenttext: My follow-up is really just more of a micro-comment to the West Coast margins. Obviously, we're in, I guess, we're in a low-demand period this wintertime, I suppose. It's not terribly cold, I suppose. But the point is that West Coast margins have come off pretty hard, and I'm curious as to how you see the outlook for 2016 relative to 2015, given obviously the impact that Torrent's [ph] had for most of last year. Any insight you can offer and that would be helpful.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- that's a good question, Doug. I think it's easier to base your reference case on 2014 versus '15 just because of the extenuating issues on the West Coast in 2015. So when we look at the West Coast market fundamentals for 2016, we see suppo
componenttext: Yes, I think -- that's a good question, Doug. I think it's easier to base your reference case on 2014 versus '15 just because of the extenuating issues on the West Coast in 2015. So when we look at the West Coast market fundamentals for 2016, we see supportive demand in the marketplace driven by the economic conditions on the West Coast, the unemployment rate, vehicle miles traveled, all those factors. So we see continued supportive demand in -- on the West Coast. And when you look at the fundamentals of just production and demand and the ability to move products off of the West Coast to seek higher-margin markets and that, the fundamentals look very good to us. And as we said in the past, we see margins relative to 2014 up between $1 to $2 a barrel with those refineries running at a reasonably high utilization rates.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, question related to the Tesoro Index, which is up a couple of dollars versus the 2014 level. I guess the question is related to the crude differentials that are embedded within that Tesoro Index, both for things like Brent-Bakken and Brent-WTI. G
componenttext: So Greg, question related to the Tesoro Index, which is up a couple of dollars versus the 2014 level. I guess the question is related to the crude differentials that are embedded within that Tesoro Index, both for things like Brent-Bakken and Brent-WTI. Given what we see on our screen today, is there a delta between what's baked into the index and what's on the screen? And then if this does become the new normal, which -- at least for 2016, what levers do you have to adjust your fleet and your crude slate to adjust to that?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steven is going to respond to your question, Neil.
componenttext: Yes, Steven is going to respond to your question, Neil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look the last couple of quarters, I think they're pretty good indicators of how the differentials kind of flow through our margins. You look at Q3 and we had a capture rate of about 90%. And in Q4, as we reported today, we came in about 82% an
componenttext: Yes, if you look the last couple of quarters, I think they're pretty good indicators of how the differentials kind of flow through our margins. You look at Q3 and we had a capture rate of about 90%. And in Q4, as we reported today, we came in about 82% and that's really driven primarily by what's happened with differentials. In particular, Mid-Continent, Bakken, Canadian crudes, differentials came down substantially. As we look forward to the first quarter into next year, as we said at Investor Day, we use a planning basis of transportation economics setting the differentials across the crude. So depending on your longer-term view of those, we still think that's fundamentally which offset our capture rate. And when they return to those levels, we think capture rate in the high 90s, 100% makes sense, as we said at Investor Day. But clearly, right now, the market's not pricing the crude oil differentials at transportation. So we are seeing that headwind as we saw in the fourth quarter.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I -- the final answer -- response to your question, Neil, about what are the levers and that what we can pull, naturally, we've been looking at the different types of crude that we can substitute and also how can we find to our logistics system pa
componenttext: Yes. So I -- the final answer -- response to your question, Neil, about what are the levers and that what we can pull, naturally, we've been looking at the different types of crude that we can substitute and also how can we find to our logistics system part of our integrated value as ways to capture advantages in crude supply costs and that it will be able to reflect in our crude cost. But that's not going to offset all of it. So like Steven said, at least in the early part of the year, we think we're under -- it's under pressure with the crude diffs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes a lot of sense. A follow-up question is just related to M&A. Can you talk big picture how you think about the opportunity set that's out there as it relates to refining M&A? And then -- and specifically, in the Mid-Continent, you've expressed intere
componenttext: Makes a lot of sense. A follow-up question is just related to M&A. Can you talk big picture how you think about the opportunity set that's out there as it relates to refining M&A? And then -- and specifically, in the Mid-Continent, you've expressed interest. Is that being a region where you want to grow? Is that still a place you want to build the business?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our view of the future is still based upon what you just said, Neil, and our focus has always been to identify any potential opportunities that we believe would be a strong fit with our business and primarily allow us to be able to go in and create v
componenttext: Yes, our view of the future is still based upon what you just said, Neil, and our focus has always been to identify any potential opportunities that we believe would be a strong fit with our business and primarily allow us to be able to go in and create value by how we operate the business and how we can execute our business model in that. So as part of any evaluations that we do, and we've been doing them for -- ever since I've been at Tesoro, we look at the same -- all of those factors but we're also very aware of the market environment and what's happening to crack spreads. We do our own projections on where we see crack spreads growing as well as crude oil differentials and those all factor into it. So our approach is not -- is really unchanged and we just have to see what happens as we go forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I have actually several quick questions. The first one is for Steven. Steven, in the past, when we see rapid changes of oil prices towards the end of the quarter, you create a mismatch between the physical barrel when it's being post and the paper b
componenttext: Maybe I have actually several quick questions. The first one is for Steven. Steven, in the past, when we see rapid changes of oil prices towards the end of the quarter, you create a mismatch between the physical barrel when it's being post and the paper barrel that you hedge on the change in value. So you could be either hedging gain or hedging loss due to that timing gap. In this quarter, do we have that? And if we do, how big is that number?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually -- I think somebody -- Doug mentioned earlier that we saw several significant moves down in crude throughout the year, and so there's been a lot of volatility in that calculation that you just mentioned. Actually, when you look at the fourth
componenttext: Yes, actually -- I think somebody -- Doug mentioned earlier that we saw several significant moves down in crude throughout the year, and so there's been a lot of volatility in that calculation that you just mentioned. Actually, when you look at the fourth quarter on a standalone basis, we had about as much of that coming into the quarter as going out. So the fourth quarter number is pretty reflective of what's underneath the business. But you're right, when you see a rapid decline in crude oil prices in the back half of a quarter, particularly in the last few weeks like we saw, you do have some headwind that you got to offset coming into the next quarter. We'd estimate that to be somewhere between $50 million and $75 million.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. But for the fourth quarter standalone, that your incoming and outcoming end up to be more or less awash, you say?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: That's right, that's right.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And that on the turnaround activities, if I'm looking at 2016, and since that you gave the throughput already for -- starting from the second quarter through the end of the year, comparing to the 2015 level, should we assume this is going to be higher, lower or about the same?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Paul, the best way to look at the turnaround activity for the company is we provide the dollar magnitude which you're aware of for '16 and you can like it up relative to '15. You can see that it's slightly higher in '16 versus '15. And for our sy
componenttext: I think, Paul, the best way to look at the turnaround activity for the company is we provide the dollar magnitude which you're aware of for '16 and you can like it up relative to '15. You can see that it's slightly higher in '16 versus '15. And for our system, most of it is concentrated in the first early part of the year, probably the first 4 months of the year and then in the latter part of the year. So it's pretty quiet all the time in between there. So we are just completing a turnaround at Martinez. We're going in to turn around at Los Angeles, and then we'll do turnarounds at the latter part of the year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. When you're talking about turnaround, maybe I can ask this question. Last year, don't know whether you feel the same way but it seems like you have more than your fair share of operating upside in your West Coast and Pacific Northwest system. Just
componenttext: Great. When you're talking about turnaround, maybe I can ask this question. Last year, don't know whether you feel the same way but it seems like you have more than your fair share of operating upside in your West Coast and Pacific Northwest system. Just curious, is that a structure issue related to the asset, some hardware? Or that is primarily human error or you're just purely unlucky?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul, I think, first, you're accurate that our -- the way we evaluate our profitability or lack of profitability when we have operating problems was higher in 2015 than what we expect to incur normally in the system. And really, it's a number of prob
componenttext: Yes. Paul, I think, first, you're accurate that our -- the way we evaluate our profitability or lack of profitability when we have operating problems was higher in 2015 than what we expect to incur normally in the system. And really, it's a number of problems that -- different things that cause different problems at times. And unfortunately, some of them are kind of sound like simple things like when we lost power because we had a power outage up in Pacific Northwest that caused the refinery to go down that caused LPOs to net that aren't built into our plans. But it is not structural. It is not human error. It's none of those factors. It's just a combination of a number of different things that we continue to work on and drive improvements in our system.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a rough estimate what was the actual repair cost and the lost opportunity cost in the fourth quarter related to the downtime?
componenttext: Do you have a rough estimate what was the actual repair cost and the lost opportunity cost in the fourth quarter related to the downtime?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- there was a -- I think it's a little bit challenging in the fourth quarter for a couple of reasons. One was that the actual downtime from not running was probably in the $50 million to $75 million range. Unfortunately, it's also complicated at
componenttext: Yes, we -- there was a -- I think it's a little bit challenging in the fourth quarter for a couple of reasons. One was that the actual downtime from not running was probably in the $50 million to $75 million range. Unfortunately, it's also complicated at the end of the year when you have downtime and you build inventories in that. So that doesn't include the total system impact. But I mentioned in my speaking points that we had issues with both cat crackers at the Los Angeles refinery and those -- the impact on those, what we would call our lost profit opportunity, was $50 million to $75 million. Those are corrected and they're back up and running and everything is in good, good condition once again. But there are side impacts on that, that we don't talk about in that $50 million to $75 million because it's how we build inventory and how we're going to run inventory in a number of different factors.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. A final question. Greg, is there any additional update comparing to December Analyst Meeting on the permit, receiving permit, for the L.A. integration project and the mixed xylene?

componenttext: So on all of our -- kind of our 3 major strategic initiatives on Los Angeles, like you said, Paul, on our West Coast, what we call our product upgrade project, which includes mixed xylenes as well as Vancouver Energy, they are all in the permitting phase. We're expecting the environmental impact study from the Los Angeles, hopefully, any day now. And we're in the environmental impact study up in the Pacific Northwest on that. So those are -- that's kind of where they all stand.

componenttext: Nothing addition to what I just answered in response to Paul's question that we're in that. We're fully involved in the process as a company. We are highly responsive to the request from the different agencies to answer questions and all that. And we, at the end of the day, we have to be -- we are dependent upon them to kind of move the ball forward and that's where we are on all of them. So right now, we don't see any issues or obstacles to that but we are in that process. And as you've heard us say, some of them are a very long process.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then final quick one. Just you managed to get a new credit facility, I think, for TLLP. Obviously, everyone's worried about MLP funding stress, but maybe talk a little bit about any concerns or otherwise that you have about funding the drop-down
componenttext: Okay. And then final quick one. Just you managed to get a new credit facility, I think, for TLLP. Obviously, everyone's worried about MLP funding stress, but maybe talk a little bit about any concerns or otherwise that you have about funding the drop-down into TLLP from a TSO perspective?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, Ed, and I appreciate you asking. Let me ask Steven to comment on that.
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, Ed, and I appreciate you asking. Let me ask Steven to comment on that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're really pleased with what we've been able to do with creating a very flexible and larger and lower cost revolver within TLLP. That's now closed. And we've gone from a capacity of $900 million to $1.7 million with really 2 capacities. One, for $1
componenttext: Yes, we're really pleased with what we've been able to do with creating a very flexible and larger and lower cost revolver within TLLP. That's now closed. And we've gone from a capacity of $900 million to $1.7 million with really 2 capacities. One, for $1 billion, to be able to allow us to fund drop-downs and the rest for general purposes. And we're able to do that with the lower overall spreads. And importantly, as we want to move TLLP to investment grade and Tesoro, it's got fall-away covenants now to allow it to become an investment-grade facility. So in terms of that part of the balance sheet, we feel very good about having the capacity to manage short-term liquidity needs. But longer term -- or in the intermediate term, the debt and equity markets and MLP space are very unstable right now. A lot of volatility, very, very poor fund flows going into the space. And so as we said at Investor Day, we've really got 2 portfolios of investments in there, the organic growth projects, which were about $400 million in our plan for '16, which we feel we could fund very, very easily through our ATM program/equity from unitholders as well as a small amount of debt. The drop-downs, we continue to have in our plan 2 drop-downs for 2016. That's what we talked about at Investor Day, the Great Northern acquisition that we just completed as well as the Alaska assets, once we complete closure of that transaction. And so we're preparing to be able to do that. We think there's still good drop-downs to make. The uncertainty is when will the market, MLP market, support those types of transactions. So we continue to monitor that and we'll be prepared to execute when the markets stabilize.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Phil Gresh at JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Phil Gresh at JPMorgan.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just a follow-up to that. To the extent that the MLP markets remain challenged, would you be willing to take back units to support the drops or use lower multiples or do something creative? Or would you be more inclined to slow down the
componenttext: First question is just a follow-up to that. To the extent that the MLP markets remain challenged, would you be willing to take back units to support the drops or use lower multiples or do something creative? Or would you be more inclined to slow down the drop pace if the market is going to remain challenging?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we always look at all those options. But we think it's important to -- for Tesoro to get cash from these drop-downs. We've laid out the base plan for this year, kind of recognized the weakness in the MLP market of 50%, cash proceeds coming from dr
componenttext: I think we always look at all those options. But we think it's important to -- for Tesoro to get cash from these drop-downs. We've laid out the base plan for this year, kind of recognized the weakness in the MLP market of 50%, cash proceeds coming from drop-downs. Ideally, it would be more than that. And so we'll look at all the facts and circumstances as the markets develop, but that wouldn't be our primary path. And in terms of valuation, we really -- each transaction has to stand on its own and be done at market. And so we don't think it makes a lot of sense to try to force something. We wanted, if you think about the principles, what we do with drop-downs, they're supportive to TLLP growth. They -- it provides cash back to Tesoro. And we do that in a way to put some path [ph] to investment grade. And so trying to flex other variables that compromise those principles is not our primary approach.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Okay, second question is just on the California capture rates. Greg, you mentioned the $50 million to $75 million headwind. But even despite that, actually, the capture rates in California looked reasonably stable over the past couple of quart
componenttext: Understood. Okay, second question is just on the California capture rates. Greg, you mentioned the $50 million to $75 million headwind. But even despite that, actually, the capture rates in California looked reasonably stable over the past couple of quarters. So ex that, I mean, as you look ahead to 2016 and all the business improvements that you're targeting, especially in the West Coast, do you have a way that you're thinking about what you would like to target for that capture rate?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, we'd like to capture 100% at the index and that's what we would strive to do. And we have more flexibility in California versus some of the other questions that was asked about capture, specifically if you go into like Mandan or Salt Lake
componenttext: Well, of course, we'd like to capture 100% at the index and that's what we would strive to do. And we have more flexibility in California versus some of the other questions that was asked about capture, specifically if you go into like Mandan or Salt Lake or that where we're more pricing off of WTI. So I mean, our forecast for ANS crude relative to Brent is still in the same range that it's been over the last few years in that. But we see opportunities, particularly from yields in that, to continue to work on our capture there. So we view the California region or the West Coast region from a capture more favorably versus the inland markets.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Okay. Last question is just on the cash from operations. Was there a sizable working capital impact in the quarter to see if I was weaker than my model?
componenttext: Sure. Okay. Last question is just on the cash from operations. Was there a sizable working capital impact in the quarter to see if I was weaker than my model?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would have expected actually to either generate cash from drawing down working capital or remaining close to flat. And we had about $150 million working capital charge in the quarter on the balance sheet. Greg mentioned that earlier. As we look at
componenttext: Yes, we would have expected actually to either generate cash from drawing down working capital or remaining close to flat. And we had about $150 million working capital charge in the quarter on the balance sheet. Greg mentioned that earlier. As we look at operational issues causing us to build inventory at the end of the year when we would have wanted to draw inventory, that's the headwind you're speaking of.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sam Margolin from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sam Margolin from Cowen and Company.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some investors have noticed that distillate margins currently are implying some real pressure for the Asian refining system and potential utilization swings and shuttered capacity as a result. I wonder if you're noticing any developments on that front. An
componenttext: Some investors have noticed that distillate margins currently are implying some real pressure for the Asian refining system and potential utilization swings and shuttered capacity as a result. I wonder if you're noticing any developments on that front. And I asked because PADD V gasoline imports were up quite a bit last year given the price environment and they added to Torrent [ph]. So any color on sort of the transpacific environment, I think, would be helpful to frame the '16 outlook against your more positive underlying view of demand.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you can -- you'll hear some of the factors going on kind of particularly centered around China and what's happening in Asia with demand in that and definitely will have an impact on the crack spread environment in Asia. I think, though, Sam,
componenttext: Yes, I think you can -- you'll hear some of the factors going on kind of particularly centered around China and what's happening in Asia with demand in that and definitely will have an impact on the crack spread environment in Asia. I think, though, Sam, from a West Coast standpoint, we don't see that having an impact on the West Coast. The imports are exactly right. We're higher because the market needed the product to come in to meet the demand as a result of operating problems on the West Coast last year. And we believe once those kind of work through the system, especially on the West Coast, that the overall fundamentals, like I said earlier, are supportive to a good margin environment in 2016.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this one's a little bit more focused on your own assets. After the Los Angeles integration, it sounds like the system is going to be referred to as sort of one refinery. Is that going to have any effect on how we should think about turnarounds?
componenttext: Okay. And this one's a little bit more focused on your own assets. After the Los Angeles integration, it sounds like the system is going to be referred to as sort of one refinery. Is that going to have any effect on how we should think about turnarounds? If there is more redundancy and you referenced the turnaround at Los Angeles or some downtime, the capture effect or the yield effect might come through the results differently? And is that -- or maybe that's just embedded in your improvement targets anyway?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, from a -- the way the system is talked about and reflected in our reporting, the Los Angeles was integrated financially almost on day 1 when we took over. So we don't have -- we don't keep 2 sets of books on each part of the 2 refineries. So that wa
componenttext: Well, from a -- the way the system is talked about and reflected in our reporting, the Los Angeles was integrated financially almost on day 1 when we took over. So we don't have -- we don't keep 2 sets of books on each part of the 2 refineries. So that was integrated immediately. The next step, as you just pointed out, is actual physical integration, which helps us to optimize the configuration refinery like we've talked about now for the last couple of years where we're basically able to shut down a cat cracker that existed at the Wilmington portion of the Los Angeles refinery and drive better flexibility between the yields off of the refinery now. But you won't see any differences on how we talk about it really, and it won't change turnarounds to that. It just gives us a lot more flexibility to operate the refinery.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Dietert of Simmons.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Dietert of Simmons.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to talk a little bit about the Pacific Northwest in crude feedstock flexibility. You highlighted in your opening remarks that the Bakken ANS differential contracted. Could you talk about your flexibility to shift away from Bakken in periods w
componenttext: I was hoping to talk a little bit about the Pacific Northwest in crude feedstock flexibility. You highlighted in your opening remarks that the Bakken ANS differential contracted. Could you talk about your flexibility to shift away from Bakken in periods when those differentials narrow? And with this competitive market, are you seeing the rail transportation cost become more competitive? How do the Bakken barrels look economically for Pacific Northwest?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have the same flexibility that existed before we started moving Bakken to the West Coast, which would put us using, if we chose to, use more ANS and then look for other types of foreign crudes that we could bring in to the Pacific Northwest. Th
componenttext: Yes. So we have the same flexibility that existed before we started moving Bakken to the West Coast, which would put us using, if we chose to, use more ANS and then look for other types of foreign crudes that we could bring in to the Pacific Northwest. The -- as Steven talked about, the crude diffs, particularly the Bakken diffs, now that they've been under a lot of pressure in that, we are starting to see lowering of the supply chain costs to get the crude over there. It's starting to happen and in different parts of the supply chain. And we believe that over time here in the next short period of time, we'll be able to make that cost very competitive, especially with, for example, the pipeline cost to get to the Gulf Coast of the United States, and we still get the yield advantage that we've talked about for some time relative to like, say, running ANS on the West Coast.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. On the marketing side, congratulations on a record earnings and appreciate the normalized margin you provided earlier on the call, could you talk a little bit about the major drivers of profitability within retail? For example, the TSO Index
componenttext: Great, great. On the marketing side, congratulations on a record earnings and appreciate the normalized margin you provided earlier on the call, could you talk a little bit about the major drivers of profitability within retail? For example, the TSO Index was similar in 4Q to 2Q of last year, yet there was a fairly significant difference in fuel margin. Could you just highlight in that consolidated marketing organization what those major drivers of profitability are that could cause it to be stronger or weaker than the index might suggest?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I didn't look at your specific question, Jeff. You looked at  something differently than I've looked at, 4Q to 2Q. I haven't looked at that. We can definitely go back and look at that. But the drivers for us in the marketing business are, one, is get
componenttext: Yes, I didn't look at your specific question, Jeff. You looked at  something differently than I've looked at, 4Q to 2Q. I haven't looked at that. We can definitely go back and look at that. But the drivers for us in the marketing business are, one, is getting high throughput through the systems because we can across all of the different models that we have, whether it be our wholesale business or our company-owned but operated by the multisite operators. And then the big lever for us is in our ARCO model of being able to go in and drive improvements in that business that are across the board in all things of how the market reacts to the changing prices.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, we've historically kind of tracked the retail side of the equation, but the wholesale profitability is going to vary, I guess, primarily directionally with crude and then product prices. Is that fair?
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, we've historically kind of tracked the retail side of the equation, but the wholesale profitability is going to vary, I guess, primarily directionally with crude and then product prices. Is that fair?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes.
componenttext: Right. Yes.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just thinking about repurchases in the current environment. I'm sort of curious how value driven you are at the moment. Obviously, the stock has come off a decent amount. Does that make you want to allocate more capital to repurchases? Or do you pur
componenttext: Greg, just thinking about repurchases in the current environment. I'm sort of curious how value driven you are at the moment. Obviously, the stock has come off a decent amount. Does that make you want to allocate more capital to repurchases? Or do you purely think about it as a return of capital that you don't need to run the business?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, we -- look, we have a very balanced and disciplined approach to how we manage the cash in the company. And we -- so we're always looking forward to -- we're not worried about just today, but we're looking what our plans are for the next 12 to 24 mon
componenttext: Brad, we -- look, we have a very balanced and disciplined approach to how we manage the cash in the company. And we -- so we're always looking forward to -- we're not worried about just today, but we're looking what our plans are for the next 12 to 24 months. And our priorities, they really haven't changed actually. The first priority is that we have very valuable strategic projects that we want to be able to drive a fundamental improvement in the overall profitability of the company. We've talked about those in the past. So we have a portfolio of those projects. Today, we have some larger projects that we've already mentioned. And then we always have a number of small ones that we kind of balance the amount of cash that we want to return in the business, but we're very disciplined about putting a certain amount of cash back into the business that helps drive fundamental improvement over time so that we get that value from there. And then secondly, to be able to go in and maintain a very competitive dividend and then use the free cash flow to be able to then purchase stock back in that. So that's the drivers for us, is we always look at what we have going on over the next 12 to sometimes as long as 24 months because the timing of major projects met and take a very balanced approach to managing the cash flow from the company.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think that's clear. And then just thinking about TLLP, can you talk a little bit about your volume outlook for the system on both the oil and the gas side? Obviously, I think you're guiding to lower gasolines at least in the first quarter. But do
componenttext: Okay. I think that's clear. And then just thinking about TLLP, can you talk a little bit about your volume outlook for the system on both the oil and the gas side? Obviously, I think you're guiding to lower gasolines at least in the first quarter. But do you see yourself having an advantage where you can offset the overall decline in those basins?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the gas volumes that we're guiding to a little bit lower is a seasonal issue, so just to be clear about that. So I think generally across our entire system, we see good support on the volumes from whether it be in the crude oil, gas, refined
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the gas volumes that we're guiding to a little bit lower is a seasonal issue, so just to be clear about that. So I think generally across our entire system, we see good support on the volumes from whether it be in the crude oil, gas, refined products. And so we don't see any unnecessary pressure on any of those parts of the TLLP drivers and all that. So we're pretty supportive of what we have going on. We believe that the organic projects that Steven talked about continue to allow us to bring additional volumes on to the system and help enhance the connection in with the other logistic systems in that. So we're very supportive of how we look at the volume growth for TLLP for 2016 in a very difficult environment.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chi Chow of Tudor, Pickering & Holt.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chi Chow of Tudor, Pickering & Holt.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back on marketing, I have a high-level question. I don't think you really addressed this back in December. But it seems like there's been a lot of changes in the company's strategy from company-operated system to your spec to this MSO model you had for a
componenttext: Back on marketing, I have a high-level question. I don't think you really addressed this back in December. But it seems like there's been a lot of changes in the company's strategy from company-operated system to your spec to this MSO model you had for a while. Now it seems like you're back to focusing on more of a branded C-store strategy. Can you just discuss the thinking on all the shifts in the marketing strategy?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I would represent it a little bit differently. I wouldn't call it a lot of shifts. So let me provide some clarity around how we're thinking about that. One, we truly, truly believe that there is incredible value in our integrated busin
componenttext: Well, first of all, I would represent it a little bit differently. I wouldn't call it a lot of shifts. So let me provide some clarity around how we're thinking about that. One, we truly, truly believe that there is incredible value in our integrated business model because of where we operate as a company. So that's very important. Two, marketing is a critical part of how we're able to drive high utilization in our refineries and that connection there. So then you look at our portfolio of marketing channels, then you can call them whether they be company owned and operated or a wholesale or a dealer channel in that. So that's kind of always been -- our push has been to be able to grow that integration in marketing. So that's very important. Then the second thing is over time, we optimize that channel mix and part of that has been like take what was company operated and go to this multisite operator, which basically allows someone else just to operate the stations but the financial drivers in that aren't significantly different as if we would have operated them ourselves. I think that's an important point. And then being able to go out and strengthen our portfolio of marketing channels by, one, the acquisition of the ARCO brand was a significant enhancement to our marketing portfolio, so it gives us that dealer channel in there. We did acquire some ARCO stations last year that fits in with our portfolio, but that's an important part of it. Our company owned but multisite operator model is a part of that, and then growing the wholesale channel is a part of that. So I don't think that we're continuing to strengthen the portfolio. And our plan that we laid out going forward is that by each region, we want to be at least fully integrated with refining, and in some regions, more integrated in being net buyers in the market and have a very good portfolio, which would be different by regions, that allows the portfolio around each region to be driven by both return on invested capital on the profitability of the channel and then on the kind of the readability as it impacts refining. So long-winded answer to your question, but that's how we look at it.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As the company looks at opportunities to acquire assets that fit in with our business, we believe our business model is a key driver of what we want to be able to do. So having the ability to have marketing integrated with it is an important part of it. D
componenttext: As the company looks at opportunities to acquire assets that fit in with our business, we believe our business model is a key driver of what we want to be able to do. So having the ability to have marketing integrated with it is an important part of it. Doesn't necessarily mean it has to be there today, but it has to be in a market where we can drive integrated value over time just like we have in Tesoro.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think I know the answer to this question, but do you believe you're receiving fair value for marketing in your stock price? And if not, what are your thoughts on realizing this value going forward?
componenttext: Okay. And then I think I know the answer to this question, but do you believe you're receiving fair value for marketing in your stock price? And if not, what are your thoughts on realizing this value going forward?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can always look at some other parts in that and come up with different answers. I -- we're very confident that with the plans that we're working on and are implementing around marketing, there is very good potential to grow the value of the marketing
componenttext: You can always look at some other parts in that and come up with different answers. I -- we're very confident that with the plans that we're working on and are implementing around marketing, there is very good potential to grow the value of the marketing business to the company. That we're very confident in. And then how that's reflected in the value over time is something we'll have -- we'll see how that determines as we're able to demonstrate success with our plan over the next 2 or 3 years like we laid out. We're -- as you recall, Chi, we said in December that based upon our normalized environment of around $650 million for marketing, our intentions are to get that to $1 billion by 2018.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would a spinoff of the business under consideration potentially down the road?
componenttext: Would a spinoff of the business under consideration potentially down the road?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We look at every -- we have the look at everything that doesn't fit our business model. Our business model needs to be very integrated. But we also recognize, as we manage the capital needs of the company, that we need to take a very holistic and a very b
componenttext: We look at every -- we have the look at everything that doesn't fit our business model. Our business model needs to be very integrated. But we also recognize, as we manage the capital needs of the company, that we need to take a very holistic and a very broad approach about what is the best, most cost-effective way to supply capital to the company and redeploy that capital to get good returns in the business. So we'll look at all different possibilities, but spinning off the marketing business, in our view, isn't something that is attractive from a value-creation standpoint.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of questions. This may be more of accounting questions. The RIN expense you guys talk about in the release, the $30 million or $0.15, I always thought that, that what sort of offset by what you made in the marketing business off of RIN. So if you can just give us more clarity around why that was expensed in the quarter versus netted out against marketing and refining?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our approach on RINs is to stay balanced with based upon what the requirements are in that expense reflects when the EPA made the changes for -- the change for 2014 -- excuse me, in 2015. We didn't have our position fully covered because we stayed
componenttext: Yes. So our approach on RINs is to stay balanced with based upon what the requirements are in that expense reflects when the EPA made the changes for -- the change for 2014 -- excuse me, in 2015. We didn't have our position fully covered because we stayed balanced. And so once they made the change, which increased the requirements for '14 and '15, we went into them, what we accrued for that expense to cover the RINs to beat our obligations for '14 and '15, which is different than your question about how they price in the market. That is just our approach, was to be balanced on RINs and we were not balanced once the government released their final estimate at the end of November and that accounts for that $30 million that Steven referenced, is the accounting to accrue for that liability.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Well, we don't ratchet it down because we have to -- we meet all the requirements. We don't ratchet the blending down. componenttext: Okay. And sorry, just on the -- so the cost for the RIN still shows up in refining and the benefit of RIN shows up in marketing, just so I sort of get that straight, that's still correct?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the quarter, we had been working on 2 pipeline projects. One was the Uinta pipeline and the second one was the Trans-Foreland Pipeline, which was the pipeline up in Cook Inlet that was going to allow us to connect Cook Inlet production directly to our
componenttext: In the quarter, we had been working on 2 pipeline projects. One was the Uinta pipeline and the second one was the Trans-Foreland Pipeline, which was the pipeline up in Cook Inlet that was going to allow us to connect Cook Inlet production directly to our refinery and avoid shipping. And those -- when the crude price environment started to decline, we have that engineering work kind of sitting on the shelf. And we have to be able to go in and say, is there a reasonable expectation that we'll be able to start those projects up again in a relatively short period of time? And the answer was no. So we wrote off the engineering work that was attributable to just those 2 projects.

componenttext: Okay, makes sense. And then last question for me. Are you -- would you say you're taking more imported crude today than lower 48 compared to a few quarters ago? Or is it roughly the same balance?

componenttext: We have been taking in more foreign crude into our system over the last little bit as the differentials have justified doing that. So -- and we do that all the time, Faisal, so it's not unusual. I mean, we do it over time depending on how we need to balance our system and respond to it. So -- but we are taking in more foreign crude today.

componenttextpreview: Okay. That would be great. Greg, second question, maybe a little bit more strategic and longer term. You guys have done phenomenally over the last several years. And with the increasing concern from the market on the macro outlook, not so much as in the U
componenttext: Okay. That would be great. Greg, second question, maybe a little bit more strategic and longer term. You guys have done phenomenally over the last several years. And with the increasing concern from the market on the macro outlook, not so much as in the U.S. but also in the overseas weaknesses in the economy and all that, does it make sense at this point, given the still very strong cash flow, to allocate part of your free cash flow, maybe 20% or so, to put it into your balance sheet to further strengthen your already strong balance sheet? I mean, for 2 for 1 as the acting insurance policy in case if the uncertainty turned out to be real. Or that if it doesn't, then at some point that if we do get into a downturn, you would be in an excellent position to take opportunity of any investment opportunity that -- to say correspondingly percent of you [ph]. So just curious, is that something that even remotely that you're thinking along those lines?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's an excellent question, Paul. We absolutely -- I think it goes back to our point about how we look at managing the cash flow with the company, and our view is to be very focused on looking at different scenarios that happen over time. And under t
componenttext: Yes, it's an excellent question, Paul. We absolutely -- I think it goes back to our point about how we look at managing the cash flow with the company, and our view is to be very focused on looking at different scenarios that happen over time. And under those scenarios, what's the impact to the company and then how should we be spending the cash with the company. So the answer is that we look at that all of the time and are very focused on how we spend the money of the company. And I mean, we've worked hard actually, like you said, to create the balance sheet that we have today. I mean, we've worked really hard to get debt to a pretty low level. We typically -- on a Tesoro on a nonconsolidated basis, at the end of the year, we were kind of almost debt-free when you look at our cash of $1 billion and debt of $1.2 billion. And then Tesoro Logistics, we believe, can stand on its own and perhaps because of a good customer base and all that, we'll be able to meet all of its requirements. But the answer to your question is yes. We're very focused on different market environments and how we want to be positioned for those environments, which may cause us to do things differently.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Our last question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quick. I just wanted to hit you on the M&A front and not necessarily just the refining side but a lot of stress and strain throughout the MLP sector. And I'm wondering, you mentioned the drop-downs potentially a limitation for you given market condit
componenttext: Real quick. I just wanted to hit you on the M&A front and not necessarily just the refining side but a lot of stress and strain throughout the MLP sector. And I'm wondering, you mentioned the drop-downs potentially a limitation for you given market conditions. Can you do acquisitions as you have been doing and maybe even a little more aggressively, given that the industry overall or the sector overall is somewhat capital-constrained here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at -- our approach is that we have to be very kind of judicious in the type of opportunities that we want to pursue, that they need to fit in, they need to be high-quality businesses that have -- that are -- that fit in with the
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at -- our approach is that we have to be very kind of judicious in the type of opportunities that we want to pursue, that they need to fit in, they need to be high-quality businesses that have -- that are -- that fit in with the way that we operate the business. And I think, for example, at the beginning of January, we closed on this system up in North Dakota that fits in extremely well to our business. We believe the value that we'll create with that is very, very attractive, and we need to continue to do, follow the same approach on other assets on that. So we are -- Steven -- I think Steven's point around being able to fund the drop-downs in that basically said that we're going to go in and look for those opportunities in a market that allows us to go to the market for both debt and equity to fund that, and it won't be any different from any type of logistics acquisition. We have the added benefits, is that we can do those at Tesoro like we recently done on 2 of them that are drop-downs for 2016.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I was just trying to think how do you weigh acquisitions. What is the sort of the internal calculation that you think about between, say, maybe an accelerated share repurchase situation versus the opportunistic acquisition?
componenttext: Right. And I was just trying to think how do you weigh acquisitions. What is the sort of the internal calculation that you think about between, say, maybe an accelerated share repurchase situation versus the opportunistic acquisition?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the value, we have to look at the acquisitions and make sure that the value contribution gives the return that meets our objectives relative to other uses of capital. It's no more complicated than that, really. But I think what the important point --
componenttext: Yes, the value, we have to look at the acquisitions and make sure that the value contribution gives the return that meets our objectives relative to other uses of capital. It's no more complicated than that, really. But I think what the important point -- part there is, is that because of the environment that we're in, as everyone has stated, is you have to be very focused on where that revenue comes from, from those different assets so that you have a strong business in a weak environment.
