headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Q1 2016 Tesoro corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra and I'm your operator. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes. And now I'd like to hand
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Q1 2016 Tesoro corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra and I'm your operator. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes. 
And now I'd like to hand the call over to Sam Ramraj. Please go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.The earnings release, which includes financia
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliation for non-GAAP financial measures should help you in analyzing the results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings release which say statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and our future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions of the Securities Act as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from expectations.
Now I will turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our first quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported first quarter net earnings from continuing operations of $58 million or $0.
componenttext:
Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our first quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported first quarter net earnings from continuing operations of $58 million or $0.48 per diluted share compared to $145 million of $1.15 per diluted share a year ago. 
Reported results for the quarter included a pretax inventory charge due to lower cost to market valuation adjustments of $147 million. Earnings in the first quarter of 2015 included a pretax benefit of $42 million related to the LCM inventory adjustment. 
Additionally, in this quarter, we recognized a pretax benefit of $6 million for a legal settlement in the logistics business. Excluding these items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations for the first quarter of 2016 were $144 million or $1.19 per diluted share and $124 million or $0.98 per diluted share for the first quarter of 2015. 
Adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter increased to $541 million  from $489 million in the same quarter last year. These results demonstrate the value of our highly integrated business model with solid results in our marketing business, growth in logistics and improved refining utilization as well as other operational and cost improvements.
Today's improvements were partially offset by lower crack spreads and [indiscernible] crude oil differentials. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 23.4%, primarily due to a benefit of $13 million or $0.11 per share from a change in tax accounting rules for stock-based compensation as well as the continued growth of TLLP's income in proportionate to Tesoro's income. 
Turning to our business segments. Adjusted EBITDA for Refining was $196 million for the first quarter 2016 compared to $256 million a year ago. This decrease primary reflected lower Refining crack spreads and much narrower crude oil differentials. 
The Tesoro Index was $12.15 per barrel in the first quarter with a realized gross refining margin of $9.66 a barrel or 80% of the Tesoro Index. This compares to a realized gross refining margin of $11.62 per barrel or 70% of the Tesoro Index last year. 
The Tesoro Index for California average $13.59 in the quarter, a decline of $4.45 from $18.04 a year ago. Additionally, Bakken differentials in the quarter narrowed over $4 a barrel relative to WTI and over $7 a barrel relative to ANS. Total throughput for the quarter was in line with expectations at 782,000 barrels a day or 89% utilization. 
Manufacturing costs in the first quarter decreased $0.78 a barrel over the same period last year to $5.55. This year-over-year [Audio Gap] the higher throughput basis in '16 compared to '15 attributable to the work stoppage in the first quarter last year.
Moving to logistics. Adjusted EBITDA grew to $174 million in the first quarter from $168 million a year ago, benefiting from growth in the gathering of processing segments as well as the acquisition by Tesoro Logistics of the Los Angeles Refinery Storage and Handing Assets in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
The total general partner and limited partner distribution received by Tesoro were $50 million during the first quarter. This is an increase of $15 million or 43% versus 2015.
In our marketing business, EBITDA for the first quarter was $239 million, an increase of 65% from a year ago. Results benefited from continued high consumer demand in our regions and growth in our branded station network. In fact, we have 178 more stations in our network than we had last year at this time. Also, marketing integration increased to 96% at the end of the quarter from 94% at the end of 2015.
Turning to cash flow. Tesoro generated $184 million of cash flow from operations in the first quarter. As far as uses of cash, we invested $96 million in income and growth projects at Tesoro and TLLP, paid quarterly dividends of $60 million, distributed $48 million to noncontrolling interests and additionally, we closed on the acquisition of Great Northern during the quarter. As a result, cash at the end of the quarter was $439 million.  
We do not repurchase shares in the quarter largely due to the funding of the acquisition. Going forward, we'll continue to execute our business with strong financial discipline which includes investing in high return capital projects and growing returns on invested capital, strengthening the balance sheet, which gives us the flexibility to make strategic investments and returning cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.
Tesoro has $1.4 billion remaining under its previously approved share repurchase program. In addition, our board declared a quarterly dividend of $0.50 per share, which equates to an annual dividend yield of approximately 2.6%. 
We've revised our expectations for 2016 capital expenditures and reduced our spending outlook by $500 million to approximately $1 billion. For Tesoro, we're reducing capital expenditure guidance by approximately $300 million. This is primarily due to permit timing changes for the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project in the Clean Product Upgrade Project. 
For TLLP, we're reducing capital expenditure guidance by approximately $200 billion primarily in growth capital. Several projects in the Rockies and the Bakken have been delayed beyond 2016 due to current low commodity price environment. Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our second quarter outlook and our earnings release issued yesterday. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steven, and good morning. We were able to deliver earnings growth in the quarter despite compressed crude oil differentials and industry refining margins being low, especially in the first 2 months of the year. Our results were driven by a strong
componenttext:
Thanks, Steven, and good morning. We were able to deliver earnings growth in the quarter despite compressed crude oil differentials and industry refining margins being low, especially in the first 2 months of the year. Our results were driven by a strong performance in our marketing and logistics businesses and demonstrate our ability to leverage our highly integrated business model.
For the quarter, Los Angeles crack spread averaged $16.32 per barrel but declined significantly in February to below $2 per barrel due to inventory builds particularly of winter-grade gasoline. 
Reflecting this trend, the Tesoro Index began the quarter at over $21 per barrel then declined to below $4 per barrel in February. The index then recovered to $15 per barrel by the end of March due to the shift towards summer-grade gasoline and continued growth in demand. 
While crude oil differentials remain narrow, we have seen an improvement in market fundamentals. For instance, [indiscernible] gasoline demand remains strong at 1.6 million barrels per day. U.S. gasoline demand was up 3.4% in the first quarter of 2016 and following a 3.5% growth rate in 2015, U.S. vehicle miles traveled grew 5.6% for February, representing the largest increase since March of 2004. 
Additionally, sales of larger [indiscernible] vehicles in the U.S. have continued to grow and this has lead to increase demand for gasoline. 
Turning into Refining operations. In California, utilization was 85% and the capture rate was also 85% in the quarter, which was impacted by crude oil differentials and refining downtime. 
In Pacific Northwest and Mid-Continent, capture rates were impacted by primarily a lower margin environment, narrower crude oil differentials and weak diesel margins, particularly in the Mid-Continent. 
For the second quarter, we expect overall utilization and refining to be between 91% and 96% primarily due to the planned maintenance at our Kenai Alaska refinery. 
Moving to logistics. Tesoro Logistics delivered record EBITDA and strong distributable cash flow in the quarter despite the continued challenging commodity price environment. 
TLLP's performance in the quarter was driven by contributions from the Los Angeles storage and pipeline assets acquisition completed in November of 2015, continued volume growth in our crude oil gathering business and strong natural gas gathering and natural gas liquids processing volumes. Tesoro expects to offer TLLP an opportunity to acquire assets from the recently announced Alaska logistics and wholesale marketing distribution acquisition and from the recently closed acquisition of Great Northern Midstream. 
This drop-downs could add an additional $70 million to $100 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. Looking forward, TLLP remains committed to achieving its long-term goal of $1 billion of EBITDA by 2017 to organic growth, strategic opportunities and drop-down from Tesoro. 
Shifting to our marketing business. Earnings were solid in the quarter, demonstrating the value of our integrated system to our overall performance. EBITDA was $239 million and fuel margin was $0.14 per gallon. 
Our performance continues to be driven by strong consumer demand and growth in our branded network of retail stations. We are excited about the growth process in this segment as we continue to focus on business improvement initiatives and organic growth opportunities that include investing in our brands, implementing store improvements, adding new retail locations and increasing our focus on our branded retail network. 
I would like to give you an update on our expectations for 2016. At our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out the company's expectations for 2016 through 2018, which were based on the following: 1, a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel; 2, marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon; and 3, crude oil differentials that reflect transportation costs. 
For 2016, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of improvements, including growth in the logistics business and an additional $500 million to $600 million of year-over-year improvements, primarily from higher utilization and operational efficiencies. 
Through the end of the first quarter, the Tesoro Index Refining throughput operational improvements and logistics growth are all in line with our expectations for 2016. Margins in marketing are at the high end as fuel volumes continue to grow, however, crude oil differentials are significantly narrower versus our expectations and this has resulted in lower capture rates and refining profitability. 
For instance, in the quarter, Bakken differentials narrowed over $4 per barrel relative to WTI and over $7 per barrel relative to ANS. 
Now turning to strategic acquisitions and project update. We closed the acquisition of Great Northern Midstream in January and expect to offer to TLLP for acquisition in the second half of this year. 
A brief update on the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State's Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC closed the public comment period in January. EFSEC is set to begin its adjudicative phase with hearings to be held from June 27, 2016, to July 29, 2016. We expect the final environmental impact statement to be issued this fall followed by a recommendation to the Governor of Washington. 
We are very committed to the proposed 360,000-barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe, environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the state of Washington and the entire West Coast. 
On the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project, we are continuing with the permitting process, and we are now in the public comment period. We expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of the year and will begin construction thereafter. 
We continue to be excited about this project as it enhances our position on the West Coast and offer several benefits, including the full physical integration of the Carson and Wilmington operations, yield flexibility of between 30,000 to 40,000 barrels a day of gasoline and distillates and a significant reduction in greenhouse gas and criteria pollutant emissions. 
Looking ahead, we remain well positioned to drive improvements in the business and deliver on the plan we presented in December of 2015. We look forward to updating you as we progress. 
Now we would take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question, apologies pronunciation, this one comes from Jeff Jeff Dietert from Simons.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question, apologies pronunciation, this one comes from Jeff Jeff Dietert from Simons.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know one of the levers that you consider as part of your growth strategy is M&A activity. And I was hoping that you could talk a little bit as you look across your refining, marketing and logistics segments, what valuations are you seeing in the marketp
componenttext: I know one of the levers that you consider as part of your growth strategy is M&A activity. And I was hoping that you could talk a little bit as you look across your refining, marketing and logistics segments, what valuations are you seeing in the marketplace? Is it good availability of attractive assets? Is this corporate M&A? Is there urgency to participate in the market the way you see them today?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Jeff. Almost 6 years ago now, we set 5 strategic priorities for the company and one of those strategic priorities is value-driven growth. And we've always looked, evaluated, stayed on top of looking for opportunities in marketplace.
componenttext: It's a good question, Jeff. Almost 6 years ago now, we set 5 strategic priorities for the company and one of those strategic priorities is value-driven growth. And we've always looked, evaluated, stayed on top of looking for opportunities in marketplace. But those opportunities, they absolutely need to meet our criteria to be accretive to the growth of the company. So not only do they need to be strategic fit as we described in the past but they also -- we need to be able to create value or we just want to pursue those opportunities. So we do not see a lot of opportunities that are available either through an auction process that are out there right now. And so we continue to look at opportunities -- look at the things that we've seen good for our business, evaluate it and see if there are ways to make them, those opportunities be accretive to our growth proposition right now. There are those opportunities that we are -- that we see available in the marketplace. But we'll continue to look at those. But, I think, it's important to realize that it has to create value, and we have to find ways to be able to do that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And secondly, another good quarter from the marketing segment. Could you talk about the sustainability of strong performance in that marketing segment? I think, some aspects benefit from declining oil prices and are hindered by rising oil prices. But that
componenttext: And secondly, another good quarter from the marketing segment. Could you talk about the sustainability of strong performance in that marketing segment? I think, some aspects benefit from declining oil prices and are hindered by rising oil prices. But that market -- your marketing business has shown more sustainable earnings. Could you talk about the outlook in that segment a little in more detail?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Jeff, if you go back and look at the guidance that we provided relative to the margins, we believe that $0.11 to $0.14 range on margins is really kind of sweet spot for the margins in our area. And, as I mentioned, we'll run the high end of that
componenttext: I think, Jeff, if you go back and look at the guidance that we provided relative to the margins, we believe that $0.11 to $0.14 range on margins is really kind of sweet spot for the margins in our area. And, as I mentioned, we'll run the high end of that range in the first 3 months of the quarter. But based upon that range of margins and what we're doing in the business, we are very comfortable that the sustainability is very sound but more importantly, that we can build upon that by the improvements that were driving in the business. For example, Steven cited some pretty successful growth that we have in our branded retail network on a year-over-year basis. We're working on the images of our stations and see good increases on same-store sales. We're working on the inside sales of the stations. So I think the bottom line is that if you look at the bridge of margins that we see from our network and in the part of the country where we do business and you build upon that, the steps that we're actively taking to enhance that, we feel very, very confident about the business performance today and what it holds for the future.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Neil Mehta and he's from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Neil Mehta and he's from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you speak to the drivers of lower capital spending in 2016. I think you get outlined a little bit in the release but a little bit more color on specifically what the 3 big projects that were pushing out here. And that is there any impact to EBITDA
componenttext: So can you speak to the drivers of lower capital spending in 2016. I think you get outlined a little bit in the release but a little bit more color on specifically what the 3 big projects that were pushing out here. And that is there any impact to EBITDA from the changes in capital spending relative to the plan that you outlined through 2018?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, be glad to do that, Neil. You have to go back to last summer, the summer 2015 when we developed our plans for 2016 and beyond. And an important part of those are our capital plans and at the time we were putting our plans together, we kind of make ou
componenttext: Yes, be glad to do that, Neil. You have to go back to last summer, the summer 2015 when we developed our plans for 2016 and beyond. And an important part of those are our capital plans and at the time we were putting our plans together, we kind of make our best assessment of the permitting process. And we kind of assume that we arrive at a about P 50 [ph] estimate on when we expect to receive the permits with the naturally we would then commence construction. And as you know, you cited not only do we have the 3 projects from a Tesoro standpoint that we're working on, but we also have some projects from Tesoro Logistics that are relatively large for that company. So I think it's best to just talk very briefly about each project. First project is the Los Angeles integration and compliance project. So all the design, engineering, all the evaluation of that project is complete. And we are in the permitting process and it is now -- that is out for public comment. And the public comment, if they stick to the schedule, will we'll actually shortly here in the next 2 or 3 weeks. And then we'll go into the final phase before they issue the permit. When we look at that last summer, that has been extended out so we lost some valuable time, which extended that project out into '17 from when we expected to spend money in 2016. The second project is our Vancouver Energy that everyone has heard us talk about now for 3 years. That project, you can now se more light at the end of the tunnel than we had for some time. The hearings are formally set for the end of June through about 30 days, so the latter part of July. All the work that we've done, the feedback that we've received and everything looks very encouraging but it has taken considerably lower than the average also can that's kind of move that project out a little. And then finally, what we call our Clean Product Upgrade Project or most of you may be familiar with this our mixed xylene and isomerization project up in the Pacific Northwest are and part of our Anacortes refinery. Along the way, we're require to do some additional work on permitting that was unexpected last summer when we developed our plans and that's what that project out. So all 3 projects, the delays are attributable to increase time in the permitting process. We do not see anything in that permitting process that gives us any concern about being successful in the permitting process. It's just taking more time. So when you factor that into our capital plans, as Steven said, that has resulted in moving our expenditures, which were to begin in 2016 out into 2017, '18 and move it out a little bit. The impact from EBITDA standpoint, as you recall, Neil, when we presented this in December, we had very little impact EBITDA impact in our 3-year time horizon. That '16, '17, '18 period. The majority of it came on after that. I think you can recall that the total of the 3 projects added about $350 million of EBITDA but very, very little part of that was in that plan. So that will just move out by about 6 to 12 months, but the underlying value is unchanged at this point in time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then a follow-up is related to hedge loss that you discussed on the fourth quarter call and I think that you guided to some level of a hedge loss in the first quarter results. How did that number end up being relative to the $50 m
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then a follow-up is related to hedge loss that you discussed on the fourth quarter call and I think that you guided to some level of a hedge loss in the first quarter results. How did that number end up being relative to the $50 million to $75 million that you outlined in the last quarter's call? Just trying to see what you're earnings power would be if we strip that out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, actual kind of across the quarter in capture and taken into account all of the moving pieces, including the hedge close, from the fourth quarter, it was probably more towards the lower end of the range. But there's other moving parts as well. Capture
componenttext: Yes, actual kind of across the quarter in capture and taken into account all of the moving pieces, including the hedge close, from the fourth quarter, it was probably more towards the lower end of the range. But there's other moving parts as well. Capture came in about where we expected to. So now was we move forward to the second quarter and beyond, we don't have -- don't see any of that time impact moving from the first quarter to the second quarter. So as we look to the second quarter, we do expect capture to be modestly higher than the first quarter. So probably be in the low 80s instead right at 80. So that should give you a better indicator of the based upon differentials kind of where they in the first quarter with the earnings power is in this environment where you've got very, very narrow crude differentials.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following on to Jeff's question earlier on the marketing business. Can you talk a little bit about progress versus the strategy that you outlined at the Analyst Day? obviously, there was the adding of the sister offering and then there was a lot of i
componenttext: Just following on to Jeff's question earlier on the marketing business. Can you talk a little bit about progress versus the strategy that you outlined at the Analyst Day? obviously, there was the adding of the sister offering and then there was a lot of implied acquisition activity there. Where do we stand on that C store side of things? And has the lack of meaningful acquisition activity does that indicate that there isn't that much attractive in the market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so first, realize it's only been 90 days since we had our analyst meeting. So kind of put that in context. So I think what that means is that we're in the early stages of taking our plans and putting them into implementation. So we have a new leader
componenttext: Yes, so first, realize it's only been 90 days since we had our analyst meeting. So kind of put that in context. So I think what that means is that we're in the early stages of taking our plans and putting them into implementation. So we have a new leader that has taken over responsibility for our marketing business that joined just 2 weeks ago. That is 1 step in the change. We are out working and developing all the plans to implement the things that we described in December of last year, and we see the same opportunity. Those opportunities are unchanged. And like Jeff's question just about the opportunities to acquire any assets for our business, we kind of scour the market for things that make sense for us and that takes time just like we said in December, it's probably unlikely that anything would happen in 2016 from an acquisition standpoint. It's just to find the right opportunities and go through the process of trying to capture those opportunities, it's just going to take time. So I think the bottom line answer is that what we said and what we see today is unchanged. We are in the early stages of implementing it and we're very confident that we will be able to deliver the expectation of a pretty significant growth in the contribution of marketing by 2018.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then talking about TLLP. Obviously, you have the $70 million to  $100 million EBITDA drop target. Can you talk a little bit about the funding for that? I think you said previously that it's important for you to get that 50% cash. I'm
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then talking about TLLP. Obviously, you have the $70 million to  $100 million EBITDA drop target. Can you talk a little bit about the funding for that? I think you said previously that it's important for you to get that 50% cash. I'm curious if that thought has changed at all?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Steven to answer that question, Brad.
componenttext: I'll ask Steven to answer that question, Brad.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Brad, our objective over time is -- when we do the drop is to bring as much cash as we can back to Tesoro. And prior to the weakening of the MLP market, we're bringing back 90% cash roughly and about 10% equity. Given the weakness in MLP market an
componenttext: Yes, so Brad, our objective over time is -- when we do the drop is to bring as much cash as we can back to Tesoro. And prior to the weakening of the MLP market, we're bringing back 90% cash roughly and about 10% equity. Given the weakness in MLP market and the importance of TLLP and our continued -- the value Passaro shareholders get from it, and we said that in that part of time moving to 50-50 cash equity position made sense. Ideally, we do want more cash and as we look at the market today, for the these drops, the key is to execute the drops when the market is strong. The debt market. That's really the key issues to build or raise capital for TLLP in the debt market and conditions have improved. But we control the timing on that and we'll go when we're opportunistic. But at the high level, as I said, we'll expect at least 50% and over time, as the MLP market continues to stabilize and strengthen, you could see more than that. But that's our plan right now.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just kind of a broader question on the low 2018 EBITDA targets. Totally understand, the minimal impact of the TSO level projects. Just the wondering if you layer in the TLLP CapEx cuts and commentary crude differentials, and we should as
componenttext: First question is just kind of a broader question on the low 2018 EBITDA targets. Totally understand, the minimal impact of the TSO level projects. Just the wondering if you layer in the TLLP CapEx cuts and commentary crude differentials, and we should assume this type of environment were to continue, you've got a $3.5 billion to $4 billion EBITDA target. How would you think about that in this type of environment with those moving pieces?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So specifically, with regards to TLLP, as you recall, we have set a target to achieve a run rate EBITDA of $1 billion by the end of next year. And we've clearly stated in there how -- what comprises that EBITDA, which includes drop-downs, some organic cap
componenttext: So specifically, with regards to TLLP, as you recall, we have set a target to achieve a run rate EBITDA of $1 billion by the end of next year. And we've clearly stated in there how -- what comprises that EBITDA, which includes drop-downs, some organic capital growth and improvements in the business in that and then when we look out to the end of 2016, for us to get to the end of 2017, we're very confident we'll hit the end of '16. But it's also important that the organic capital plays an important part of that, that we are able to see some of the projects come back online in '17 that have been moved out from '16 into '17. And that is a function of prices. They are -- it's a part of our achievement of the $1 billion. It's not a significant part of it. But if we do have flexibility to do other things because of our drop-downs, and so we'll stay focused on how we allocate capital to the growth of TLLP that creates the most value, whether it be through organic capital, potentially some small acquisitions and then the ability to drop-down. In the greater scheme for Tesoro like you stated, when we laid out our target for 2018, which was a EBITDA between $3.5 billion to $4 billion, based upon the market environment that I reiterated in my comments, we see that to be very, very achievable. The only sensitivity to that is how Steven described the crude oil differentials that -- but we see them trend towards transportation costs. Someone has to pay to move that oil to get into that refineries. I mean, it doesn't get there for no cost and so the market is that how to that, that settled because it's a fundamental view was that the cost of transportation will set the differential over time for crude to clear in the refining centers. So we're very comfortable about getting it and the timing will manage around it with the projects and organic capital.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then just on the return of capital. Given your M&A commentary and the fact that there are no buybacks in the first quarter. I mean, how should we think about buybacks and are you starting the program in the second quarter, just where doe
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just on the return of capital. Given your M&A commentary and the fact that there are no buybacks in the first quarter. I mean, how should we think about buybacks and are you starting the program in the second quarter, just where does that stand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that if you go back and focus on what Steven said, our -- how we manage the cash of the company has been unchanged for several years here. So we are very committed to investing in capital projects that had value to the company. That's priority and
componenttext: I think that if you go back and focus on what Steven said, our -- how we manage the cash of the company has been unchanged for several years here. So we are very committed to investing in capital projects that had value to the company. That's priority and it's always been a part of, not all of our free cash flow. And that really hasn't changed at all. Then the rest of that cash flow is available to return to shareholders through dividend and through our buybacks. And to be clear, in the first quarter of last year, we didn't return any cash to shareholders in the form of repurchases. It's just the way we manage our cash flow because of the typical seasonal low in margins, also compounded by heavy maintenance always in the first quarter. And so we expect to stay focused on our priorities. They are unchanged and Steven reiterated, we currently have $1.4 billion of authorization to repurchase shares, and we'll manage our free cash flow as we go through the rest of the year and into next year.

componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is more of a micro question. Seems like last night Exxon filed its restart permit for the 7th of May, so I guess is coming back now. headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The 1 and I'll just share with you the way we look at it and is the fact we go back and we look at just the fundamental analysis of the West Coast supply demand, refinery utilization. And if you exclude 2015 because of the operating issues in the ind
componenttext: Yes. The 1 and I'll just share with you the way we look at it and is the fact we go back and we look at just the fundamental analysis of the West Coast supply demand, refinery utilization. And if you exclude 2015 because of the operating issues in the industry and the impact that it had on the way that the crack spreads behaved, you exclude that, you saw actually a very strong West Coast market where a good utilization rates and good balance between supply and demand is [indiscernible] , for example, LE crack spreads in the $16 to $17 range on an annual basis. So when we look forward and start and assume that the industry has all available capacity and is running at pretty strong utilization rates, and we factor in the demand in the marketplace, which continues to improve, which is I'll answer your question, about how we see the retail sales. But the demand continues to improve. So not only did we get the growth and demand in '14, we have growth in demand in '15. We're seeing growth and demand in '16. And so the fundamental -- our fundamental outlook is for a very favorable market environment. The demand looks very, very good. Oil Refining capacity in the PAD will be up and running and running at relatively high utilization rates that you experienced out in PADD V. And we still see a net of need to import gasoline in that environment. So will go through this transition of changes as the additional Refining comes operations come back on and you will lead us to settle very. But we our outlook is very favorable from a fundamental analysis standpoint. So if you go back and say you had $16, $17 crack, LA cracker spreads in 2014, you move forward to use a stronger demand. That's kind of our view of you can take that for what it's worth, that's kind our view for going forward into '16 income '17 and '18. [indiscernible]

componenttext: Regarding same-store sales, we've seen good same-store sales again probably a little bit stronger that we've even expected for the after such strong performance last year. So the drivers, the unemployment rate in the West Coast across the States continues to be very favorable to having a lot of people working. It has high vehicle miles traveled and continued growth in vehicle miles traveled. We did have some heavy rains that did impact the demand in January. But since then, demand has picked back up and those same-store sales are up and very, very attractive on a year-on-year basis. [indiscernible] demand

componenttext: Yes, that's an excellent question, Doug. I've been expecting to for you to ask something like that. Distillate has been weaker. The diesel cracks have been relatively weak until recently and they've actually started to move up. So if you look at the first of the year, diesel cracks were about half of what the had been historically. On the West Coast when you factor in that LA crack spread that I talked about and now they've recovered about half of that downside and are trending more back to the historical average, however, they are not there and has had a little bit of an impact on the LA crack spread but we see the drivers of distillate on the West Coast as being very, very supportive to distillate margins. Doug, I may [indiscernible] made 1 point, I don't think I give a specific number but our since the results for the quarter on a year-on-year basis are up 2%. I do think I said that but.

componenttext: Probably not necessarily. I'm not sure I understand the question completely. But from our perspective -- just from a Tesoro perspective, I think, it's important to state that you hear us talk a lot about our integrated business model, which we believe allows us to run the business to capture the maximum value that we can from the way we operate along that, integrate value chain. And so the marketing business for us is absolutely an integral part of that business. And the connections with logistics for us is how we were able to take and distribute the product from our facilities out into our -- the market areas that we attract. And that's part of the overall integrated business. But I'm not sure I see any of the opportunities that you are talking about outside of that with other people because the marketing business and you look at the best people in the marketing business, for the most part, are privately owned companies that have retail marketing operations. So I don't necessarily -- I understand your correct question correctly, I don't see if it there.

componenttext: Yes, so as part of our capital plans going out part in time, partly because some of those refineries fall under the requirement of the 2020 time horizon, Paul, because of the size of the refineries. But we had no material impact on the RINs because our integrated business.

componenttext: Yes, our biggest -- in the time horizon that you mentioned, the 18 months, our biggest unplanned downtime was the result of that work stoppage that we experienced in California about a year ago in the February, March time frame that was a big impact from us in the, I think, we had given the number that was about a $0.25 billion impact of just basically at the able to run the Martinez refinery when it was in the final stages of turnaround and the work stoppage occurred. componenttextpreview: The big thing to watch really is when you clear crude out of the Bakken, the industry when the crude moves out of the Bakken and goes to the refinancing synergy, you have to look at what are the costs to get the crude out of the area and for us, it's we h
componenttext: The big thing to watch really is when you clear crude out of the Bakken, the industry when the crude moves out of the Bakken and goes to the refinancing synergy, you have to look at what are the costs to get the crude out of the area and for us, it's we have to be able to compete with the pipeline to the Gulf coast by rail to the West Coast. And when we look at our supply chain cost of how we gather crude oil in North Dakota and then gets into our distribution systems effectively, we compete with that pipeline cost, particularly the future pipeline cost with the anticipated construction of a new pipeline out of Bakken to the Gulf coast to be able to the to the West. Coast, and we actually feel pretty good that we're going to be able to reduce our supply chain costs to the Bakken to be competitive with pipeline cost to the Gulf coast. And then in addition, we'll be able to capture the Refining value because of the displacement of crudes that we run today with Bakken crude oil, which we've clearly stated in the past is between $3 to $5 per barrel on average and stayed on that range even at low crude oil prices.
