Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Q1 2016 Tesoro Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra, and I'm your operator. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes. 
And now I'd like to hand the call over to Sam Ramraj. Please go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. The earnings release, which includes financi
componenttext:
Thank you. And good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. 
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP financial measures, should help you in analyzing the results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com. Please refer to the forward-looking statement in the earnings release, which says statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions of the securities act as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations.
Now I will turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our first quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported first quarter net earnings from continuing operations of $58 million or $
componenttext:
Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our first quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported first quarter net earnings from continuing operations of $58 million or $0.48 per diluted share compared to $145 million of $1.15 per diluted share a year ago. Reported results for the quarter included a pretax inventory charge due to lower of cost or market valuation adjustments of $147 million. Earnings in the first quarter of 2015 included a pretax benefit of $42 million related to the LCM inventory adjustment. 
Additionally, in this quarter, we recognized a pretax benefit of $6 million for a legal settlement in the logistics business. Excluding these items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations for the first quarter of 2016 were $144 million or $1.19 per diluted share and $124 million or $0.98 per diluted share for the first quarter of 2015. 
Adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter increased to $541 million  from $489 million in the same quarter last year. These results demonstrate the value of our highly integrated business model, with solid results in our marketing business, growth in logistics and improved refining utilization as well as other operational and cost improvements. These improvements were partially offset by lower crack spreads and narrower crude oil differentials. 
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 23.4% primarily due to a benefit of $13 million or $0.11 per share from a change in tax accounting rules for stock-based compensation as well as the continued growth of TLLP's income in proportion to Tesoro's income. 
Turning to our business segments. Adjusted EBITDA for refining was $196 million for the first quarter of 2016 compared to $256 million a year ago. This decrease primarily reflected lower refining crack spreads and much narrower crude oil differentials. 
The Tesoro Index was $12.15 per barrel in the first quarter, with a realized gross refining margin of $9.66 a barrel or 80% of the Tesoro Index. This compares to a realized gross refining margin of $11.62 per barrel or 70% of the Tesoro Index last year. The Tesoro Index for California averaged $13.59 in the quarter, a decline of $4.45 from $18.04 a year ago. Additionally, Bakken differentials in the quarter narrowed over $4 a barrel relative to WTI and over $7 a barrel relative to ANS.  
Total throughput for the quarter was in line with expectations at 782,000 barrels a day or 89% utilization. 
Manufacturing costs in the first quarter decreased $0.78 a barrel over the same period last year to $5.55. This year-over-year [Audio Gap]decrease was due to the higher throughput basis in '16 compared to '15 attributable to the work stoppage in the first quarter of last year.
Moving to Logistics. Adjusted EBITDA grew to $174 million in the first quarter from $168 million a year ago, benefiting from growth in the gathering and processing segments as well as the acquisition by Tesoro Logistics of the Los Angeles Refinery storage and handling assets in the fourth quarter of 2015. The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $50 million during the first quarter. This is an increase of $15 million or 43% versus 2015.
In our marketing business, EBITDA for the first quarter was $239 million, an increase of 65% from a year ago. Results benefited from continued high consumer demand in our regions and growth on our branded station network. In fact, we have 178 more stations in our network than we had last year at this time. Also, marketing integration increased to 96% at the end of the quarter from 94% at the end of 2015.
Turning to cash flow. Tesoro generated $184 million of cash flow from operations in the first quarter. As far as uses of cash, we invested $96 million in income and growth projects at Tesoro and TLLP; paid quarterly dividends of $60 million; distributed $48 million to noncontrolling interests; and additionally, we closed on the acquisition of Great Northern during the quarter. As a result, cash at the end of the quarter was $439 million. 
We did not repurchase shares in the quarter largely due to the funding of the acquisition. Going forward, we'll continue to execute our business with strong financial discipline, which includes investing in high-return capital projects and growing returns on invested capital; strengthening the balance sheet, which gives us the flexibility to make strategic investments; and returning cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. Tesoro has $1.4 billion remaining under its previously approved share repurchase program. In addition, our board declared a quarterly dividend of $0.50 per share, which equates to an annual dividend yield of approximately 2.6%. 
We've revised our expectations for 2016 capital expenditures and reduced our spending outlook by $500 million to approximately $1 billion. For Tesoro, we're reducing capital expenditure guidance by approximately $300 million. This is primarily due to permit timing changes for the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project in the Clean Product Upgrade Project.  
For TLLP, we're reducing capital expenditure guidance by approximately $200 billion (sic) [$200 million] primarily in growth capital. Several projects in the Rockies and the Bakken have been delayed beyond 2016 due to the current low commodity price environment. Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our second quarter outlook in our earnings release issued yesterday. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steven, and good morning. We were able to deliver earnings growth in the quarter despite compressed crude oil differentials and industry refining margins being low, especially in the first 2 months of the year. Our results were driven by strong pe
componenttext:
Thanks, Steven, and good morning. We were able to deliver earnings growth in the quarter despite compressed crude oil differentials and industry refining margins being low, especially in the first 2 months of the year. Our results were driven by strong performance in our marketing and Logistics businesses and demonstrate our ability to leverage our highly integrated business model.
For the quarter, Los Angeles crack spread averaged $16.32 per barrel but declined significantly in February to below $2 per barrel due to inventory builds particularly of winter-grade gasoline. Reflecting this trend, the Tesoro Index began the quarter at over $21 per barrel then declined to below $4 per barrel in February. The index then recovered to $15 per barrel by the end of March due to the shift towards summer-grade gasoline and continued growth in demand. 
While crude oil differentials remain narrow, we have seen an improvement in market fundamentals. For instance, PADD 5  gasoline demand remained strong at 1.6 million barrels per day. U.S. gasoline demand was up 3.4% in the first quarter of 2016. And following a 3.5% growth rate in 2015, U.S. vehicle miles traveled grew 5.6% for February, representing the largest increase since March of 2004. 
Additionally, sales of larger sports utility vehicles in the U.S. have continued to grow, and this has lead to increased demand for gasoline. 
Turning to Refining operations. In California, utilization was 85%, and the capture rate was also 85% in the quarter, which was impacted by crude oil differentials and refining downtime. In Pacific Northwest and Mid-Continent, capture rates were impacted by primarily a lower-margin environment, narrower crude oil differentials and weak diesel margins, particularly in the Mid-Continent. For the second quarter, we expect overall utilization in Refining to be between 91% and 96%, primarily due to the planned maintenance at our Kenai Alaska refinery. 
Moving to Logistics. Tesoro Logistics delivered record EBITDA and strong distributable cash flow in the quarter despite the continued challenging commodity price environment. TLLP's performance in the quarter was driven by contributions from the Los Angeles storage and pipeline assets acquisition completed in November of 2015, continued volume growth in our crude oil gathering business and strong natural gas gathering and natural gas liquids processing volumes. 
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP an opportunity to acquire assets from the recently announced Alaska logistics and wholesale marketing distribution acquisition and from the recently closed acquisition of Great Northern Midstream. 
These drop-downs could add an additional $70 million to $100 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. Looking forward, TLLP remains committed to achieving its long-term goal of $1 billion of EBITDA by 2017 through organic growth, strategic opportunities and drop-down from Tesoro. 
Shifting to our marketing business. Earnings were solid in the quarter, demonstrating the value of our integrated system to our overall performance. EBITDA was $239 million, and fuel margin was $0.14 per gallon. Our performance continues to be driven by strong consumer demand and growth in our branded network of retail stations. We are excited about the growth prospects in this segment as we continue to focus on business improvement initiatives and organic growth opportunities that include investing in our brands, implementing store improvements, adding new retail locations and increasing our focus on our branded retail network. 
I would like to give you an update on our expectations for 2016. At our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out the company's expectations for 2016 through 2018, which were based on the following: one, a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel; two, marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon; and three, crude oil differentials that reflect transportation costs. For 2016, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of improvements, including growth in the Logistics business and an additional $500 million to $600 million of year-over-year improvements, primarily from higher utilization and operational efficiencies. 
Through the end of the first quarter, the Tesoro Index, refining throughput, operational improvements and logistics growth are all in line with our expectations for 2016. Margins in marketing are at the high end as fuel volumes continue to grow. However, crude oil differentials are significantly narrower versus our expectations, and this has resulted in lower capture rates and refining profitability. For instance, in the quarter, Bakken differentials narrowed over $4 per barrel relative to WTI and over $7 per barrel relative to ANS. 
Now turning to strategic acquisitions and project update. We closed the acquisition of Great Northern Midstream in January and expect to offer it to TLLP for acquisition in the second half of this year. 
A brief update on the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC closed the public comment period in January. EFSEC is set to begin its adjudicative phase with hearings to be held from June 27, 2016 to July 29, 2016. We expect the final environmental impact statement to be issued this fall, followed by a recommendation to the governor of Washington. We are very committed to the proposed 360,000-barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe, environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the State of Washington and the entire West Coast. 
On the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project, we are continuing with the permitting process, and we are now in the public comment period. We expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of the year and will begin construction thereafter. We continue to be excited about this project as it enhances our position on the West Coast and offers several benefits, including the full physical integration of the Carson and Wilmington operations, yield flexibility of between 30,000 to 40,000 barrels a day of gasoline and distillates and a significant reduction in greenhouse gas and criteria pollutant emissions. 
Looking ahead, we remain well positioned to drive improvements in the business and deliver on the plan we presented in December of 2015. We look forward to updating you as we progress. 
Now we will take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question, this one comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons .
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question, this one comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons .

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know one of the levers that you consider as part of your growth strategy is M&A activity. And I was hoping that you could talk a little bit -- as you look across your Refining, marketing and Logistics segments, what valuations are you seeing in the mark
componenttext: I know one of the levers that you consider as part of your growth strategy is M&A activity. And I was hoping that you could talk a little bit -- as you look across your Refining, marketing and Logistics segments, what valuations are you seeing in the marketplace? Is there good availability of attractive assets? Is this corporate M&A? Is there urgency to participate in the markets the way you see them today?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Jeff. Almost 6 years ago now, we set 5 strategic priorities for the company, and one of those strategic priorities is value-driven growth. And we have always looked, evaluated and stayed on top of looking for opportunities in marketp
componenttext: It's a good question, Jeff. Almost 6 years ago now, we set 5 strategic priorities for the company, and one of those strategic priorities is value-driven growth. And we have always looked, evaluated and stayed on top of looking for opportunities in marketplace. But those opportunities, they absolutely need to meet our criteria to be accretive to the growth of the company. So not only do they need to be a strategic fit, as we've described in the past, but they also -- we need to be able to create value or we just won't pursue those opportunities. So we do not see a lot of opportunities that are available, either through an auction process that are out there right now. And so we continue to look at the things that we think would fit our business, evaluate it and see if there are ways to make them -- those opportunities be accretive to our growth proposition. And right now, there aren't those opportunities that we are -- that we see available in the marketplace, but we'll continue to look at those. But I think it's important to realize that it has to create value, and we have to find ways to be able to do that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And secondly, another good quarter from the marketing segment. Could you talk about the sustainability of strong performance in that marketing segment? I think some aspects benefit from declining oil prices and are hindered by rising oil prices. But that
componenttext: And secondly, another good quarter from the marketing segment. Could you talk about the sustainability of strong performance in that marketing segment? I think some aspects benefit from declining oil prices and are hindered by rising oil prices. But that market -- your marketing business has shown more sustainable earnings. Could you talk about the outlook in that segment in a little bit more detail?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Jeff, if you go back and look at the guidance that we provided relative to the margins, we believe that $0.11 to $0.14 range on margins is really kind of the sweet spot for the margins in our area. And as I mentioned, we're on the high end of tha
componenttext: I think, Jeff, if you go back and look at the guidance that we provided relative to the margins, we believe that $0.11 to $0.14 range on margins is really kind of the sweet spot for the margins in our area. And as I mentioned, we're on the high end of that range in the first 3 months of the quarter. But based upon that range of margins and what we're doing in the business, we are very comfortable that the sustainability is very sound but, more importantly, that we can then build upon that by the improvements that we're driving in the business. For example, Steven cited some pretty successful growth that we had in our branded retail network on a year-over-year basis. We're working on the images of our stations and see good increases on same-store sales. We're working on the inside sales of the stations in there. So I think the bottom line is, is that if you look at the range of margins that we see for our network in the part of the country where we do business and you build upon that the steps that we're actively taking to enhance that, we feel very, very confident about the business performance today and what it holds for the future.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Neil Mehta, and he's from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Neil Mehta, and he's from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you speak to the drivers of lower capital spending in 2016. I think you guys outlined it a little bit in the release, but a little bit more color on specifically what the 3 big projects are that were pushing out here. And then is there any impact t
componenttext: So can you speak to the drivers of lower capital spending in 2016. I think you guys outlined it a little bit in the release, but a little bit more color on specifically what the 3 big projects are that were pushing out here. And then is there any impact to EBITDA from the changes in capital spending relative to the plan that you outlined through 2018?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Be glad to do that, Neil. You have to go back to last summer, so the summer of 2015, when we developed our plans for 2016 and beyond, and an important part of those are our capital plans. And at the time we were putting our plans together, we kind of
componenttext: Yes. Be glad to do that, Neil. You have to go back to last summer, so the summer of 2015, when we developed our plans for 2016 and beyond, and an important part of those are our capital plans. And at the time we were putting our plans together, we kind of make our best assessment of the permitting process, and we kind of assume that we arrive at about a P50 estimate of when we expect to receive the permits. We then -- naturally, we would then commence construction. And as you know, you cited, not only do we have the 3 projects from a Tesoro standpoint that we're working on, but we also have some projects from Tesoro Logistics that are relatively large for that company. So I think it's best to just talk very briefly about each project. First project is the Los Angeles integration and compliance project. So all the design, engineering, all the evaluation of that project is complete, and we are in the permitting process. And it is now -- that is out for public comment, and the public comment, if they stick to the schedule, will conclude actually shortly here within the next 2 or 3 weeks. And then they'll go into the final phase before they issue the permit. When we looked at that last summer, that has been extended out so we lost some valuable time, which extended that project out into '17 from when we expected to spend money in 2016. The second project is our Vancouver Energy that everyone has heard us talk about now for 3 years. That project, you can now see more of the light at the end of the tunnel than we have for some time. The hearings are formally set for the end of June through about 30 days, so the latter part of July. All the work that we've done, the feedback that we've received and everything looks very encouraging, but it has taken considerably longer than we ever thought. So that's kind of moved that project out a little. And then finally, what we call our Clean Product Upgrade Project or what most of you may be familiar with is our mixed xylene and isomerization project up in the Pacific Northwest area in support of our Anacortes refinery. Along the way, we're required to do some additional work on permitting that was unexpected last summer when we developed our plans, and that's moved that project out. So all 3 projects, the delays are attributable to increased time in the permitting process. We do not see anything in that permitting process that gives us any concern about being successful in the permitting process. It's just taking more time. So when you factor that into our capital plans, as Steven said, that has resulted in moving our expenditures, which were to begin in 2016 out into 2017, '18 and moved it out a little bit. The impact from a EBITDA standpoint, as you recall, Neil, when we presented this in December, we had very little impact -- EBITDA impact in our 3-year time horizon, that '16, '17, '18 period. The majority of it came on after that. I think you can recall that the total of the 3 projects added about $350 million of EBITDA but very, very little part of that was in that plan. So that will just move out by about 6 to 12 months, but the underlying value is unchanged at this point in time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then the follow-up is related to hedge loss that you discussed on the fourth quarter call, and I think you guided to some level of a hedge loss in the first quarter results. How did that number end up being relative to the $50 mil
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then the follow-up is related to hedge loss that you discussed on the fourth quarter call, and I think you guided to some level of a hedge loss in the first quarter results. How did that number end up being relative to the $50 million to $75 million that you outlined on the last quarter call? Just trying to see what your earnings power would be if we strip that out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look kind of across the quarter, capture and taking into account all the moving pieces, including the hedge loss from the fourth quarter, it was probably more towards the lower end of the range. But there's other moving parts as well. Capture c
componenttext: Yes. As we look kind of across the quarter, capture and taking into account all the moving pieces, including the hedge loss from the fourth quarter, it was probably more towards the lower end of the range. But there's other moving parts as well. Capture came in about where we expected to. So now as we move forward to the second quarter and beyond, we don't have -- we don't see any of that timing impact moving from the first quarter to the second quarter. So as we look to the second quarter, we do expect capture to be modestly higher than the first quarter, so it'll probably be in the low 80s instead right at 80. So that should give you a better indicator of -- based upon differentials, kind of where they were in the first quarter, what the earnings power is in this environment where you've got very, very narrow crude differentials.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following on to Jeff's question earlier on the marketing business. Can you talk a little bit about progress versus the strategy that you outlined at the Analyst Day? Obviously, there was the adding of a C-store offering, and there was a lot of implie
componenttext: Just following on to Jeff's question earlier on the marketing business. Can you talk a little bit about progress versus the strategy that you outlined at the Analyst Day? Obviously, there was the adding of a C-store offering, and there was a lot of implied acquisition activity there. Where do we stand on the C-store side of things? And has -- the lack of meaningful acquisition activity, does that indicate that there isn't that much you're seeing attractive on the market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first, realize it's only been 90 days since we had our Analyst Meeting, so kind of put that in context. So I think what that means is that we're in the early stages of taking our plans and putting them into implementation. So we have a new leader
componenttext: Yes. So first, realize it's only been 90 days since we had our Analyst Meeting, so kind of put that in context. So I think what that means is that we're in the early stages of taking our plans and putting them into implementation. So we have a new leader that has taken over responsibility for our marketing business that joined just 2 weeks ago. That is one step in the change. We are out working and developing all the plans to implement the things that we described in December of last year, and we see the same opportunities there. Those opportunities are unchanged. And like Jeff's question just about the opportunities to acquire any assets for our business, we kind of scour the market for things that make sense for us, and that takes time, just like we said in December. And it's probably unlikely that anything would happen in 2016 from an acquisition standpoint. It's just -- until we find the right opportunities and go through the process of trying to capture those opportunities, it's just going to take time. So I think the bottom line answer is that what we said and what we see today is unchanged. We are in the early stages of implementing it, and we're very confident that we will be able to deliver the expectation of a pretty significant growth in the contribution of marketing by 2018.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then talking about TLLP. Obviously, you have the $70 million to  $100 million EBITDA drop target. Can you talk a little bit about the funding for that? I think you've said previously that it's important to you to get back 50% cash. I
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then talking about TLLP. Obviously, you have the $70 million to  $100 million EBITDA drop target. Can you talk a little bit about the funding for that? I think you've said previously that it's important to you to get back 50% cash. I'm curious if that thought has changed at all.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Steven to answer that question, Brad.
componenttext: I'll ask Steven to answer that question, Brad.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brad, so our objective over time is to -- when we do the drops is to bring as much cash as we can back to Tesoro. And prior to the weakening in MLP market, we're bringing back 90% cash roughly and about 10% equity. Given the weakness in MLP market an
componenttext: Yes. Brad, so our objective over time is to -- when we do the drops is to bring as much cash as we can back to Tesoro. And prior to the weakening in MLP market, we're bringing back 90% cash roughly and about 10% equity. Given the weakness in MLP market and the importance of TLLP and our continued -- the value that Tesoro shareholders get from it, we said that in that period of time moving to a 50-50 cash, equity position made sense. Ideally, we do want more cash. And as we look at the market today, for these drops, the key is to execute the drops when the market is strong, the debt market. That's really -- the key issue is to be able to raise capital for TLLP in the debt market when conditions have improved. But we control the timing on that, and we'll go when we're opportunistic. But at a high level, as I said, we'll expect at least 50%, and over time, as the MLP market continues to stabilize and strengthen, you could see more than that. But that's our plan right now.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just kind of a broader question on the 2018 EBITDA target. Totally understand the minimal impact of the TSO-level projects. Just kind of wondering. If you layer in the TLLP CapEx cuts and commentary on crude differentials, if we were to
componenttext: First question is just kind of a broader question on the 2018 EBITDA target. Totally understand the minimal impact of the TSO-level projects. Just kind of wondering. If you layer in the TLLP CapEx cuts and commentary on crude differentials, if we were to assume this type of environment were to continue, you got a $3.5 billion to $4 billion EBITDA target, how would you think about that in this type of environment with those moving pieces?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So specifically, with regards to TLLP, as you recall, we have set a target to achieve a run-rate EBITDA of $1 billion by the end of next year. And we've clearly stated in there how -- what comprises that EBITDA, which includes drop-downs, some organic cap
componenttext: So specifically, with regards to TLLP, as you recall, we have set a target to achieve a run-rate EBITDA of $1 billion by the end of next year. And we've clearly stated in there how -- what comprises that EBITDA, which includes drop-downs, some organic capital growth and improvements in the business in that. And when we look out to the end of 2016, for us to get to the end of 2017, we're very confident we'll hit the end of '16. But it's also important that -- the organic capital plays an important part of that, that we are able to see some of the projects come back online in '17 that have been moved out from '16 into '17. And that is a function of prices. They are -- it's a part of our achievement of the $1 billion. It's not a significant part of it. But we do have flexibility to do other things because of our drop-downs, and so we'll stay focused on how we allocate capital to the growth of TLLP that creates the most value, whether it be through organic capital, potentially some small acquisitions and then the ability to drop down. In the greater scheme for Tesoro, like you stated, when we laid out our target for 2018, which was a EBITDA between $3.5 billion to $4 billion, based upon the market environment that I reiterated in my comments, we see that to be very, very achievable. The only sensitivity to that is how Steven described the crude oil differentials, and -- but we see them trending towards transportation costs. Someone has to pay to move that oil to get it to the refineries. I mean it doesn't get there for no cost, and so the market's going to have to let that settle. Because it's our fundamental view is, is that the cost of transportation will set the differential in -- over time for crude to clear to the refining centers. So we're very comfortable about getting it and the timing. We'll manage around it with projects and organic capital.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then just on the return of capital. Given your M&A commentary and the fact that there are no buybacks in the first quarter, I mean, how should we think about where buybacks sit? And are you restarting the program in the second quarter? J
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just on the return of capital. Given your M&A commentary and the fact that there are no buybacks in the first quarter, I mean, how should we think about where buybacks sit? And are you restarting the program in the second quarter? Just where does that stand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you go back and focus on what Steven said, our -- how we manage the cash of the company has been unchanged for several years here, so we are very committed to investing in capital projects that add value to the company. That's one priority, and
componenttext: I think if you go back and focus on what Steven said, our -- how we manage the cash of the company has been unchanged for several years here, so we are very committed to investing in capital projects that add value to the company. That's one priority, and it's been -- always been a part of, not all of, our free cash flow. And that really hasn't changed at all. Then the rest of that cash flow is available to return to shareholders through dividend and through our buybacks. And to be clear, in the first quarter of last year, we didn't return any cash to shareholders in the form of repurchases. It just is the way we manage our cash flow because of the typical seasonal low in margins, also compounded by heavy maintenance always in the first quarter. And so we expect to stay focused on our priorities. They are unchanged, and Steven reiterated we currently have $1.4 billion of authorization to repurchase shares. And we'll manage our free cash flow as we go through the rest of the year and into next year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have another question for you. This one is from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.
componenttext: We have another question for you. This one is from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just a follow-up on the CapEx, if I may. I just want to check that we're reading this right. So should we think about that CapEx slipping into subsequent years? In which case, what was your best guess on timing? I mean, do we add this to our 2017 Ca
componenttext: Greg, just a follow-up on the CapEx, if I may. I just want to check that we're reading this right. So should we think about that CapEx slipping into subsequent years? In which case, what was your best guess on timing? I mean, do we add this to our 2017 CapEx number? Or how should we think about it?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what you need to do is you need to take our guidance for 2016, first of all. That's the most important, and that lays clearly out what we expect to do in 2016. We will then work our plans for 2017, '18 and '19. We usually share a 3-year time
componenttext: Yes. I think what you need to do is you need to take our guidance for 2016, first of all. That's the most important, and that lays clearly out what we expect to do in 2016. We will then work our plans for 2017, '18 and '19. We usually share a 3-year time horizon, and we'll allocate the capital to the business that allows us to, one, continue to focus on maintaining the integrity of our assets. That is absolutely a core principle of how we allocate capital. We will do that. We will then allocate to the major projects that we have talked about to allow them to move at the pace that they will. And we'll lay those plans out when we get closer there. But it would be inappropriate to just add it on to what we talked about earlier because you need to allow us to go back in and allocate the capital that meets with the -- our objectives of generating the free cash flow for the company.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So basically, the EBITDA -- you're still committed to the projects, I guess, is really what I'm trying to get at.
componenttext: Okay. So basically, the EBITDA -- you're still committed to the projects, I guess, is really what I'm trying to get at.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up is really more a macro question. It seems that last night Exxon filed its restart permit for the 7th of May, so I guess Torrance is coming back now. What are you seeing in terms of the regional market? Because it's obviously been a bit
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is really more a macro question. It seems that last night Exxon filed its restart permit for the 7th of May, so I guess Torrance is coming back now. What are you seeing in terms of the regional market? Because it's obviously been a bit soft across the whole country, but given where the inventories are in the West Coast, I'm a little surprised that they still are soft. Just wondering if you could just give us a framework as to how you see things and perhaps layer into that same-store sales on retail just to give us an indicator how you see demand.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The one -- and I'll just share with you the way that we look at it and -- is that we go back and we look at just a fundamental analysis of the West Coast supply/demand, refinery utilization. And if you exclude 2015 because of the operating issues in
componenttext: Yes. The one -- and I'll just share with you the way that we look at it and -- is that we go back and we look at just a fundamental analysis of the West Coast supply/demand, refinery utilization. And if you exclude 2015 because of the operating issues in the industry and the impact that it had on the way that the crack spreads behaved, if you exclude that, you saw actually a very strong West Coast market, where -- had good utilization rates and good balance between supply and demand. You saw, for example, LA crack spreads in the $16 to $17 range on an annual basis. So when we look forward and start -- and assume that the industry has all available capacity and is running at pretty strong utilization rates and we factor in the demand in the marketplace, which continues to improve, which is, I'll answer your question, about how we see the retail sales. But the demand continues to improve. So not only did we get the growth in demand in '14, we have growth in demand in '15. We're seeing growth in demand in '16. And so the fundamental -- our fundamental outlook is for a very favorable market environment. The demand looks very, very good. The oil refining capacity in the PADD will be up and running and running at relatively high utilization rates that you experienced out in PADD 5. And we still see a net need to import gasoline in that environment. So we'll go through this transition of changes as the additional refining comes -- operations come back on, and we'll -- the dust will settle there. But we -- our outlook is very favorable from a fundamental analysis standpoint. So if you go back and you say you had $16, $17 crack -- LA crack spreads in 2014, you move forward to use a stronger demand. That's kind of our view of -- you can take that for what it's worth. That's kind of our view for going forward into '16, '17 and '18. Regarding...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the answer -- sorry, go ahead.
componenttext: I appreciate the answer -- sorry, go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Regarding same-store sales, we've seen good same-store sales again, probably a little bit stronger that we even expected for the -- after such strong performance last year. So the drivers, the unemployment rate in the West Coast across the states con
componenttext: Yes. Regarding same-store sales, we've seen good same-store sales again, probably a little bit stronger that we even expected for the -- after such strong performance last year. So the drivers, the unemployment rate in the West Coast across the states continues to be very favorable to having a lot of people working. It has high vehicle miles traveled and continued growth in vehicle miles traveled. We did have some heavy rains that did impact demand in January. But since then, demand has picked back up, and those same-store sales are up and look very, very attractive on a year-on-year basis. So that is, of course, the view on demand.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say I appreciate the answer on the gasoline front. Can I also ask you to touch on distillate?
componenttext: I was going to say I appreciate the answer on the gasoline front. Can I also ask you to touch on distillate?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's an excellent question, Doug. I would expect you to ask something like that. Distillate has been weaker. The diesel cracks have been relatively weak until recently, and they have actually started to move up. So if you look at the first part of
componenttext:
Yes. That's an excellent question, Doug. I would expect you to ask something like that. Distillate has been weaker. The diesel cracks have been relatively weak until recently, and they have actually started to move up. So if you look at the first part of the year, diesel cracks were about half of what they had been historically on the West Coast, when you factor in that LA crack spread that I talked about. And now they've recovered about half of that downside and are trending more up on the -- more back to the historical average. However, they're not there, and that has had a little bit of an impact on the LA crack spread. But we see the drivers of distillate demand on the West Coast as being very supportive to distillate margins. 
Doug, I may just answer -- make one point. Our -- I don't think I gave a specific number, but our same-store sales for the quarter on a year-on-year basis are up 2%. I don't think I said that, but...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have another question for you. This one is from Sam Margolin from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We have another question for you. This one is from Sam Margolin from Cowen and Company.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry if I misheard this. This might have been 2 separate ideas. But did you say that there's some integration between the Vancouver rail project and the Los Angeles integration? Is there a permanent change in crude slate that you're targeting that ma
componenttext: I'm sorry if I misheard this. This might have been 2 separate ideas. But did you say that there's some integration between the Vancouver rail project and the Los Angeles integration? Is there a permanent change in crude slate that you're targeting that makes the EBITDA target work? Or was that 2 points that I just combined in my head?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we made no comment about that whatsoever. We have said that once Vancouver Energy is up and operating, we'll use crude oil into the facility to supply our West Coast operations, but there's no connection to the permits.
componenttext: Yes. No, we made no comment about that whatsoever. We have said that once Vancouver Energy is up and operating, we'll use crude oil into the facility to supply our West Coast operations, but there's no connection to the permits.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then this one is a little more speculative, but you guys get asked a lot about sort of strategic ideas for the marketing business as it scales. As you look across kind of the midstream landscape, some of these businesses are a lot less stable th
componenttext: Okay. And then this one is a little more speculative, but you guys get asked a lot about sort of strategic ideas for the marketing business as it scales. As you look across kind of the midstream landscape, some of these businesses are a lot less stable than what was originally contemplated a few years ago, but the marketing business is. Do you see any opportunity where midstream operators without an operating sponsor have demand to maybe integrate more marketing and retail assets into their businesses and there's an opportunity for Tesoro to sort of gain share into midstream segments through some kind of deployment of the retail assets in a partnership?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably -- not necessarily. I'm not sure I understand the question completely. But from our perspective -- just from a Tesoro perspective, I think it's important to state that you hear us talk a lot about our integrated business model, which we believe a
componenttext: Probably -- not necessarily. I'm not sure I understand the question completely. But from our perspective -- just from a Tesoro perspective, I think it's important to state that you hear us talk a lot about our integrated business model, which we believe allows us to run the business to capture the maximum value that we can from the way that we operate along that integrated value chain. And so the marketing business for us is absolutely an integral part of that business. And the connections with logistics for us is how we are able to take and distribute the product from our facilities out into our -- the market areas that we attract. So we -- that's part of our overall integrated business. But I'm not sure I see any of the opportunities that you're talking about outside of that with other people. Because the marketing business, when you look at -- the best people in the marketing business, for the most part, are privately owned companies that have retail marketing operations. I don't -- if I understand your correct -- question correctly, I don't see a fit there.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Paul Cheng, Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Paul Cheng, Barclays.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, in the unlikely event that you don't receive permit in LA, is there a plan B that will allow you to at least partially get some of the benefit? Or that is -- you do need the permit in order for you to be able to get any of the benefit?
componenttext: Greg, in the unlikely event that you don't receive permit in LA, is there a plan B that will allow you to at least partially get some of the benefit? Or that is -- you do need the permit in order for you to be able to get any of the benefit?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, Paul, let me state we will receive the permit in LA. There's nothing out there that tells us -- I mean it provides tremendous benefits to -- if you look at -- one of the benefits is that we absolutely reduce CO2 and other emissions quite sign
componenttext: Well, first, Paul, let me state we will receive the permit in LA. There's nothing out there that tells us -- I mean it provides tremendous benefits to -- if you look at -- one of the benefits is that we absolutely reduce CO2 and other emissions quite significantly. So we're very confident that we will get the permit. So I think that's important to state that. And so we just -- there is no need for a plan B.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe on Tier 3, I believe your California facility maybe is already in compliance mostly or at least. Can you give us a status where we are? And then how much is the additional spending you may still need, if any? And also, one of your competit
componenttext: Okay. And maybe on Tier 3, I believe your California facility maybe is already in compliance mostly or at least. Can you give us a status where we are? And then how much is the additional spending you may still need, if any? And also, one of your competitors have said in the first quarter their margin capture has been significantly impacted by the ethanol branding laws. Don't know whether that impact you guys or your invoice that you send out to your customer is basically breakdown between the neat[ph] gasoline and ethanol so ethanol is just a passthrough.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first, Paul, the answer to your question regarding Tier 3 gasoline in California, and you're right, the majority of the gasoline has been 10 ppm in California for some time. However, we do make some higher-sulfur gasoline that we then sell into Ne
componenttext: Yes. So first, Paul, the answer to your question regarding Tier 3 gasoline in California, and you're right, the majority of the gasoline has been 10 ppm in California for some time. However, we do make some higher-sulfur gasoline that we then sell into Nevada and Arizona that is not 10 ppm gasoline. As part of our Los Angeles integration and compliance project, that will allow us to have our system be at 100% compliance with Tier 3 gasoline. And it's a small part of it, but it does allow us to get to the full compliance with Tier 3 gasoline. So the second question with regards to...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I’m sorry, how about the other facility and the quality, Kenai and also...
componenttext: Great. I’m sorry, how about the other facility and the quality, Kenai and also...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are -- as part of our capital plans going out in time -- partly because some of those refineries fall under the requirement of the 2020 time horizon, Paul, because of the size of the refineries, so we have a plan between now and 2020 to have ou
componenttext: Yes. So we are -- as part of our capital plans going out in time -- partly because some of those refineries fall under the requirement of the 2020 time horizon, Paul, because of the size of the refineries, so we have a plan between now and 2020 to have our system be able to meet the requirements of Tier 3 gasoline. We will invest in that in Anacortes as part of our project, our West Coast mixed xylene and isomerization project. We will invest in Salt Lake City to be able to get to Tier 3 gasoline, and then we'll balance out the rest of our system to be able to be in compliance with it. On the RINs, as we stated, we have a very high integration, particularly with gasoline that puts our exposure to RINs different than a company that is maybe a merchant refiner and selling into the spot market. So we did not have any material impact at all from a RINs standpoint in the first quarter. And I don't recall what they were in 2015, but they may have been half of what the value of the RIN was in '16. So -- but we had no material impact on the RINs because of our integrated business.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Actually, your competitor is not so much referring to RIN. They are referring to the ethanol price is actually higher than the gasoline price in their market. And so as they brand their ethanol into that, they have suffered a big loss for every gal
componenttext: Great. Actually, your competitor is not so much referring to RIN. They are referring to the ethanol price is actually higher than the gasoline price in their market. And so as they brand their ethanol into that, they have suffered a big loss for every gallon that they burn. So I just want to see that -- whether that is -- you also face it. I don't think in the California market because the gasoline price is high enough, but whether in your other markets you have a similar issue or that in your invoice you actually treat the ethanol price as a passthrough so it doesn't really impact you.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm sorry, I misunderstood you. I thought you were referring to RINs on that. So we did not have an impact on the way ethanol priced relative to gasoline. That wasn't an impact on our net margin in the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry, I misunderstood you. I thought you were referring to RINs on that. So we did not have an impact on the way ethanol priced relative to gasoline. That wasn't an impact on our net margin in the quarter.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Greg, do you have an estimate what is the opportunity cost loss in the first quarter related to the unplanned downtime? And also, if you have the number also for the planned downtime.
componenttext: Okay, great. Greg, do you have an estimate what is the opportunity cost loss in the first quarter related to the unplanned downtime? And also, if you have the number also for the planned downtime.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't -- we typically don't talk about what the opportunity cost is. We had -- I can tell you that in the first quarter, we had our Los Angeles Refinery down for planned maintenance, and we had some unplanned maintenance in the early part of the quarte
componenttext: We don't -- we typically don't talk about what the opportunity cost is. We had -- I can tell you that in the first quarter, we had our Los Angeles Refinery down for planned maintenance, and we had some unplanned maintenance in the early part of the quarter. There was a continuation from the end of the year when we talked about that in our 4Q earnings call. But other than that, that's all that was -- that's all that I can comment on that, Paul.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And since we are talking about unplanned downtime, over the last 18 months, maybe it's just that the media magnifies, but it seems like you guys have your fair share of the operating upset in the California market or the West Coast market. A, whethe
componenttext: Okay. And since we are talking about unplanned downtime, over the last 18 months, maybe it's just that the media magnifies, but it seems like you guys have your fair share of the operating upset in the California market or the West Coast market. A, whether, Greg, you will agree with that assessment. And if you do, what may be the cause of that? Or what is the action that you're taking trying to correct it?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our biggest -- if you -- in the time horizon that you mentioned, the 18 months, our biggest unplanned downtime was the result of the work stoppage that we experienced in California about a year ago in the February, March time frame. That was a big im
componenttext: Yes. Our biggest -- if you -- in the time horizon that you mentioned, the 18 months, our biggest unplanned downtime was the result of the work stoppage that we experienced in California about a year ago in the February, March time frame. That was a big impact from us in -- I think we had given a number. That was about $0.25 billion impact of just basically not being able to run the Martinez Refinery when it was in the final stages of turnaround and the work stoppage occurred. Other than that, I think our unplanned downtime, the way that we look at it is maybe up slightly versus where we would expect it to be from a world-class standpoint but not significantly above that across our systems. So we think that if you can keep about 2% -- if you can have about 2% of your gross margin as -- anything in -- 2% or less of your gross margin as unplanned downtime is world-class performance in our view.'s

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: Next question comes from Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of what I had has been tackled. The only -- couple of housekeeping items for you. For one, I don't recall what composition of your crude slate comes from Canada. But I guess the question I had is, do you anticipate any impact from all these fires and
componenttext: Most of what I had has been tackled. The only -- couple of housekeeping items for you. For one, I don't recall what composition of your crude slate comes from Canada. But I guess the question I had is, do you anticipate any impact from all these fires and downtime? Is that going to change your supply?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, our primary supply of Canadian crude goes into the Pacific Northwest refineries, and there has been no impact at all. And we do not expect any impact. That is -- where we use Canadian crude oil today.
componenttext: No, our primary supply of Canadian crude goes into the Pacific Northwest refineries, and there has been no impact at all. And we do not expect any impact. That is -- where we use Canadian crude oil today.

componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean I'm assuming the inventories are pretty well supplied. So even if there were some downtime, I would assume you could kind of drawdown on that for at least some period of time, right?
componenttext: Okay. I mean I'm assuming the inventories are pretty well supplied. So even if there were some downtime, I would assume you could kind of drawdown on that for at least some period of time, right?

componenttextpreview: Yes. And we take the late -- the light Canadian crude into the Pacific Northwest, not the heavy crude.
componenttext: Yes. And we take the late -- the light Canadian crude into the Pacific Northwest, not the heavy crude.

componenttext: Yes, you will. There might be a little bit more favorability from tax rate, from this item, but it's immaterial compared to what we saw this quarter. And yes, so we'll start -- we'll move you right back into historical tax rates.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The final thing, Greg, if you don't mind. I know you already kind of went through the operational performance initiatives. It seems like everything is in line as far as the controllable items that you can kind of control on operations and whatnot. M
componenttext: Okay. The final thing, Greg, if you don't mind. I know you already kind of went through the operational performance initiatives. It seems like everything is in line as far as the controllable items that you can kind of control on operations and whatnot. Marketing is above what you thought. Differentials are down. But just kind of order of magnitude, it seems like the differential component could be maybe a little more impactful longer term, if it were to persist, compared to higher marketing margin. So I'm just curious, if the 1Q levels were to continue, do you think that would bring you below the range? Or are you still in a position, even at the current depressed levels, where you think you could deliver on the targets that were outlined?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Blake, on the specific targets that we've outlined, as I stated, we feel comfortable in every area, except for crude differentials. And I guess a way to look at your own sensitivity on that is we run about 300 million barrels of crude a year. And if ou
componenttext: So Blake, on the specific targets that we've outlined, as I stated, we feel comfortable in every area, except for crude differentials. And I guess a way to look at your own sensitivity on that is we run about 300 million barrels of crude a year. And if our index is, whatever, $13 to $14 a barrel, just say $13, then every 10% loss in the capture rate is worth with $130 million. So you can see kind of a relative impact versus say -- if you've said that the target was 100% capture and you're off by 20%, that gives you kind of an idea. I mean, I said $120 million (sic) [$130 million]. It's $300 million, excuse me, so it's every dollar is about $300 million in capture.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have another question for you, and this one's from Roger Read, Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We have another question for you, and this one's from Roger Read, Wells Fargo.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, kind of like Blake said, most of it has been hit pretty well here. But maybe just another question on sort of the economics out of the Bakken, both locally demand and then across the Pacific Northwest. What are some of the moving parts we ought t
componenttext: I guess, kind of like Blake said, most of it has been hit pretty well here. But maybe just another question on sort of the economics out of the Bakken, both locally demand and then across the Pacific Northwest. What are some of the moving parts we ought to be watching here? I know a lot of your rail was originally built where there wasn't much of a pipeline option. Maybe give us an idea of kind of how the pricing dynamics work there.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big thing to watch really is when you clear crude out of the Bakken, the industry, when the crude moves out of the Bakken and goes to the refining centers, you have to look at what are those costs to get the crude out of the area. And for us, it's --
componenttext: The big thing to watch really is when you clear crude out of the Bakken, the industry, when the crude moves out of the Bakken and goes to the refining centers, you have to look at what are those costs to get the crude out of the area. And for us, it's -- we have to be able to compete with the pipeline to the Gulf Coast by rail to the West Coast. And when we look at our supply chain cost of how we gather crude oil in North Dakota and then get it into our distribution system effectively, we compete with that pipeline cost, particularly the future pipeline cost with the anticipated construction of a new pipeline out of Bakken to the Gulf Coast to be able to get to the West coast. And we actually feel pretty good that we're going to be able to reduce our supply chain costs to the Bakken to be competitive with pipeline cost to the Gulf Coast. And then in addition, we'll be able to capture the refining value because of the displacement of crudes that we run today with Bakken crude oil, which we've clearly stated in the past is between $3 to $5 a barrel on average, and that's stayed in that range even at low crude oil prices.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just one last question on the LA refinery integration project. You're obviously confident you'd get the permits and all for that. Can you give us an idea if there's any particular milestone, a particular committee that has to rul
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just one last question on the LA refinery integration project. You're obviously confident you'd get the permits and all for that. Can you give us an idea if there's any particular milestone, a particular committee that has to rule on it or something from the state government, just curious, like a date to watch or a particular group to pay attention to here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- it's the South Coast Air Quality District (sic) [South Coast Air Quality Management District] that is responsible for the permit. And as I stated in the comments earlier, the -- it is in the public comment phase right now. We expect that to end
componenttext: So the -- it's the South Coast Air Quality District (sic) [South Coast Air Quality Management District] that is responsible for the permit. And as I stated in the comments earlier, the -- it is in the public comment phase right now. We expect that to end here around maybe the third week of May. It will then take those public comments and have it -- and so the key thing will be late summer to hear back from the permitting authority regarding their response to the public comments.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And after that, what would be the -- year-end was the idea that you get a final ruling, I guess.
componenttext: Okay. And after that, what would be the -- year-end was the idea that you get a final ruling, I guess.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have another question for you. This one's from Johannes Van Der Tuin from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We have another question for you. This one's from Johannes Van Der Tuin from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On behalf of Johannes Van Der Tuin, it's Ed Westlake. The -- I guess, 2 questions. First one is just around, I guess, the Rocky Mountain gas assets of QEP. You outlined, when you purchased those assets, that there was growth potential. You outlined it was
componenttext: On behalf of Johannes Van Der Tuin, it's Ed Westlake. The -- I guess, 2 questions. First one is just around, I guess, the Rocky Mountain gas assets of QEP. You outlined, when you purchased those assets, that there was growth potential. You outlined it was sort of a localized basin. Obviously, gas prices in the winter were probably detrimental. But can you talk about what you think your customers are telling you in terms of the gating factors to get on the front to develop any growth out of that particular area, oil versus gas?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ed, we see that area being stable on a go-forward basis in this low price environment, with our discussions with the producers in that and what's going on and not only just for potential new wells but field maintenance in that, that they're using to
componenttext: Yes. Ed, we see that area being stable on a go-forward basis in this low price environment, with our discussions with the producers in that and what's going on and not only just for potential new wells but field maintenance in that, that they're using to get production up. So our views for this year are that the production in the areas remain stable.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then on the waterborne barrels -- I mean, in the past, sometimes where there has been disconnects, you've been able to benefit. Obviously, you can process a lot of mediums and heavies in the California business. Maybe just any comments abou
componenttext: All right. And then on the waterborne barrels -- I mean, in the past, sometimes where there has been disconnects, you've been able to benefit. Obviously, you can process a lot of mediums and heavies in the California business. Maybe just any comments about availability or the market for those waterborne barrels out of Pacific?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have -- it's a good, excellent point. We have seen some very interesting availability of crudes that haven't been available to us for a long time on the West Coast. So we have been bringing crudes from parts of the world that we typically haven't
componenttext: Yes, we have -- it's a good, excellent point. We have seen some very interesting availability of crudes that haven't been available to us for a long time on the West Coast. So we have been bringing crudes from parts of the world that we typically haven't brought crudes in from for probably -- in the last 6 years, and they're pricing very attractively into the West Coast. So it is the -- I guess if the point of your question is just the dynamics of how producers are pricing that crude. It's been very competitive and offered us some unique opportunities to bring crudes into the West Coast.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then final one. As we look at the sensitivities, we all have our own views of where transport differentials are going to be for the crude diffs. Anything funny as opposed to just the benchmarks that you lay out, so WCS times your WCS volumes, WTI time
componenttext: And then final one. As we look at the sensitivities, we all have our own views of where transport differentials are going to be for the crude diffs. Anything funny as opposed to just the benchmarks that you lay out, so WCS times your WCS volumes, WTI times your WTI volumes? In terms of trying to do that calculation, I'm thinking Salt Lake perhaps diffs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's anything funny in there. I think the -- I mean someone has to pay those costs to get it from the producing area to the refinery. And it's just how those show up in publicly available differentials, in that when you look at clearing p
componenttext: I don't think there's anything funny in there. I think the -- I mean someone has to pay those costs to get it from the producing area to the refinery. And it's just how those show up in publicly available differentials, in that when you look at clearing prices by region in that, whether it be Clearbrook or whatever. So we don't see any see anything unique or special that would say the diffs won't beat the transportation costs over time.

componenttext: So we're most familiar with West Coast exports, as you would expect. Particularly to comment on your statement about gasoline exports going to Asia, we don't see that off of the West Coast.

componenttext: In the first quarter, we had -- as a result of some operating problems in the fourth quarter of last year, we had a lot of intermediate feedstocks that we ran through, for example, our cat cracker, and that would have probably had an impact on how our yields were for gasoline. And so it's not going to be -- that was not normal operation, so that rate wouldn't be sustainable.

componenttext: What we said, Paul, was that we have 2 specific groups of assets. One is the pipeline and rail facility that we acquired -- that Tesoro acquired at the beginning of this year. And an acquisition that we'll be making in Alaska with some additional distribution assets and -- combined with some existing Tesoro distribution assets in Alaska, will be dropped down this year also. And we've said that the combination of those 2 drop-downs would probably provide EBITDA to TLLP on an annual basis in the range of $70 million to $100 million.

componenttext: Yes. We have to let that go through our process -- valuation process between Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics and the conflicts committee. So it's a formal process that's at market rates in that. So it would just be premature for me to comment on that. I mean we do look at comparables and see what other people are doing in the industry, but we also look at the nature of these type of assets and their potential from a growth standpoint.
