headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj of VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure a
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP and financial measures, should help you in analyzing our results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
I would like to point out that starting this quarter, Tesoro will no longer be reporting adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS, but will continue to highlight significant items impacting quarterly results to help you analyze our performance. Further information can be found in the earnings release issued yesterday.
Please refer to the forward-looking statement in the earnings release, which says statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions of the Securities Act as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 m
componenttext:
Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 million attributable to Tesoro or $3.47 per diluted share compared to $586 million or $4.62 a share a year ago. 
Consolidated net earnings were $449 million for the second quarter compared to $620 million for the same period last year, and EBITDA for the second quarter was $956 million compared to $1.2 billion a year ago. 
Reported earnings and EBITDA for the quarter included a pretax inventory benefit due to a lower cost of market valuation adjustment of $363 million or $220 million after-tax. 
Our second quarter 2016 results reflect continued growth in our Logistics business and strong performance in marketing, offset by lower-than-expected performance in refining. 
Turning to the business segments. Refining operating income was $520 million for the second quarter compared to $757 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $692 million versus $880 million last year. 
The Tesoro Index was $13.93 a barrel in the second quarter with a gross refining margin of $15.70 a barrel or 113% of the Tesoro Index. This compares to gross refining margin of $19.13 per barrel or 89% of the Tesoro Index last year. 
Please remember that gross refining margin in the quarter included a pretax benefit of $363 million related to the LCM inventory adjustment. 
Total refinery throughput for the quarter was at the lower end of our guidance at 802,000 barrels a day or 92% utilization. During the quarter, we had an extension of the planned maintenance at our Kenai, Alaska refinery as well as unplanned unit downtime within our California region and both of these impacted our throughput and capture rates. 
Manufacturing costs in the second quarter decreased $0.57 a barrel over the same period last year to $5.01. This year-over-year decrease was due to the higher throughput in '16 compared to 2015, but also a decline in natural gas prices. 
Tesoro's integrated business model helps mitigate our exposure to RINs, however, the price of RINs increased in the second quarter and impacted us by approximately $10 million. 
Moving to Logistics. Operating income increased to $125 million in the second quarter from $104 million a year ago and segment EBITDA grew to $172 million from $149 million last year. 
Results benefited from year-over-year volume growth in the crude oil gathering and terminalling transportation businesses as well as contributions from TLP's acquisition of the LA storage and handling assets. 
The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $59 million during the second quarter. This is an increase of $26 million or 79% versus 2015. 
Turning to marketing. Operating income was $161 million compared to $212 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $173 million compared to $223 million last year. 
Our fuel margins were $0.105 a gallon in the second quarter. During the second quarter, we saw continued strong fundamentals and favorable business conditions. These include: Growth in consumer demand; increase in vehicle miles traveled; growth in Tesoro's fuel sale volumes of 6%; and 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network; and marketing integration increased to 98% from 93% a year ago. 
Now I'd like to take a moment to discuss our continued focus on creating value for shareholders by driving improvements in our business, then I'll discuss our financial discipline and principles of capital allocation. 
We remain committed to driving improvements in the earnings of our business each year and all cycles in the industry. In 2016, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of operating income and EBITDA improvements through these efforts. This includes organic growth and acquisitions in our logistics business, growth in our marketing business and costs, yields and other efficiencies in refining and commercial operations. We're on track to deliver these results in 2016. 
These improvements can be seen in our relative performance over time. In fact, if you look at Tesoro's earnings CAGRs since 2014 versus that of our core peers, you'll see our overall earnings were down approximately 4% due to lower overall refining industry margins and crude differentials. However, the core peer group is down approximately 15% to 25%. We believe this reflects the impact of our continued focus on driving business improvements every year. 
Further, the same relative outperformance can be seen in our free cash flow yields. This continued focus on and execution of driving improvements results in significant shareholder value creation and that continues to be seen in our cash flows and capital allocation priorities. 
We ended the quarter with a consolidated cash balance of $1.1 billion compared to $942 million at the end of 2015. Our balance sheet remains strong, with a total debt, net of unamortized issuance costs to capitalization ratio of 36%. 
Excluding TLP debt and equity, our debt-to-capitalization ratio was 19% at the end of the second quarter. We also currently have $2.1 billion of availability under our revolving credit facility. We continue to believe that we are well-positioned to obtain the investment-grade ratings from both companies. Investment-grade credit ratings for Tesoro and TLP offer substantial benefits of both companies, including lower relative debt spreads of 100 to 200 basis points over time, potential combined interest cost savings of $80 million to $105 million and most importantly, the ability to access extended debt maturities for TLLP. 
Turning to cash flows. Tesoro generated $444 million of cash flow from operating activities in the second quarter. Now I'll discuss how we deployed cash to create long-term shareholder value. 
First, we invested in high-return capital projects and grow returns on invested capital. During the quarter, we invested $105 million in income growth per capital project at Tesoro and TLLP. Our combined capital expenditures through the first half of 2016 were approximately $400 million. We expect 2016 capital spending of approximately $1 billion, which is consistent with our previously announced plan. 
Second, we continue to ensure we have a some balance sheet to give us the flexibility to make strategic investments and return cash to shareholders. In the quarter, we spent approximately $80 million on 2 highly accretive acquisitions. 
We continue to look for additional opportunities and are currently focusing on targets in midstream and other assets, which can enhance our integrated business model. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased 1.3 million shares for approximately $100 million. Tesoro currently has $1.3 billion remaining under its previously approved share repurchase program. We also paid quarterly dividends of $121 million and distributed $98 million to noncontrolling interest. 
Yesterday, we announced that our board approved a 10% increase to the quarterly dividend, which is now $0.55 a share or $2.20 per share annually. Additionally, during the quarter, TLLP successfully raised approximately $1 billion of debt and equity. TLLP repaid the amounts outstanding under its revolving credit facility, and will use the balance to fund future drops and growth investments. 
As we entered 2016, given the uncertainty MLP capital markets, Tesoro plan to support TLLP's growth and take approximately 50% of drop-down proceeds in the form of TLLP units. Given the success and the strength of TLLP's equity and debt offerings in the second quarter, Tesoro now has the flexibility to receive a greater portion of cash as consideration for future drop-downs. 
With July's last storage and terminalling assets down Martinez, Martinez storage and marine drop downs, TLLP now expects [ph] $50 million to $75 million of net net earnings or approximately $90 million to $110 million of annual EBITDA from drop-downs from Tesoro in 2016, which is an increase of approximately 10% to 30% from previous guidance. 
This increased  EBITDA range for TLLP provides Tesoro the opportunity to obtain higher than previously expected cash proceeds from drop-downs in 2016. 
Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our second quarter outlook in our earnings release issued yesterday. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter. Even with the Tesoro Index, 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portf
componenttext:
Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter. Even with the Tesoro Index, 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portfolio and each has significant synergy opportunities and growth potential. 
Turning to refining operations. On the West Coast, we saw increased product demand in the quarter. Our refining utilization in California was 94%, throughput and capture rates were impacted by unplanned unit downtime in the region. 
In the Pacific Northwest, our performance was impacted by longer-than-planned maintenance in our Kenai, Alaska refinery and this led to lower throughput in the region. 
In the Mid-Continent, the Tesoro Index was down approximately 34% in the second quarter to $14.65. This lower margin environment, along with narrower crude oil differentials, negatively impacted year-over-year operating results. 
For the third quarter, we expect overall refinery utilization to be between 93% and 99%. 
Moving to Logistics. Tesoro Logistics delivered strong operating income and segment EBITDA growth in the quarter despite the continued weak overall commodity environment. TLLP's performance in the quarter was driven by growth in our crude oil pipeline gathering, natural gas liquids processing, terminalling and pipeline transportation throughput as well as contributions from the Los Angeles Storage and Handling Asset acquisition. 
Year-to-date, TLLP has seen volume growth of approximately 23% in crude oil pipeline gathering volumes, 5% in NGL processing throughput, 4% in terminalling throughput and 4% in pipeline transportation volumes over the same period last year. 
Additionally, on July 1, Tesoro agreed to sell storage and terminalling assets in Alaska to TLLP for $444 million. These assets include crude oil, feedstock and refine product storage tanks in Kenai, Alaska and refine product terminals in Anchorage and Fairbanks. 
The total acquisition price includes cash proceeds to Tesoro of $400 million and the issuance of common and general partner units to Tesoro valued at about $44 million. 
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP the opportunity to acquire crude oil and refined product storage and marine assets in Martinez, California in the second half of this year these. Assets could add $16 million to $36 million of annual net earnings and $40 million to $60 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. 
Also, Tesoro now expects to offer the previously announced Great Northern Midstream assets in North Dakota for sale to TLLP sometime after this year. 
Looking forward, TLLP continues to grow its business and remains on track to achieve our target of $825 million of annual operating income and $1 billion in annual segment EBITDA by year-end of next year. 
Shifting to our Marketing business. Overall performance in the quarter was good. During the second quarter, we saw a continuing positive trends in the market and in our business. 
Continued strong consumer demand with gasoline demand up 2.5% through May, an increase in vehicle miles traveled of 3.4% through the same time period, growth in Tesoro's fuel volumes of about 6%, an increase -- 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network and marketing integration, as Steven said, increased to 98% versus 93% last year. 
We remain excited about the growth prospects we see in this business. Against a backdrop of a strong economy, growth in consumer demand and favorable conditions in the markets in which we operate, we continue to expand our network of stations in focus on growth opportunities towards our goal of $916 [ph] million of operating income and $1 billion of segment EBITDA by 2018. 
Turning to strategic acquisitions and project updates. We closed the acquisition of wholesale marketing and logistics assets in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska in June. The acquisition enhances our capability to efficiently and reliably serve our customers in the State of Alaska. 
In addition, as I referenced earlier, we agreed to sell the Logistics portion of this acquisition to TLLP in July. We also acquired the Dakota Prairie refinery, a 20,000 barrel a day refinery in Dickinson, North Dakota and its associated business. 
A brief update on the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State's Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC concluded the 5-week period portion of adjudicative phase on July 29 of this year. On -- Once EFSEC issue of final environmental impact statement, they will provide a recommendation to the Governor of Washington. 
We are very committed to the proposed 360,000-barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the State of Washington and the West Coast.
Moving to the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project, we continue to make progress on the permitting process, the public comment period closed in mid-June and the South Coast Air Quality Management District is currently responding to the comments that were submitted and preparing the final environmental impact report. 
We continue to expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of this year and plan to begin construction thereafter. 
As you know, we are excited about this project because it enhances our position on the West Coast and offers several benefits, including the full integration of the Carson and Wilmington operations, yield flexibility of 30,000 to 40,000 barrels per day between gasoline and distillates and a significant reduction in greenhouse gas and other criteria pollutant emissions. 
To provide you an update on the progress to deliver improvements in our business, at our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out our expectations for 2016, which were based upon a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel, Marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon, crude oil differentials that reflect the cost of transportation and year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiencies of $500 million to $600 million. 
Through the first half of the year, the Tesoro Index and Marketing fuel margins are basically in line with our expectations. Crude oil differentials, however, continued to be significantly narrower than our expectations. This has resulted in lower capture rates and lower refining profitability than our original expectations for this year. 
Refining utilization is at the low end of our expectations, primarily due to unplanned maintenance. As a result, we now expect year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiency of $400 million to $500 million. 
Additionally, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income in 2016, consisting of $200 million the $250 million in refining, $175 million to $200 million in logistics and $25 million to $50 million in marketing. 
As Steven said, through the first half of 2016, our estimate and Refining and Marketing improvements are on track with our full year expectations, while logistics improvements are tracking slightly below the range, which is primarily attributable to slower-than-expected organic growth due to the weak commodity price environment. 
For the full year 2016, we remain committed to delivering the $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income we laid out at our Analyst at Investor Day. 
Let me conclude by saying that we are committed to creating shareholder value by continuing to optimize our assets across the value chain, driving improvements in the business and growing and transforming our portfolio of refining, logistics and marketing assets. 
Now we will take your questions. Operator?

componenttext: It's Jeff Dietert with Simmons. headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first 1 was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning in July. The second 1 originally was anticipated to be the
componenttext: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first 1 was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning in July. The second 1 originally was anticipated to be the what we refer to as the Great Northern pipeline system in North Dakota, which was the acquisition that Tesoro made in January of this year. But as we guided into that business more and we looked at how we wanted to commercializes those assets, we always recognize when we made the acquisition that we wanted to make some changes that would provide the service and the cost effectiveness to the producers and that's just taking us a little bit longer than we anticipated. We had hoped to be able to completed for the second half of 2016. That's going to be a little bit slower so we'll move that forward, and we prepared already to do the drop we're doing at Martinez in the first half of 2017. So we have effectively just flip the 2 transactions and so fundamentally, there's really no change.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, when you look prior 2016, we typically and one of the reasons we have and MLP when we drop is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for the value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's a very also very, very good
componenttext: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, when you look prior 2016, we typically and one of the reasons we have and MLP when we drop is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for the value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's a very also very, very good for Tesoro. Heading into this year, there's tremendous uncertainty if you recall in the first quarter around the capital markets and MLP space and our base plan was only to get about 50% cash from those drops. You can see in the first drop that we just announced, Greg highlighted this morning, that we got 90% cash. i have no reason to expect that this point that we won't see substantially higher than 50% cash in the next drop as well.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast peer. I mean just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do think it's putting p
componenttext: So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast peer. I mean just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do think it's putting pressure on it during the summer driving season? Is it function of imports from Asia? Is it the restart of [ph] as a combination of couple different things? What's the mechanism you see that clears this up?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Neil, the short-term observation that you just made for the month of July is kind of right on because that's what we have on our website as you stated. So I think it's more important to take a step back and look at the fundamental drivers in
componenttext: Yes, I think, Neil, the short-term observation that you just made for the month of July is kind of right on because that's what we have on our website as you stated. So I think it's more important to take a step back and look at the fundamental drivers in the West Coast region in the United States and from everything that we've been both observing and saying over the last couple of 2 or 3 years, you see a continued strong demand growth, the refineries have been running in the utilization rate that they typically have because the market has been in a position where to supply the product, and the -- with the demand and the overall fundamentals, we see the market as being very, very attractive from a fundamental analysis standpoint. However, today, we find ourselves in a period of time where the markets are a lot weaker, and you probably hit the nail on the head with the 2 points that you made, you have -- we did experience in of the higher levels of imports during the transition of ownership and an refinery in California and that change in ownership is kind the working its way through the system. But as we look forward, the fundamentals to us are as attractive as they've ever been. And so we don't see anything that would indicate to us that there's any structural change in the market that would have an impact on the margin environment going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the [ph] from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?
componenttext: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the [ph] from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, you don't actually need a product to get into their -- the market right now. The market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, you don't actually need a product to get into their -- the market right now. The market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then a follow-up question here is on retail. Going back to your retail indicators here, July has been outstanding. And so can you talk a little bit about the margin environment and why you're seeing that strength? Is just a reflection of demand
componenttext: Great. And then a follow-up question here is on retail. Going back to your retail indicators here, July has been outstanding. And so can you talk a little bit about the margin environment and why you're seeing that strength? Is just a reflection of demand or something else? And then as we look at your stock, there's an argument that you are not getting a lot of credit for that marketing or retail business. What's the path to unlocking the value?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I mean, you used the right word to describe the market environment. So I don't -- for retail, I mean, it's very good right now. It's been -- It's actually in the second quarter was a little bit -- it was a relatively stable market environment now
componenttext: Yes, so I mean, you used the right word to describe the market environment. So I don't -- for retail, I mean, it's very good right now. It's been -- It's actually in the second quarter was a little bit -- it was a relatively stable market environment now and as a result, our margins were a little bit on the lower end of what we would have expected in that but demand was good and the supply customers worked extremely well and the same dynamics we believe are in place that we've had for some time. So we see a very good outlook for the supply to the customers in the third quarter. The -- your second question about the -- how our shares show up in the marketplace, I think, just probably 3 or 4 key comments. One is, as you know and everyone else knows, we are absolutely committed to continued to drive improvements in their business, which we've demonstrated to be very good at being able to deliver those improvements. And as both Steven and I stated, we're on track to accomplish what we laid out for this year and we'll lay out our plans for next year at the end of this year. So I think that's important. In the -- from a refining standpoint, we are absolutely committed to driving a very strong operating excellence management system, which translates into high reliability in our refining operations. The second quarter was not good for us. We experienced some unplanned maintenance that we didn't expect to have and we've dealt with that. It's all been taken care off and we are running extremely well right now. So that was about a little bit disappointing but it's that focus on driving that continued operating excellence and in our operations. We want to be able to continue to grow both the Logistics business, and we're encouraged about to what we see out there and the things we're working on as well as the Marketing business. We're in the early stages of our plans that we talked about last year on Marketing. We -- Steven mentioned that the number of our station count is up about 8% year-on-year, which is strong growth primarily in what people refer to as the wholesale or the jumper channel, and we continue to drive fundamental improvement in the marketing business. So we're going to stay absolutely focus on those commitments that we've made to drive improvements in the business, and we believe that the market will see the impact of that as we move forward over time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, Steven. One thing also, I think, if you look back earlier in the year, the value of refineries logistics assets and the ability to generate cash from those assets versus either being a decline in the rate of growth or the inability to access the cap
componenttext: Neil, Steven. One thing also, I think, if you look back earlier in the year, the value of refineries logistics assets and the ability to generate cash from those assets versus either being a decline in the rate of growth or the inability to access the capital markets, I think that's something that we continue to demonstrate the strength of TLLP on a relative basis. So I think that, that's 1 element of what we've been doing as well, to your earlier point, it may not be recognized.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Greg, may be a follow-up on some of the comments here on the West Coast gasoline market. When you've talked before or if you look back several years ago, the thought was always the California refineries or West Coast refineries run for that in th
componenttext: I guess, Greg, may be a follow-up on some of the comments here on the West Coast gasoline market. When you've talked before or if you look back several years ago, the thought was always the California refineries or West Coast refineries run for that in the market was at an oversupply. One goes down, the market gets great. You made a comment that we don't need an extra products right now and it seems to me that most of the West Coast is running fairly well. Is there any changes in the we're looking at that? Is demand a little bit weaker or just a discussion of the imports that came in earlier? I'm just trying to get a feeling of that fundamental shift underway in the West Coast of sort of almost permanent undersupply or exactly what we're looking at?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Roger, probably nothing further to add when you do just a pure fundamental analysis of the West Coast market. Our indications are when refineries running at relatively high utilization rates, that the gasoline market needs a small amount of imports t
componenttext: Yes, Roger, probably nothing further to add when you do just a pure fundamental analysis of the West Coast market. Our indications are when refineries running at relatively high utilization rates, that the gasoline market needs a small amount of imports to meet the needs of the marketplace and that analysis hasn't changed. So we see good demand still. We see refineries running at the higher end of the utilization versus historical levels. But all in the inventory levels are comfortable level they are kind of where they are on 5-year average standpoints. So all of those factors look would. We do not see anything that would give any indication other than what we've already said, really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay and kind of following up on that. The retail demand obviously looks good. If you look out to next and we have another 1-or-so percent net growth and fuel demand, I mean, that would imply that California is going ultimately need a slightly higher level of imports or much better utilization across the whole platform, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right. The other thing to do factor in as you look out is as you know, as you need to look at what the maintenance plans are for the entire refining system and how that would impact the supply demand balance. So it could require a litt
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right. The other thing to do factor in as you look out is as you know, as you need to look at what the maintenance plans are for the entire refining system and how that would impact the supply demand balance. So it could require a little bit more productive dependent upon the level of maintenance activity on a relative basis. But it would require more imports.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just the last question, the permit process for the California integration or the Southern California integration, are there any particular hurdles we should be watching for here, a particular date, a vote would occur, anything like that?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's no. The actual hearing process culminated probably 5 or 6 weeks ago, all of that is in the hands of the South Coast Quality Management District. We believe we're in the window for the permit to be granted here and as I stated, we're on track to st
componenttext: There's no. The actual hearing process culminated probably 5 or 6 weeks ago, all of that is in the hands of the South Coast Quality Management District. We believe we're in the window for the permit to be granted here and as I stated, we're on track to start construction as soon as we receive the permits. So we're just going through that final stages of the process really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I want to tie in with Jeff's comment on the, I guess, the cash balance into the second half of the year and how that ties in with the buybacks. Obviously, you had a decent amount of buybacks in Q2. But I'm just curious, should we be thinking of a mo
componenttext: Greg, I want to tie in with Jeff's comment on the, I guess, the cash balance into the second half of the year and how that ties in with the buybacks. Obviously, you had a decent amount of buybacks in Q2. But I'm just curious, should we be thinking of a more ratable program since you have so much cash coming from the drops I guess, regardless of what the macro environment looks like I mean, it seems like that allows you to kind of continue purchasing throughout the cycle. But I just wanted to confirm that that's kind of what you were thinking?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Steven to comment on that, Blake.
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Steven to comment on that, Blake.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake. Our strategy of really working to have the flexibility to either make strategic investment, acquisition and return cash to shareholders throughout the cycle has really been our consistent approach and focus. And that's still true today. To you
componenttext: Yes, Blake. Our strategy of really working to have the flexibility to either make strategic investment, acquisition and return cash to shareholders throughout the cycle has really been our consistent approach and focus. And that's still true today. To your point, as you we do some share repurchases in the second quarter, I wouldn't think about it as necessarily being just a ratable fixed amount but our goal is to be able to generate cash to fully execute our growth plan and continue to buy back shares as well as grow the dividend over time commensurate of the growth of the underlying business portfolio. And so you should expect us to continue to execute that way.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. The second question was on the, I guess, the recent acquisition of the Dakota Prairie Asset. For 1, I see there is an uptick in the Mid-Con throughput. I am assuming that's a function of that asset being added to the mix. But more broadly speaking
componenttext: Got it. The second question was on the, I guess, the recent acquisition of the Dakota Prairie Asset. For 1, I see there is an uptick in the Mid-Con throughput. I am assuming that's a function of that asset being added to the mix. But more broadly speaking, I guess can you just talk about some of the longer term opportunities there. It seems like given the construction cost of that asset, what you actually paid for or I guess you basically assume debt, it seems the current opportunity once they can differentials kind of move back in our favor?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake. I think there are 3 key points to make about what we now refer to as the Dickinson refinery is that 1, because of our system approach to operating the business, we will be able to deliver probably more than what we stated earlier from the syne
componenttext: Yes, Blake. I think there are 3 key points to make about what we now refer to as the Dickinson refinery is that 1, because of our system approach to operating the business, we will be able to deliver probably more than what we stated earlier from the synergy impact if you recall our press release, we stated that we expect it to deliver about $20 million of synergies. And once we got actually into the business, which I'll remind you is only been about 30 days, we've actually seen more opportunities which is always encouraging. And so for being able to operate in our system, it will fit in very, very well to the Tesoro total integrated value chain. The other 2 points are that 1, we will continue to supply ultra-low sulfur diesel to the business market that the Dickinson refinery operates in. And more encouragingly, the naphtha and resid that comes of the refinery will fit extremely well into other refineries in Tesoro, which will be able to upgrade by running it through primarily our cat crackers. So that will provide an added benefit versus what was done with the particularly the NAFTA in the past. And then the third thing is that we are in the early stages. We see other opportunities with refineries. So the way that the refinery is constructed provides the potential opportunity to produce renewable diesel and that is something that we're in the early stages of evaluating, and we would expect to have that work done by the latter part of this year and that's important because when you look at the total system and particularly in the State of California and our need for renewable diesel, the value of producing it versus purchasing it is very, very attractive. And so we're reasonably optimistic we'll be able to make that happen going forward here. So that's the value of the Dickinson refinery to Tesoro.

componenttext: Great. And just rounding that up that's part of the throughput increase I'm assuming in 3Q obviously, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: First of all, thanks for the breakout of the inventory impact regionally in the press release. That's helpful. I was just looking at the sort of California results, and you know net of inventory, the capture looks like it was affected by the downtime you mentioned. I was wondering if there were any other factors there, specifically if there's been a change to the residents to the segment residents of RINs in the consolidated system? If you recognize those in marketing now and transfer them back to refining or if it's the same as it has been?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only impact to our results for California for 2Q is the result of some unplanned maintenance that showed up in both lower throughput and the capture rate. That's it.
componenttext: The only impact to our results for California for 2Q is the result of some unplanned maintenance that showed up in both lower throughput and the capture rate. That's it.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just following up on the Great Northern assets, I recall there's -- for that transaction, there's a pretty wide arbitrage between the acquisition valuation and what you can drop it down for. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in the
componenttext: Okay. And then just following up on the Great Northern assets, I recall there's -- for that transaction, there's a pretty wide arbitrage between the acquisition valuation and what you can drop it down for. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in the landscape that's continuing that trend or if it is -- if that spread has been dynamic given the commodity environment?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me correct what you said because that statement at the beginning is not accurate. There is no white arbitrage. What we said about the acquisition of the Great Northern assets was that we paid a very attractive value on a relative basis and that our in
componenttext: Let me correct what you said because that statement at the beginning is not accurate. There is no white arbitrage. What we said about the acquisition of the Great Northern assets was that we paid a very attractive value on a relative basis and that our intention was to then take those assets. And if the appropriate time after we, I guess, the best way to describe it is if we further commercialize that system into the overall Tesoro North Dakota system, we would sell that to Tesoro Logistics. But it's incorrect to state that there's some white arbitrage. That's not accurate.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chi Chow of Tudor figuring.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chi Chow of Tudor figuring.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, so with the downturn in the crude market this year, are you seeing any actions on your transportation costs coming down in your regions? And specifically, is it making rail and your terminal fees on rail actually better option at this point versus k
componenttext: Greg, so with the downturn in the crude market this year, are you seeing any actions on your transportation costs coming down in your regions? And specifically, is it making rail and your terminal fees on rail actually better option at this point versus kind of what we're seeing from last year?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So we have mentioned this in the past that directionally, we would see changes in the cost, the total cost structure. And for Tesoro, that's moving block and crude from the North Dakota to the West Coast us you are ware, we would see changes i
componenttext: Absolutely. So we have mentioned this in the past that directionally, we would see changes in the cost, the total cost structure. And for Tesoro, that's moving block and crude from the North Dakota to the West Coast us you are ware, we would see changes in natural repeat the significant changes to make the movement of rail more competitive with, for example, pipeline out of Bakken and that is absolutely starting to happen across all parts of that supply chain and kind of along the lines of what we thought it would be. So we are very confident that when that -- all those changes worked their way through, which probably isn't too far off from now, the movement of Bakken crude oil by rail to the Pacific Northwest would be very competitive with pipeline shipments out of North Dakota.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then I also have a West Coast market question. Not so much on imports coming in but on the export market. Are there strategies that you're looking to grow that market for you out of California? How important is that market? Seems like Latin America and Mexico, it's been a designation even from the West Coast. There's been some reports of Chinese barrels even showing up in Mexico these days. Just -- any sort of a discussion on what you're seeing in that dynamic? Any competition for that sort of market and what are you going to do to grow that market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, if you look at the regional supply demand, and you take the West Coast to both starting all the way we from West Coast of Canada to the United States into Mexico, you will see that there's a need for imports into that greater region. And as kind
componenttext: I think, if you look at the regional supply demand, and you take the West Coast to both starting all the way we from West Coast of Canada to the United States into Mexico, you will see that there's a need for imports into that greater region. And as kind of a natural flow, it makes sense for particularly state of Pacific Northwest to be able to move product into Mexico. We see about 140,000-barrel a day need for product on the West Coast of Mexico for gasoline and distillates and kind of a natural place for that is to curve a system balance across that whole Western region. And so as a company, we've stated many times in the past that it's a natural part of our system and moving product into Mexico, Chile and Peru primarily. We don't see any structural changes on that. We still see, especially Mexico to have the strong need and healthy and reasonably good demand growth. And that presents to go above that business different ways that are just in the early stages of looking at to see what makes sense for Tesoro kind of over time and we don't have an answer for that yet.

componenttext: So, Phil, if you reflect back on what you said in December of last year, I think, we broke it down into 2 pieces. The first piece we said was that with the existing assets in the company, we had somewhere -- I'm just going off from memory here, but something between $350 million to $500 million of EBITDA attributable to those assets. And then we said we had another $150 million to $250 million or so with the things we're working on will ultimately be dropped down in there and that hasn't changed. That is unchanged from what we said then. So what have we done? Well 1, what we talked about earlier is we sold part of what was -- part of the EBITDA kind of let's call it the legacy Tesoro assets, which was the Alaska assets around the [ph] refinery. But in addition, from the other Botha, the other properties we are dropping down the acquisition that we did from Flint Hills Resources and that gives you the EBITDA number that came with that. And then the other only change is instead of taking the EBITDA that would have come from opportunities, which is the Great Northern anthropic down in the second half of this year, as I mentioned, we'll move that out of '16 and bring forward what we plan to do with Martinez that I think in the press release gave an EBITDA number of -- I don't remember what the number is. What is it? Up to around -- up to about $50 million. So that you can just see how that affects the 2 buckets of opportunities that we talked about. So not a big change.

componenttext: Okay, got it. And my second question just on the CapEx, the reduction in the CapEx. Is there any reduction in your sustaining capital requirements relative to what you thought before? headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure a
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP and financial measures, should help you in analyzing our results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
I would like to point out that starting this quarter, Tesoro will no longer be reporting adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS, but will continue to highlight significant items impacting quarterly results to help you analyze our performance. Further information can be found in the earnings release issued yesterday.
Please refer to the forward-looking statement in the earnings release, which says statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and our future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act, as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 m
componenttext:
Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 million attributable to Tesoro or $3.47 per diluted share compared to $586 million or $4.62 a share a year ago. 
Consolidated net earnings were $449 million for the second quarter compared to $620 million for the same period last year, and EBITDA for the second quarter was $956 million compared to $1.2 billion a year ago. 
Reported earnings and EBITDA for the quarter included a pretax inventory benefit due to a lower cost of market valuation adjustment of $363 million or $220 million after-tax. 
Our second quarter 2016 results reflect continued growth in our Logistics business and strong performance in marketing, offset by lower-than-expected performance in refining. 
Turning to the business segments. Refining operating income was $520 million for the second quarter compared to $757 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $692 million versus $880 million last year. 
The Tesoro Index was $13.93 a barrel in the second quarter with a gross refining margin of $15.70 a barrel or 113% of the Tesoro Index. This compares to gross refining margin of $19.13 per barrel or 89% of the Tesoro Index last year. 
Please remember that gross refining margin in the quarter included a pretax benefit of $363 million related to the LCM inventory adjustment. 
Total refining throughput for the quarter was at the lower end of our guidance at 802,000 barrels a day or 92% utilization. During the quarter, we had an extension of the planned maintenance at our Kenai, Alaska refinery as well as unplanned unit downtime within our California region and both of these impacted our throughput and capture rates. 
Manufacturing costs in the second quarter decreased $0.57 a barrel over the same period last year to $5.01. This year-over-year decrease was due to the higher throughput in '16 compared to 2015, but also a decline in natural gas prices. 
Tesoro's integrated business model helps mitigate our exposure to RINs, however, the price of RINs increased in the second quarter and impacted us by approximately $10 million. 
Moving to Logistics. Operating income increased to $125 million in the second quarter from $104 million a year ago and segment EBITDA grew to $172 million from $149 million last year. 
Results benefited from year-over-year volume growth in the crude oil gathering and terminalling transportation businesses as well as contributions from TLP's acquisition of the LA storage and handling assets. 
The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $59 million during the second quarter. This is an increase of $26 million or 79% versus 2015. 
Turning to marketing. Operating income was $161 million compared to $212 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $173 million compared to $223 million last year. 
Our fuel margins were $0.105 a gallon in the second quarter. During the second quarter, we saw continued strong fundamentals and favorable business conditions. These include: Growth in consumer demand; increase in vehicle miles traveled; growth in Tesoro's fuel sale volumes of 6%; and 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network; and marketing integration increased to 98% from 93% a year ago. 
Now I'd like to take a moment to discuss our continued focus on creating value for shareholders by driving improvements in our business, then I'll discuss our financial discipline and principles of capital allocation. 
We remain committed to driving improvements in the earnings of our business each year and in all cycles of the industry. In 2016, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of operating income and EBITDA improvements through these efforts. This includes organic growth and acquisitions in our logistics business, growth in our marketing business and costs, yields and other efficiencies in refining and commercial operations. We're on track to deliver these results in 2016. 
These improvements can be seen in our relative performance over time. In fact, if you look at Tesoro's earnings CAGR since 2014 versus that of our core peers, you'll see our overall earnings were down approximately 4% due to lower overall refining industry margins and crude differentials. However, the core peer group is down approximately 15% to 25%. We believe this reflects the impact of our continued focus on driving business improvements every year. 
Further, the same relative outperformance can be seen in our free cash flow yields. This continued focus on and execution of driving improvements results in significant shareholder value creation and that continues to be seen in our cash flows and capital allocation priorities. 
We ended the quarter with a consolidated cash balance of $1.1 billion compared to $942 million at the end of 2015. Our balance sheet remains strong, with a total debt, net of unamortized issuance costs to capitalization ratio of 36%. 
Excluding TLLP debt and equity, our debt-to-capitalization ratio was 19% at the end of the second quarter. We also currently have $2.1 billion of availability under our revolving credit facility. We continue to believe that we are well-positioned to obtain the investment-grade ratings for both companies. Investment-grade credit ratings for Tesoro and TLLP offer substantial benefits to both companies, including lower relative debt spreads of 100 to 200 basis points over time, potential combined interest cost savings of $80 million to $105 million and most importantly, the ability to access extended debt maturities for TLLP. 
Turning to cash flows. Tesoro generated $444 million of cash flow from operating activities in the second quarter. Now I'll discuss how we deploy cash to create long-term shareholder value. 
First, we invest in high-return capital projects and grow returns on invested capital. During the quarter, we invested $105 million in income growth per capital projects at Tesoro and TLLP. Our combined capital expenditures through the first half of 2016 were approximately $400 million. We expect 2016 capital spending of approximately $1 billion, which is consistent with our previously announced plan. 
Second, we continue to ensure we have some balance sheet to give us the flexibility to make strategic investments and return cash to shareholders. In the quarter, we spent approximately $80 million on 2 highly accretive acquisitions. 
We continue to look for additional opportunities and are currently focusing on targets in midstream and other assets, which can enhance our integrated business model. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased 1.3 million shares for approximately $100 million. Tesoro currently has $1.3 billion remaining under its previously approved share repurchase program. We also paid quarterly dividends of $121 million and distributed $98 million to noncontrolling interest. 
Yesterday, we announced that our board approved a 10% increase to the quarterly dividend, which is now $0.55 a share or $2.20 per share annually. Additionally, during the quarter, TLLP successfully raised approximately $1 billion of debt and equity. TLLP repaid the amounts outstanding under its revolving credit facility, and will use the balance to fund future drops and growth investments. 
As we entered 2016, given the uncertainty in MLP capital markets, Tesoro plan to support TLLP's growth and take approximately 50% of drop-down proceeds in the form of TLLP units. Given the success and the strength of TLLP's equity and debt offerings in the second quarter, Tesoro now has the flexibility to receive a greater portion of cash as consideration for future drop-downs. 
With July's Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets drop-down and the new announced Martinez -- Martinez storage and marine assets drop-down, TLLP now expects probably $50 million to $75 million of net earnings or approximately $90 million to $110 million of annual EBITDA from drop-downs from Tesoro in 2016, which is an increase of approximately 10% to 30% from previous guidance. 
This increased  EBITDA range for TLLP provides Tesoro the opportunity to obtain higher than previously expected cash proceeds from drop-downs in 2016. 
Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our second quarter outlook in our earnings release issued yesterday. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter even with the Tesoro Index 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portfol
componenttext:
Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter even with the Tesoro Index 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portfolio and each has significant synergy opportunities and growth potential. 
Turning to refining operations. On the West Coast, we saw increased product demand in the quarter. Our refining utilization in California was 94%, throughput and capture rates were impacted by unplanned unit downtime in the region. 
In the Pacific Northwest, our performance was impacted by longer-than-planned maintenance at our Kenai, Alaska refinery and this led to lower throughput in the region. 
In the Mid-Continent, the Tesoro Index was down approximately 34% in the second quarter to $14.65. This lower margin environment, along with narrower crude oil differentials, negatively impacted year-over-year operating results. 
For the third quarter, we expect overall refinery utilization to be between 93% and 99%. 
Moving to Logistics. Tesoro Logistics delivered strong operating income and segment EBITDA growth in the quarter despite the continued weak overall commodity environment. TLLP's performance in the quarter was driven by growth in our crude oil pipeline gathering, natural gas liquids processing, terminalling and pipeline transportation throughput as well as contributions from the Los Angeles Storage and Handling Asset acquisition. 
Year-to-date, TLLP has seen volume growth of approximately 23% in crude oil pipeline gathering volumes, 5% in NGL processing throughput, 4% in terminalling throughput and 4% in pipeline transportation volumes over the same period last year. 
Additionally, on July 1, Tesoro agreed to sell storage and terminalling assets in Alaska to TLLP for $444 million. These assets include crude oil, feedstock and refined product storage tanks in Kenai, Alaska and refined product terminals in Anchorage and Fairbanks. 
The total acquisition price includes cash proceeds to Tesoro of $400 million and the issuance of common and general partner units to Tesoro valued at about $44 million. 
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP the opportunity to acquire crude oil and refined product storage and marine assets in Martinez, California in the second half of this year. These assets could add $16 million to $36 million of annual net earnings and $40 million to $60 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. 
Also, Tesoro now expects to offer the previously announced Great Northern Midstream assets in North Dakota for sale to TLLP sometime after this year. 
Looking forward, TLLP continues to grow its business and remains on track to achieve our target of $825 million of annual operating income and $1 billion in annual segment EBITDA by year-end of next year. 
Shifting to our Marketing business. Overall performance in the quarter was good. During the second quarter, we saw continuing positive trends in the market and in our business. 
Continued strong consumer demand with gasoline demand up 2.5% through May, an increase in vehicle miles traveled of 3.4% through the same time period, growth in Tesoro's fuel volumes of about 6%, an increase -- 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network and marketing integration, as Steven said, increased to 98% versus 93% last year. 
We remain excited about the growth prospects we see in this business. Against a backdrop of a strong economy, growth in consumer demand and favorable conditions in the markets in which we operate, we continue to expand our network of stations and focus on growth opportunities towards our goal of $960 million of operating income and $1 billion of segment EBITDA by 2018. 
Turning to strategic acquisitions and project updates. We closed the acquisition of wholesale marketing and logistics assets in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska in June. The acquisition enhances our capability to efficiently and reliably serve our customers in the State of Alaska. 
In addition, as I referenced earlier, we agreed to sell the Logistics portion of this acquisition to TLLP in July. We also acquired the Dakota Prairie refinery, a 20,000 barrel a day refinery in Dickinson, North Dakota and its associated business. 
A brief update on the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State's Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC concluded the 5-week hearing portion of the adjudicative phase on July 29 of this year. On -- Once EFSEC issues a final environmental impact statement, they will provide a recommendation to the Governor of Washington. 
We are very committed to the proposed 360,000 barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the State of Washington and the West Coast.
Moving to the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project, we continue to make progress on the permitting process, the public comment period closed in mid-June and the South Coast Air Quality Management District is currently responding to the comments that were submitted and preparing the final environmental impact report. 
We continue to expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of this year and plan to begin construction thereafter. 
As you know, we are excited about this project because it enhances our position on the West Coast and offers several benefits, including the full integration of the Carson and Wilmington operations, yield flexibility of 30,000 to 40,000 barrels per day between gasoline and distillates and a significant reduction in greenhouse gas and other criteria pollutant emissions. 
To provide you an update on the progress to deliver improvements in our business, at our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out our expectations for 2016, which were based upon a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel, Marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon, crude oil differentials that reflect the cost of transportation and year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiencies of $500 million to $600 million. 
Through the first half of the year, the Tesoro Index and Marketing fuel margins are basically in line with our expectations. Crude oil differentials, however, continued to be significantly narrower than our expectations. This has resulted in lower capture rates and lower refining profitability than our original expectations for this year. 
Refining utilization is at the low end of our expectations, primarily due to unplanned maintenance. As a result, we now expect year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiency of $400 million to $500 million. 
Additionally, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income in 2016, consisting of $200 million to $250 million in refining, $175 million to $200 million in logistics and $25 million to $50 million in marketing. 
As Steven said, through the first half of 2016, our estimated Refining and Marketing improvements are on track with our full year expectations, while logistics improvements are tracking slightly below the range, which is primarily attributable to slower-than-expected organic growth due to the weak commodity price environment. 
For the full year 2016, we remain committed to delivering the $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income we laid out at our Analyst and Investor Day. 
Let me conclude by saying that we are committed to creating shareholder value by continuing to optimize our assets across the value chain, driving improvements in the business and growing and transforming our portfolio of refining, logistics and marketing assets.   
Now we will take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first 1 was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning in July. The second 1 originally was anticipated to be wha
componenttext: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first 1 was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning in July. The second 1 originally was anticipated to be what we refer to as the Great Northern pipeline system in North Dakota, which was the acquisition that Tesoro made in January of this year. But as we guided into that business more and we looked at how we wanted to commercialize those assets, we always recognize when we made the acquisition that we wanted to make some changes that would provide the service and the cost effectiveness to the producers and that's just taking us a little bit longer than we anticipated. We had hoped to be able to complete it for the second half of 2016. That's going to be a little bit slower, so we'll move that forward, and we were prepared already to do the drop we're doing at Martinez in the first half of 2017. So we  effectively just flipped the 2 transactions and so fundamentally, there's really no change.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, if you look prior to 2016, we typically and one of the reasons we have an MLP when we do drop is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's also very very good for Teso
componenttext: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, if you look prior to 2016, we typically and one of the reasons we have an MLP when we do drop is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's also very very good for Tesoro. Heading into this year, there's tremendous uncertainty if you recall in the first quarter around the capital markets and MLP space and our base plan was only to get about 50% cash from those drops. You can see in the first drop that we just announced, Greg highlighted this morning that we got 90% cash. I have no reason to expect at this point that we won't see substantially higher than 50% cash in the next drop as well.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast Tier. I'm just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do you think is putting pr
componenttext:
So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast Tier. I'm just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do you think is putting pressure on it during the summer driving season? Is it a function of imports from Asia? Is it the restart of Torrance as a combination of couple different things? What's the mechanism you see that clears this up?
Yes, I think, Neil, the short-term observation that you just made for the month of July is kind of right on because that's what we have on our website as you stated. So I think it's more important to take a step back and look at the fundamental drivers in the West Coast region in the United States and from everything that we've been both observing and saying over the last couple of 2 or 3 years, you see a continued strong demand growth, the refineries have been running in the utilization rate that they typically have because the market has been in a position where to supply the product, and the -- with the demand and the overall fundamentals, we see the market as being very, very attractive from a fundamental analysis standpoint. However, today, we find ourselves in a period of time where the markets are a lot weaker, and you probably hit the nail on the head with the 2 points that you made, you had -- we did experience a little bit higher levels of imports during the transition of ownership in a refinery in California and that change in ownership is kind of working its way through the system. But as we look forward, the fundamentals to us are as attractive as they've ever been. And so we don't see anything that would indicate to us that there's any structural change in the market that would have an impact on the margin environment going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the arb from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?
componenttext: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the arb from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean you don't -- you actually don't need the product to get into their -- to the market right now if the market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.
componenttext: Yes, I mean you don't -- you actually don't need the product to get into their -- to the market right now if the market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
