headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure a
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO.
The earnings release, which includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP and financial measures, should help you in analyzing our results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
I would like to point out that starting this quarter, Tesoro will no longer be reporting adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS, but will continue to highlight significant items impacting quarterly results to help you analyze our performance. Further information can be found in the earnings release issued yesterday.
Please refer to the forward-looking statement in the earnings release, which says statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and our future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act, as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 m
componenttext:
Thank you, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our second quarter 2016 financial performance and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported second quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $418 million attributable to Tesoro or $3.47 per diluted share compared to $586 million or $4.62 a share a year ago. 
Consolidated net earnings were $449 million for the second quarter compared to $620 million for the same period last year, and EBITDA for the second quarter was $956 million compared to $1.2 billion a year ago. 
Reported earnings and EBITDA for the quarter included a pretax inventory benefit due to a lower cost of market valuation adjustment of $363 million or $220 million after-tax. 
Our second quarter 2016 results reflect continued growth in our Logistics business and strong performance in Marketing, offset by lower-than-expected performance in Refining. 
Turning to the business segments. Refining operating income was $520 million for the second quarter compared to $757 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $692 million versus $880 million last year. 
The Tesoro Index was $13.93 a barrel in the second quarter with a gross Refining margin of $15.70 a barrel or 113% of the Tesoro Index. This compares to gross Refining margin of $19.13 per barrel or 89% of the Tesoro Index last year. 
Please remember that gross Refining margin in the quarter included a pretax benefit of $363 million related to the LCM inventory adjustment. 
Total Refining throughput for the quarter was at the lower end of our guidance at 802,000 barrels a day or 92% utilization. During the quarter, we had an extension of the planned maintenance at our Kenai, Alaska refinery as well as unplanned unit downtime within our California region and both of these impacted our throughput and capture rates. 
Manufacturing costs in the second quarter decreased $0.57 a barrel over the same period last year to $5.01. This year-over-year decrease was due to the higher throughput in '16 compared to 2015, but also a decline in natural gas prices. 
Tesoro's integrated business model helps mitigate our exposure to RINs. However, the price of RINs increased in the second quarter and impacted us by approximately $10 million. 
Moving to Logistics. Operating income increased to $125 million in the second quarter from $104 million a year ago and segment EBITDA grew to $172 million from $149 million last year. 
Results benefited from year-over-year volume growth in the crude oil gathering and terminalling and transportation businesses as well as contributions from TLP's acquisition of the LA storage and handling assets. 
The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $59 million during the second quarter. This is an increase of $26 million or 79% versus 2015. 
Turning to Marketing. Operating income was $161 million compared to $212 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $173 million compared to $223 million last year. 
Our fuel margins were $0.105 a gallon in the second quarter. During the second quarter, we saw continued strong fundamentals and favorable business conditions. These include: Growth in consumer demand; increase in vehicle miles traveled; growth in Tesoro's fuel sale volumes of 6%; and 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network; and marketing integration increased to 98% from 93% a year ago. 
Now I'd like to take a moment to discuss our continued focus on creating value for shareholders by driving improvements in our business, then I'll discuss our financial discipline and principles of capital allocation. 
We remain committed to driving improvements in the earnings of our business each year and in all cycles of the industry. In 2016, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of operating income and EBITDA improvements through these efforts. This includes organic growth and acquisitions in our Logistics business, growth in our Marketing business and costs, yields and other efficiencies in Refining and commercial operations. We're on track to deliver these results in 2016. 
These improvements can be seen in our relative performance over time. In fact, if you look at Tesoro's earnings CAGR since 2014 versus that of our core peers, you'll see our overall earnings were down approximately 4% due to lower overall refining industry margins and crude differentials. However, the core peer group is down approximately 15% to 25%. We believe this reflects the impact of our continued focus on driving business improvements every year. 
Further, the same relative outperformance can be seen in our free cash flow yields. This continued focus on and execution of driving improvements results in significant shareholder value creation and that continues to be seen in our cash flows and capital allocation priorities. 
We ended the quarter with a consolidated cash balance of $1.1 billion compared to $942 million at the end of 2015. Our balance sheet remains strong, with a total debt, net of unamortized issuance costs to capitalization ratio of 36%. 
Excluding TLLP debt and equity, our debt-to-capitalization ratio was 19% at the end of the second quarter. We also currently have $2.1 billion of availability under our revolving credit facility. We continue to believe that we are well-positioned to obtain investment-grade ratings for both companies. Investment-grade credit ratings for Tesoro and TLLP offer substantial benefits to both companies, including lower relative debt spreads of 100 to 200 basis points over time, potential combined interest cost savings of $80 million to $105 million and most importantly, the ability to access extended debt maturities for TLLP. 
Turning to cash flows. Tesoro generated $444 million of cash flow from operating activities in the second quarter. Now I'll discuss how we deploy cash to create long-term shareholder value. 
First, we invest in high-return capital projects and grow returns on invested capital. During the quarter, we invested $105 million in income growth for capital projects at Tesoro and TLLP. Our combined capital expenditures through the first half of 2016 were approximately $400 million. We expect 2016 capital spending of approximately $1 billion, which is consistent with our previously announced plan. 
Second, we continue to ensure we have a strong balance sheet to give us the flexibility to make strategic investments and return cash to shareholders. In the quarter, we spent approximately $80 million on 2 highly accretive acquisitions. 
We continue to look for additional opportunities and are currently focusing on targets in midstream and other assets which can enhance our integrated business model. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased 1.3 million shares for approximately $100 million. Tesoro currently has $1.3 billion remaining under its previously approved share repurchase program. We also paid quarterly dividends of $121 million and distributed $98 million to noncontrolling interests. 
Yesterday, we announced that our board approved a 10% increase to the quarterly dividend, which is now $0.55 a share or $2.20 per share annually. Additionally, during the quarter, TLLP successfully raised approximately $1 billion of debt and equity. TLLP repaid the amounts outstanding under its revolving credit facility, and will use the balance to fund future drops and growth investments. 
As we entered 2016, given the uncertainty in MLP capital markets, Tesoro planned to support TLLP's growth and take approximately 50% of drop-down proceeds in the form of TLLP units. Given the success and the strength of TLLP's equity and debt offerings in the second quarter, Tesoro now has the flexibility to receive a greater portion of cash as consideration for future drop-downs. 
With July's Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets drop-down and the new announced Martinez -- Martinez storage and marine assets drop-down, TLLP now expects probably $50 million to $75 million of net earnings or approximately $90 million to $110 million of annual EBITDA from drop-downs from Tesoro in 2016, which is an increase of approximately 10% to 30% from previous guidance. 
This increased EBITDA range for TLLP provides Tesoro the opportunity to obtain higher than previously expected cash proceeds from drop-downs in 2016. 
Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our second quarter outlook in our earnings release issued yesterday. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter even with the Tesoro Index 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portfol
componenttext:
Thank you, Steven, and good morning. Tesoro's integrated business model enabled us to execute well this quarter even with the Tesoro Index 6% lower compared to the average of 2014 and 2015. We completed 2 acquisitions that further strengthened our portfolio and each has significant synergy opportunities and growth potential. 
Turning to refining operations. On the West Coast, we saw increased product demand in the quarter. Our refining utilization in California was 94%. Throughput and capture rates were impacted by unplanned unit downtime in the region. 
In the Pacific Northwest, our performance was impacted by longer-than-planned maintenance at our Kenai, Alaska refinery and this led to lower throughput in the region. 
In the Mid-Continent, the Tesoro Index was down approximately 34% in the second quarter to $14.65. This lower margin environment, along with narrower crude oil differentials, negatively impacted year-over-year operating results. 
For the third quarter, we expect overall refinery utilization to be between 93% and 99%. 
Moving to Logistics. Tesoro Logistics delivered strong operating income and segment EBITDA growth in the quarter despite the continued weak overall commodity environment. TLLP's performance in the quarter was driven by growth in our crude oil pipeline gathering, natural gas liquids processing, terminalling and pipeline transportation throughput as well as contributions from the Los Angeles Storage and Handling Asset acquisition. 
Year-to-date, TLLP has seen volume growth of approximately 23% in crude oil pipeline gathering volumes, 5% in NGL processing throughput, 4% in terminalling throughput and 4% in pipeline transportation volumes over the same period last year. 
Additionally, on July 1, Tesoro agreed to sell storage and terminalling assets in Alaska to TLLP for $444 million. These assets include crude oil, feedstock and refined product storage tanks in Kenai, Alaska and refined product terminals in Anchorage and Fairbanks. 
The total acquisition price includes cash proceeds to Tesoro of $400 million and the issuance of common and general partner units to Tesoro valued at about $44 million. 
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP the opportunity to acquire crude oil and refined product storage and marine assets in Martinez, California in the second half of this year. These assets could add $16 million to $36 million of annual net earnings and $40 million to $60 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. 
Also, Tesoro now expects to offer the previously announced Great Northern Midstream assets in North Dakota for sale to TLLP sometime after this year. 
Looking forward, TLLP continues to grow its business and remains on track to achieve our target of $825 million of annual operating income and $1 billion in annual segment EBITDA by year-end of next year. 
Shifting to our Marketing business. Overall performance in the quarter was good. During the second quarter, we saw continuing positive trends in the market and in our business. 
Continued strong consumer demand with gasoline demand up 2.5% through May, an increase in vehicle miles traveled of 3.4% through the same time period, growth in Tesoro's fuel [ph] volumes of about 6%, an increase -- 8% increase in the total number of stations in our network and marketing integration, as Steven said, increased to 98% versus 93% last year. 
We remain excited about the growth prospects we see in this business. Against a backdrop of a strong economy, growth in consumer demand and favorable conditions in the markets in which we operate, we continue to expand our network of stations and focus on growth opportunities towards our goal of $960 million of operating income and $1 billion of segment EBITDA by 2018. 
Turning to strategic acquisitions and project updates. We closed the acquisition of wholesale marketing and logistics assets in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska in June. The acquisition enhances our capability to efficiently and reliably serve our customers in the State of Alaska. 
In addition, as I referenced earlier, we agreed to sell the Logistics portion of this acquisition to TLLP in July. We also acquired the Dakota Prairie Refinery, a 20,000 barrel a day refinery in Dickinson, North Dakota, and its associated business. 
A brief update on the Vancouver Energy project. The Washington State's Energy Facility Site Evaluation Council or EFSEC concluded the 5-week hearing portion of the adjudicative phase on July 29 of this year. On -- Once EFSEC issues a final environmental impact statement, they will provide a recommendation to the Governor of Washington. 
We are very committed to the proposed 360,000 barrel per day crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will clearly demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe, environmentally-responsible facility that offers benefits to the State of Washington and the West Coast.
Moving to the Los Angeles Refinery integration and compliance project. We continue to make progress on the permitting process, the public comment period closed in mid-June and the South Coast Air Quality Management District is currently responding to the comments that were submitted and preparing the final environmental impact report. 
We continue to expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of this year and plan to begin construction thereafter. 
As you know, we are excited about this project because it enhances our position on the West Coast and offers several benefits, including the full integration of the Carson and Wilmington operations, yield flexibility of 30,000 to 40,000 barrels per day between gasoline and distillates and a significant reduction in greenhouse gas and other criteria pollutant emissions. 
To provide you an update on the progress to deliver improvements in our business, at our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out our expectations for 2016, which were based upon a Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel, marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon, crude oil differentials that reflect the cost of transportation and year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiencies of $500 million to $600 million. 
Through the first half of the year, the Tesoro Index and marketing fuel margins are basically in line with our expectations. Crude oil differentials, however, continued to be significantly narrower than our expectations. This has resulted in lower capture rates and lower refining profitability than our original expectations for this year. 
Refining utilization is at the low end of our expectations, primarily due to unplanned maintenance. As a result, we now expect year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiency of $400 million to $500 million. 
Additionally, we committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income in 2016, consisting of $200 million to $250 million in Refining, $175 million to $200 million in Logistics and $25 million to $50 million in Marketing. 
As Steven said, through the first half of 2016, our estimated Refining and Marketing improvements are on track with our full year expectations, while Logistics improvements are tracking slightly below the range, which is primarily attributable to slower-than-expected organic growth due to the weak commodity price environment. 
For the full year 2016, we remain committed to delivering the $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income we laid out at our Analyst and Investor Day. 
Let me conclude by saying that we are committed to creating shareholder value by continuing to optimize our assets across the value chain, driving improvements in the business and growing and transforming our portfolio of Refining, Logistics and Marketing assets. 
Now we will take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert of Simmons.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert of Simmons.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff Dietert with Simmons. You've announced or agreed on the Alaska Storage and Terminalling sale down to TLLP and with today's announcement, the Martinez assets, and these are drawing bigger cash portions than you previously discussed. You kind of a
componenttext: It's Jeff Dietert with Simmons. You've announced or agreed on the Alaska Storage and Terminalling sale down to TLLP and with today's announcement, the Martinez assets, and these are drawing bigger cash portions than you previously discussed. You kind of add the lower CapEx that you announced in the first quarter call and throughput guidance that looks healthy for 3Q, no sign of major maintenance. It looks like there's a pretty meaningful step function increase in cash in the back half of the year. Am I interpreting that correctly? Could you discuss that a little bit?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right, Jeff. If you take everything that you just talked about and our starting point from what Steven just mentioned that we ended the quarter with $1.1 billion cash balance and you add up our -- the factors, I won't even elaborate on
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right, Jeff. If you take everything that you just talked about and our starting point from what Steven just mentioned that we ended the quarter with $1.1 billion cash balance and you add up our -- the factors, I won't even elaborate on those, what you've stated. It would suggest that our cash balance would be significantly higher at the end of the year, particularly versus what we laid out with our plans. And I think the important point is, and I don't probably need to reiterate, but Steven laid out our allocation of capital and that's basically unchanged as we move forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it appears that this -- it looks like a step-up in drop-downs into TLLP, but again, it's allowing you to meet your targets that you discussed last December. Is this really in line with your expectations or is there some acceleration there?
componenttext: And it appears that this -- it looks like a step-up in drop-downs into TLLP, but again, it's allowing you to meet your targets that you discussed last December. Is this really in line with your expectations or is there some acceleration there?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first one was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning, in July. The second one originally was anticipated to b
componenttext: What happened is that we originally intended, as we stated, to have 2 asset sales from Tesoro to Tesoro Logistics in 2016. The first one was the Alaska, which we complete -- started at the beginning, in July. The second one originally was anticipated to be what we refer to as the Great Northern pipeline system in North Dakota, which was the acquisition that Tesoro made in January of this year. But as we got into that business more and we looked at how we wanted to commercialize those assets, we always recognize when we made the acquisition that we wanted to make some changes that would provide the service and the cost effectiveness to the producers, and that's just taking us a little bit longer than we anticipated. We had hoped to be able to complete it for the second half of 2016. That's going to be a little bit slower, so we'll move that forward, and we were prepared already to do the drop we're doing at Martinez in the first half of 2017. So we effectively just flipped the 2 transactions and so fundamentally, there's really no change.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And could you talk about the considerations as to how the Martinez asset drop might be financed, what percentage might be cash?
componenttext: Got you. And could you talk about the considerations as to how the Martinez asset drop might be financed, what percentage might be cash?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- Steven is the expert on that. Let me ask him to comment.
componenttext: Yes, let me -- Steven is the expert on that. Let me ask him to comment.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, if you look prior to 2016, we typically -- and one of the reasons we have an MLP when we do drops is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's also very, very good for
componenttext: Hey, Jeff, when we came into the year, if you look prior to 2016, we typically -- and one of the reasons we have an MLP when we do drops is to bring back substantial cash to Tesoro for value creation. That's good for TLLP but it's also very, very good for Tesoro. Heading into this year, there was tremendous uncertainty, if you recall, in the first quarter around the capital markets and MLP space and our base plan was only to get about 50% cash from those drops. You can see in the first drop that we just announced, Greg highlighted this morning that we got 90% cash. I have no reason to expect at this point that we won't see substantially higher than 50% cash in the next drop as well.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast Tier. I'm just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do you think is putting pr
componenttext: So Greg, I want to talk a little bit about the West Coast Tier. I'm just looking at the Tesoro Index on your website. It looks like in July, it's fallen from $15.50 to $11 a barrel. As you think about the California market, what do you think is putting pressure on it during the summer driving season? Is it a function of imports from Asia? Is it the restart of Torrance, is it a combination of a couple different things? What's the mechanism you see that clears this up?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Neil, the short-term observation that you just made for the month of July is kind of right on because that's what we have on our website, as you stated. So I think it's more important to take a step back and look at the fundamental drivers i
componenttext: Yes, I think, Neil, the short-term observation that you just made for the month of July is kind of right on because that's what we have on our website, as you stated. So I think it's more important to take a step back and look at the fundamental drivers in the West Coast region in the United States, and from everything that we've been both observing and saying over the last couple -- 2 or 3 years, you see a continued strong demand growth, the refineries have been running in the utilization rate that they typically have because the market has been in a position where -- to supply the product, and the -- with the demand and the overall fundamentals, we see the market as being very, very attractive from a fundamental analysis standpoint. However, today, we find ourselves in a period of time where the market's a lot weaker, and you probably hit the nail on the head with the 2 points that you made, you had -- we did experience a little bit higher levels of imports during the transition of ownership in a refinery in California and that change in ownership is kind of working its way through the system. But as we look forward, the fundamentals to us are as attractive as they've ever been. And so we don't see anything that would indicate to us that there's any structural change in the market that would have an impact on the margin environment going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the ARB from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?
componenttext: Do you think the margin as it stands right now, Greg, is enough to close the ARB from Asia and therefore, back out the imports?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean you don't -- you actually don't need the product to get into their -- to the market right now. The market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.
componenttext: Yes, I mean you don't -- you actually don't need the product to get into their -- to the market right now. The market is well supplied and so we don't see the imports coming forward into the market, Neil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the follow-up question here is on retail. Going back to your retail indicators here, July has been outstanding. And so can you talk a little bit about the margin environment and why you're seeing that strength? Is just a reflection of dema
componenttext: Great. And then the follow-up question here is on retail. Going back to your retail indicators here, July has been outstanding. And so can you talk a little bit about the margin environment and why you're seeing that strength? Is just a reflection of demand or something else? And then as we look at your stock, there's an argument that you are not getting a lot of credit for that marketing or retail business. What's the path to unlocking that value?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I mean, you used the right word to describe the market environment. So I don't -- for retail, I mean, it's very good right now. It's been -- it's actually, in the second quarter, was a little bit -- it was a relatively stable market environment no
componenttext: Yes, so I mean, you used the right word to describe the market environment. So I don't -- for retail, I mean, it's very good right now. It's been -- it's actually, in the second quarter, was a little bit -- it was a relatively stable market environment now and as a result, our margins were a little bit on the lower end of what we would have expected in that, but demand was good and the supply to customers worked extremely well and the same dynamics, we believe, are in place that we've had for some time. So we see a very good outlook for the supply to the customers in the third quarter. The -- your second question about the -- how our shares show up in the marketplace, I think, just probably 3 or 4 key comments. One is, as you know and everyone else knows, we are absolutely committed to continue to drive improvements in the business, which we've demonstrated to be very good at being able to deliver those improvements. And as both Steven and I stated, we're on track to accomplish what we laid out for this year and we'll lay out our plans for next year at the end of this year. So I think that's important. In the -- from a refining standpoint, we are absolutely committed to driving a very strong operating excellence management system, which translates into high reliability in our refining operations. The second quarter was not good for us. We experienced some unplanned maintenance that we didn't expect to have and we've dealt with that. It's all been taken care of and we are running extremely well right now. So that was a little bit disappointing, but it's that focus on driving that continued operating excellence in our operations. We want to be able to continue to grow both the Logistics business, and we're encouraged by what we see out there and the things that we're working on as well as the Marketing business. We're in the early stages of our plans that we talked about last year on Marketing. We -- Steven mentioned that the number of our station count is up about 8% year-on-year, which is strong growth primarily in what people refer to as the wholesale or the jobber channel, and we continue to drive fundamental improvements in the Marketing business. So we're going to stay absolutely focused on those commitments that we've made to drive the improvements in the business, and we believe that the market will see the impact of that as we move forward over time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, it's Steven. One thing also, I think, if you look back earlier in the year, the value of Refineries and Logistics assets and the ability to generate cash from those assets versus either being a decline in the rate of growth or the inability to acces
componenttext: Neil, it's Steven. One thing also, I think, if you look back earlier in the year, the value of Refineries and Logistics assets and the ability to generate cash from those assets versus either being a decline in the rate of growth or the inability to access the capital markets, I think that's something that we continue to demonstrate the strength of TLLP on a relative basis. And so I think that, that's one element of what we've been doing as well, to your earlier point, it may not be recognized.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Roger Read.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Roger Read.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Greg, may be a follow-up on some of the comments there on the West Coast gasoline market. When you've talked before or if you look back several years ago, the thought was always that if California refineries or West Coast refineries ran full out,
componenttext: I guess, Greg, may be a follow-up on some of the comments there on the West Coast gasoline market. When you've talked before or if you look back several years ago, the thought was always that if California refineries or West Coast refineries ran full out, the market was a little oversupplied. One goes down, the market gets great. You made the comment that we don't need any extra product right now and it seems to me that most of the West Coast is running fairly well. Have there been any changes in the way you're looking at that? Has demand been a little bit weaker or it's just a function of the imports that came in earlier? I'm just trying to get kind of a feeling of that fundamental shift underway in the West Coast of sort of almost permanent undersupply or exactly what we're looking at?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Roger, probably nothing further to add. When you do just a pure fundamental analysis of the West Coast market, our indications are when refineries run at relatively high utilization rates that the gasoline market needs a small amount of imports to me
componenttext: Yes, Roger, probably nothing further to add. When you do just a pure fundamental analysis of the West Coast market, our indications are when refineries run at relatively high utilization rates that the gasoline market needs a small amount of imports to meet the needs of the marketplace and that analysis hasn't changed. So we see good demand still. We see refineries running at the higher end of the utilization versus historical levels and the inventory levels are at a comfortable level, they are kind of where they are on a 5-year average standpoint. So all of those factors look good. We do not see anything that would give any indication other than what we've already said, really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and kind of following up on that. The retail demand obviously looks good. If you look out to next year and we have another 1-or-so percent net growth in fuel demand, I mean, that would imply that California is going ultimately need a slightly higher
componenttext: Okay, and kind of following up on that. The retail demand obviously looks good. If you look out to next year and we have another 1-or-so percent net growth in fuel demand, I mean, that would imply that California is going ultimately need a slightly higher level of imports or much better utilization across the whole platform, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're exactly right. The only thing I think you need to factor in when you look out is, as you know, is you need to look at what the maintenance plans are for the entire refining system and how that would impact the supply/demand balance. So it coul
componenttext: Yes, you're exactly right. The only thing I think you need to factor in when you look out is, as you know, is you need to look at what the maintenance plans are for the entire refining system and how that would impact the supply/demand balance. So it could require a little bit more product, dependent upon the level of maintenance activity on a relative basis. But it would require more imports.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just the last question, the permit process for the California integration or the Southern California integration, are there any particular hurdles we should be watching for here, a particular date that a vote would occur, anything li
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just the last question, the permit process for the California integration or the Southern California integration, are there any particular hurdles we should be watching for here, a particular date that a vote would occur, anything like that?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's -- no. The actual hearing process culminated probably 5 or 6 weeks ago, all of that's in the hands of the South Coast Air Quality Management District. We believe we're in the window for the permit to be granted here and as I stated, we're on track
componenttext: There's -- no. The actual hearing process culminated probably 5 or 6 weeks ago, all of that's in the hands of the South Coast Air Quality Management District. We believe we're in the window for the permit to be granted here and as I stated, we're on track to start construction as soon as we receive the permits. So we're just going through those final stages of the process really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez of Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez of Howard Weil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I want to tie in with Jeff's comment on the, I guess, the cash balance into the second half of the year and how that ties in with the buybacks. Obviously, you had a decent amount of buybacks in Q2. But I'm just curious, should we be thinking of a mo
componenttext: Greg, I want to tie in with Jeff's comment on the, I guess, the cash balance into the second half of the year and how that ties in with the buybacks. Obviously, you had a decent amount of buybacks in Q2. But I'm just curious, should we be thinking of a more ratable program since you have so much cash coming from the drops. I guess, regardless of what the macro environment looks like, I mean, it seems like that allows you to kind of continue purchasing throughout the cycle. But I just wanted to confirm that that's kind of what you are thinking?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Steven to comment on that, Blake.
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'll ask Steven to comment on that, Blake.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake. Our strategy of really working to have the flexibility to either make strategic investment, acquisition and return cash to shareholders throughout the cycle has really been our consistent approach and focus. And that's still true today. To you
componenttext: Yes, Blake. Our strategy of really working to have the flexibility to either make strategic investment, acquisition and return cash to shareholders throughout the cycle has really been our consistent approach and focus. And that's still true today. To your point, as you -- we did do some share repurchases in the second quarter, I wouldn't think about it as necessarily being just a ratable fixed amount, but our goal is to be able to generate enough cash to allow us to fully execute our growth plan and continue to buy back shares as well as grow the dividend over time commensurate with the quality and the growth of the underlying business portfolio. And so you should expect us to continue to execute that way.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. The second question was on the, I guess, the recent acquisition of the Dakota Prairie asset. For one, I see there is an uptick in the Mid-Con throughput. I am assuming that's a function of that asset being added to the mix. But more broadly speaki
componenttext: Got it. The second question was on the, I guess, the recent acquisition of the Dakota Prairie asset. For one, I see there is an uptick in the Mid-Con throughput. I am assuming that's a function of that asset being added to the mix. But more broadly speaking, I guess, can you just talk about some of the longer term opportunities there. It seems like, given the construction cost of that asset, what you actually paid for it, or I guess just basically assumed debt, it seems like a real opportunity once Bakken differentials kind of move back in our favor?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake. I think there are 3 key points to make about the -- what we now refer to as the Dickinson Refinery is that 1, because of our system approach to operating the business, we will be able to deliver probably more than what we stated earlier from a
componenttext: Yes, Blake. I think there are 3 key points to make about the -- what we now refer to as the Dickinson Refinery is that 1, because of our system approach to operating the business, we will be able to deliver probably more than what we stated earlier from a synergy impact. If you recall our press release, we stated that we expect it to deliver about $20 million of synergies. And once we got actually into the business, which I'll remind you has only been about 30 days, we've actually seen more opportunities in that, which is always encouraging. And so for being able to operate it in our system, it will fit in very, very well to the Tesoro total integrated value chain. The other 2 points are that 1, we will continue to supply ultra-low sulfur diesel to the business market that the Dickinson Refinery operates in. And more encouragingly, the naphtha and resid that comes off the refinery will fit extremely well into other refineries in Tesoro, which we'll be able to upgrade by running it through primarily our cat crackers. So that will provide an added benefit versus what was done with the -- particularly the naphtha in the past. And then the third thing is that we are in the early stages. We see other opportunities with the refineries. So the way that the refinery is constructed provides the potential opportunity to produce renewable diesel and that is something that we're in the early stages of evaluating, and we would expect to have that work done by the latter part of this year, and that's important because when you look at the total system, and particularly in the State of California, and our need for renewable diesel, the value of producing it versus purchasing it is very, very attractive. And so we're reasonably optimistic we'll be able to make that happen going forward here. So that's the value of the Dickinson refinery to Tesoro.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just rounding out that is part of the throughput increase, I'm assuming, in 3Q obviously, right?
componenttext: Great. And just rounding out that is part of the throughput increase, I'm assuming, in 3Q obviously, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In 3Q. Yes, yes. 3Q, you're correct.
componenttext: In 3Q. Yes, yes. 3Q, you're correct.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Sam Margolin of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Sam Margolin of Cowen and Company.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, thanks for the breakout of the inventory impact regionally in the press release. That's helpful. I was just looking at the sort of California results, and you know, net of the inventory, the capture, looks like it was affected by the downtim
componenttext: First of all, thanks for the breakout of the inventory impact regionally in the press release. That's helpful. I was just looking at the sort of California results, and you know, net of the inventory, the capture, looks like it was affected by the downtime you mentioned. I was wondering if there were any other factors in there, specifically if there's been a change to the residents -- to the segment residents of RINs in the consolidated system. If you recognize those in Marketing now and transfer them back to Refining or if it's the same as it has been?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only impact to our results for California for 2Q is a result of some unplanned maintenance that showed up in both lower throughput and the capture rate. That's it.
componenttext: The only impact to our results for California for 2Q is a result of some unplanned maintenance that showed up in both lower throughput and the capture rate. That's it.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just following up on the Great Northern assets, I recall there's -- for that transaction, there's a pretty wide arbitrage between the acquisition valuation and what you could drop it down for. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in th
componenttext: Okay. And then just following up on the Great Northern assets, I recall there's -- for that transaction, there's a pretty wide arbitrage between the acquisition valuation and what you could drop it down for. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in the landscape that's continuing that trend or if it is -- if that spread has been dynamic given the commodity environment?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me correct what you said because that statement at the beginning is not accurate. There is no wide arbitrage. What we have said about the acquisition of the Great Northern assets was that we paid a very attractive value on a relative basis and that ou
componenttext: Let me correct what you said because that statement at the beginning is not accurate. There is no wide arbitrage. What we have said about the acquisition of the Great Northern assets was that we paid a very attractive value on a relative basis and that our intention was to then take those assets and at the appropriate time, after we, I guess, the best way to describe it is if we further commercialized that system into the overall Tesoro North Dakota system, we would sell that to Tesoro Logistics. But it's incorrect to state that there's some wide arbitrage. That's not accurate.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chi Chow of Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chi Chow of Tudor, Pickering.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, so with the downturn in the crude market this year, are you seeing any actions on your transportation costs coming down in your regions? And specifically, is it making rail and your terminal fees on rail actually a better option at this point versus
componenttext: Greg, so with the downturn in the crude market this year, are you seeing any actions on your transportation costs coming down in your regions? And specifically, is it making rail and your terminal fees on rail actually a better option at this point versus kind of what we're seeing from last year?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So we have mentioned this in the past that directionally, we would see changes in the cost, the total cost structure. And for Tesoro, that's moving Bakken crude from North Dakota to the West Coast, as you are aware, that we would see changes,
componenttext: Absolutely. So we have mentioned this in the past that directionally, we would see changes in the cost, the total cost structure. And for Tesoro, that's moving Bakken crude from North Dakota to the West Coast, as you are aware, that we would see changes, and actually pretty significant changes to make the movement of rail more competitive with, for example, pipeline out of Bakken and that is absolutely starting to happen across all parts of that supply chain and kind of along the lines of what we thought it would be. So we are very confident that when that -- all those changes work their way through, which probably isn't too far off from now, the movement of Bakken crude oil by rail to the Pacific Northwest will be very competitive with pipeline shipments out of North Dakota.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify what kind of target you expect on those rail costs going forward here?
componenttext: Can you quantify what kind of target you expect on those rail costs going forward here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you take what we've said historically, around -- specifically around moving Bakken to our Anacortes Refinery, I think, in the past, we've talked about a number between $9 and $10 a barrel. We would expect those numbers to come off as much as 40%.
componenttext: If you take what we've said historically, around -- specifically around moving Bakken to our Anacortes Refinery, I think, in the past, we've talked about a number between $9 and $10 a barrel. We would expect those numbers to come off as much as 40%.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well that's -- that would be a nice, nice move. What sort of level of rail volumes are you moving right now to Anacortes?
componenttext: Okay. Well that's -- that would be a nice, nice move. What sort of level of rail volumes are you moving right now to Anacortes?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's unchanged from what we have. Our facility is a 50,000 barrel a day facility. For the most part, it runs at a very high utilization rate.
componenttext: It's unchanged from what we have. Our facility is a 50,000 barrel a day facility. For the most part, it runs at a very high utilization rate.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I also have a West Coast market question. Not so much on imports coming in, but on the export market. Are there strategies that you're looking to grow that market for you out of California? How important is that market? Seems like La
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I also have a West Coast market question. Not so much on imports coming in, but on the export market. Are there strategies that you're looking to grow that market for you out of California? How important is that market? Seems like Latin America and Mexico, it's been a destination even from the West Coast. There's been some reports of Chinese barrels even showing up in Mexico these days. Just -- any sort of discussion on what you're seeing in that dynamic? Any competition for that export market and what are you going to do to grow that market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, if you look at the regional supply/demand, and you take the west coast of both -- starting all the way from west coast of Canada to -- through the United States into Mexico, you will see that there's a need for imports into that greater region. A
componenttext: I think, if you look at the regional supply/demand, and you take the west coast of both -- starting all the way from west coast of Canada to -- through the United States into Mexico, you will see that there's a need for imports into that greater region. And as kind of a natural flow, it makes sense for particularly, say, the Pacific Northwest to be able to move product into Mexico. We see about 140,000 barrel a day need for product on the west coast of Mexico for gasoline and distillates and kind of a natural place for that is to have the system balance across that whole Western region. And so as a company, we've stated many times in the past that it's a natural part of our system and moving product into Mexico, Chile and Peru primarily. We don't see any structural changes in that. We still see, especially Mexico to have the strong need and healthy and reasonably good demand growth. And that presents opportunities to go about that business different ways that we're just in the early stages of looking at to see what makes sense for Tesoro kind of over time and we don't have an answer on that yet.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you moving barrels from Anacortes into Mexico right now?
componenttext: Are you moving barrels from Anacortes into Mexico right now?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we move barrels from -- into south, it comes from the Anacortes area.
componenttext: When we move barrels from -- into south, it comes from the Anacortes area.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Interesting. And one maybe final quick question for Steven. For 3Q, do you have any sort of estimate on the working capital impact with commodity prices coming down in the quarter?
componenttext: Interesting. And one maybe final quick question for Steven. For 3Q, do you have any sort of estimate on the working capital impact with commodity prices coming down in the quarter?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- as we look at working capital internally, we continue to try to find ways to reduce our overall levels of working capital, and we see opportunities to continue to do that. As you said, sometimes when commodity prices drop, you see short term pr
componenttext: Yes, we -- as we look at working capital internally, we continue to try to find ways to reduce our overall levels of working capital, and we see opportunities to continue to do that. As you said, sometimes when commodity prices drop, you see short term price impacts on it, but overall, our intent is to continue to make working capital a source of cash over time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You expect that in 3Q to be a source of cash?
componenttext: You expect that in 3Q to be a source of cash?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most likely. I would -- We don't get too specific by quarter but directionally, in the second half, we do expect working capital to be a source of cash.
componenttext: Most likely. I would -- We don't get too specific by quarter but directionally, in the second half, we do expect working capital to be a source of cash.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Igor Grinman, chiming in for Ryan. You've spoken a decent amount on the marketing side today. But just curious if you can maybe add on what you're seeing on the M&A side currently out there. I know we're kind of early here in the innings
componenttext: This is actually Igor Grinman, chiming in for Ryan. You've spoken a decent amount on the marketing side today. But just curious if you can maybe add on what you're seeing on the M&A side currently out there. I know we're kind of early here in the innings post the December Analyst Day and the acquisition that you guys referenced to kind of longer term in your forecast there. But just curious where that stands today, if timing-wise if we should think about that as a longer term -- more of a longer term event than anything near term, any color there?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, first, just to restate what was mentioned earlier, we are seeing good growth in our wholesale jobber business. And as we mentioned, and maybe both Steven and I, that's up about 8% year-on-year, which is -- that's very favorable because that'
componenttext: Yes, I think, first, just to restate what was mentioned earlier, we are seeing good growth in our wholesale jobber business. And as we mentioned, and maybe both Steven and I, that's up about 8% year-on-year, which is -- that's very favorable because that's one of our target areas of growth. That's a first point. The second point is other activity in our areas has actually been relatively quiet. There was one transaction that occurred earlier this year that we looked very hard at, but for us to be -- to create value from it, the price it was paid was above what we would be willing to pay. It just didn't offer us the opportunity there. Other than that, it's been relatively quiet. So we're very focused on looking at other -- the opportunities to continue to grow our business and to also to improve our existing business there, and you stated it very clearly, our -- what we laid out in the end of 2015 was our approach over time that we would look at those opportunities and target between '16, '17 and '18 to deliver that growth in Marketing.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And maybe just one more, just to switch gears a little bit to the refining side. I guess a lot of the focus today has been more on the West Coast or maybe some of the capture weakness given the unplanned downtime that you saw in 2Q. But
componenttext: I appreciate that. And maybe just one more, just to switch gears a little bit to the refining side. I guess a lot of the focus today has been more on the West Coast or maybe some of the capture weakness given the unplanned downtime that you saw in 2Q. But the Mid-Con was pretty positive this quarter, it saw pretty dramatic sequential uptick. Just curious as to how sustainable that result out there is and maybe just some kind of drivers you can point to in the quarter. I only ask because a lot of the peers have actually seen pretty sizable drops quarter-on-quarter. So it's just kind of contrary to what has happened out there.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, you know, we did run well this quarter within the region. Also our Great Northern acquisition -- Logistics acquisition, because we haven't dropped to down yet, is also within that region. So some of the favorability you see is from that.
componenttext: Yes, I think, you know, we did run well this quarter within the region. Also our Great Northern acquisition -- Logistics acquisition, because we haven't dropped to down yet, is also within that region. So some of the favorability you see is from that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will continue because that asset is performing extremely well versus our original expectations.
componenttext: And that will continue because that asset is performing extremely well versus our original expectations.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Phil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Phil.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on your droppable EBITDA. Just kind of curious where do you stand today in total droppable EBITDA after you complete what's planned for 2016, and does it all sit in Refining at this point? I know you've had some EBITDA move from Refining
componenttext: First question is on your droppable EBITDA. Just kind of curious where do you stand today in total droppable EBITDA after you complete what's planned for 2016, and does it all sit in Refining at this point? I know you've had some EBITDA move from Refining to retail, but I don't believe wholesale was part of that EBITDA. So maybe just an update on that front.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Phil, if you just reflect back on what we said in December of last year, I think we broke it down into 2 pieces. The first piece we said was that with the existing assets in the company, we had somewhere -- I'm just going off my memory here, but somet
componenttext: So, Phil, if you just reflect back on what we said in December of last year, I think we broke it down into 2 pieces. The first piece we said was that with the existing assets in the company, we had somewhere -- I'm just going off my memory here, but something between $350 million to $500 million of EBITDA attributable to those assets. And then we said we had another $150 million to $250 million or so with things that we're working on that would ultimately be dropped down in there, and that hasn't changed. That is unchanged from what we said then. So what have we done? Well 1, what we talked about earlier was we sold part of what was in that -- part of the EBITDA and that kind of, let's call it the legacy Tesoro assets, which were the Alaska assets around the Kenai refinery. But in addition, from the other bucket, the opportunities we are dropping down the acquisition that we did from Flint Hills Resources, so that gives you that EBITDA number that came with that. And then the only other change is instead of taking the EBITDA that would have come from opportunities, which is the Great Northern and drop it down in the second half of this year, as I mentioned, we'll move that out of '16 and bring forward what we planned to do with Martinez that I think in the press release gave an EBITDA number of -- I don't remember what the number is. What is it? Up to around -- up to about $50 million. So that, you can just see how that affects the 2 buckets of opportunities that we talked about. So not a big change.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And my second question is just on the CapEx, the reduction in the CapEx. Is there any reduction in your sustaining capital requirements relative to what you thought before? Or is this all on growth CapEx. The reason I ask is kind of going ba
componenttext: Okay, got it. And my second question is just on the CapEx, the reduction in the CapEx. Is there any reduction in your sustaining capital requirements relative to what you thought before? Or is this all on growth CapEx. The reason I ask is kind of going back to the Analyst Day, there's a really big step-up in sustaining capital for 2016 relative to what we've seen historically.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- in our sustaining capital, we had a portion of our compliance with the Consent Decree, which we've talked about probably now for 2 or 3 years, but then we've been working on that, so we are in the final stages of wrapping up our expenditures
componenttext: Yes, so we -- in our sustaining capital, we had a portion of our compliance with the Consent Decree, which we've talked about probably now for 2 or 3 years, but then we've been working on that, so we are in the final stages of wrapping up our expenditures on the Consent Decree and there's -- there haven't been any material changes in our sustaining capital spend other than that. So it's -- most of it, as we stated earlier, was attributable to the timing of the permitting for the projects versus what we thought we would do in 2015, move those -- move that spend out into '17, '18.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. If I could sneak one last question in. Could you potentially quantify the lost opportunity cost from the second quarter for Refining? And if you have it, by region.
componenttext: Okay, got it. If I could sneak one last question in. Could you potentially quantify the lost opportunity cost from the second quarter for Refining? And if you have it, by region.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Phil, to get back into that level of detail is something that I'd prefer not to do. But you can -- if you take our guidance on crude runs, in the midpoint of our guidance on what we said we were going to do in the second quarter and what we actua
componenttext: You know Phil, to get back into that level of detail is something that I'd prefer not to do. But you can -- if you take our guidance on crude runs, in the midpoint of our guidance on what we said we were going to do in the second quarter and what we actually did, gives you an indication of how far off we are. And that I will tell you is absolutely attributable to doing some additional work at the Kenai refinery. Once we had the refinery down, we took the whole plant down and did an extensive turnaround at Kenai and that took longer. And secondly, the operating problems and maintenance that we did in the California system are solely attributable to the impact on our crude runs. And secondly, if you go back, if you look at our capture which we disclosed versus -- we have said we thought we'd in the very low 80% for 2Q, that tells you, that answers your question.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I get -- to ask it another way, are you comfortable with that low 80s capture in the third quarter?
componenttext: So I get -- to ask it another way, are you comfortable with that low 80s capture in the third quarter?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- I'd just like to add one point. I think what's important is we were able to go back in during the second quarter and the operating problems we identified, we have actually dealt with those and they are behind us, and we are now running ver
componenttext: Yes. I think -- I'd just like to add one point. I think what's important is we were able to go back in during the second quarter and the operating problems we identified, we have actually dealt with those and they are behind us, and we are now running very, very well and expect to throughout the rest of the year. And have a little bit of maintenance in the fourth quarter, but relatively low maintenance going forward between now and the end of the year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng of Barclays.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just curious that -- I mean there's a number of very large pipelines going to source oil from Bakken. It's going to come on stream in the coming months into 2019, 2020. So from that standpoint, are you concerned you may not actually have sufficient
componenttext: Greg, just curious that -- I mean there's a number of very large pipelines going to source oil from Bakken. It's going to come on stream in the coming months into 2019, 2020. So from that standpoint, are you concerned you may not actually have sufficient oil from Bakken to fit in even if you get the approval from the Vancouver project?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We believe, Paul that the cost structure that we have will allow us to compete very effectively with the pipelines. The challenge will be that people who commit to those pipelines have an obligation to either pay or ship on the pipeline. So our system --
componenttext: We believe, Paul that the cost structure that we have will allow us to compete very effectively with the pipelines. The challenge will be that people who commit to those pipelines have an obligation to either pay or ship on the pipeline. So our system -- because fortunately, we have both a gathering, a storage and a pipeline system, allows us to go out and with our relationships with the producers, buy at the least [ph] and move it into our system. So the competition may be greater, but we don't -- we're not concerned that we'll be short supply, to answer your question.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Steven, next 2 questions are for you. Do you have any hedging gain or loss in the second quarter that is not fully offset by the corresponding value change in the physical barrels?
componenttext: Okay. Steven, next 2 questions are for you. Do you have any hedging gain or loss in the second quarter that is not fully offset by the corresponding value change in the physical barrels?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, nothing material, Paul.
componenttext: No, nothing material, Paul.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing material? And we shouldn't assume that heading into the third quarter, there's any material hedging gain or loss starting with third quarter, right?
componenttext: Nothing material? And we shouldn't assume that heading into the third quarter, there's any material hedging gain or loss starting with third quarter, right?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Q2 didn't have any effect at the end of the quarter that would roll into Q3. So no issue with that.
componenttext: No, Q2 didn't have any effect at the end of the quarter that would roll into Q3. So no issue with that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And going back to your earlier comment that if you are comparing year-to-date your result comparing to 2014, you did not drop as much as your competitor and that is the proof for the synergy benefit. I probably get it wrong, but if I look at it some
componenttext: Okay. And going back to your earlier comment that if you are comparing year-to-date your result comparing to 2014, you did not drop as much as your competitor and that is the proof for the synergy benefit. I probably get it wrong, but if I look at it somewhat differently, region by region, if I look at your Pacific Northwest and your California system as one, as the entire West Coast, for the last fourth quarter, rolling fourth quarter, your EBITDA per barrel is about $7.80, which is about $3 higher than your 2014 average, which is great. The only problem is that Phillips 66 and Valero look like they're up about $3.90 and $6.40 per barrel. So they actually improved far more. Now if I'm looking at your inland system, your Mid-Con, in the same period you dropped by $9, because the defense [ph] have dropped a lot, but if I'm looking at the inland system from Phillips 66, Valero, HollyFrontier, and Western together, they dropped a little bit more than $3. So maybe I'm just looking at it totally wrong. But that doesn't seem to suggest you guys have improved compared to your peers.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think a couple of comments. First, it's the overall earnings of the company, Paul, not just pointing to Refining segment, which, very importantly for us, because we run a very integrated -- highly integrated business into marketing. And what we'
componenttext: Yes, so I think a couple of comments. First, it's the overall earnings of the company, Paul, not just pointing to Refining segment, which, very importantly for us, because we run a very integrated -- highly integrated business into marketing. And what we've been able to do on a relative basis with our marketing business back to where we were in 2014 as well as the substantial growth we've had in our Logistics business, so across the company, that's where the comment was geared.

componenttext: Versus others?

componenttext: Yes, we can do that over time.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really a question on TLLP. I mean, you've done a fantastic job of getting EBITDA up $950 million I think is the consensus now for next year. You're on a 7% yield, which is wider than the growth MLPs, because I guess people are just saying how can you go t
componenttext: Really a question on TLLP. I mean, you've done a fantastic job of getting EBITDA up $950 million I think is the consensus now for next year. You're on a 7% yield, which is wider than the growth MLPs, because I guess people are just saying how can you go to the next level. Obviously the drops help and the organic investment. But maybe talk a little bit about your more strategic thoughts about top of funnel feeding of the MLP beast, and then a follow-up.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on TLLP, 2 key points. One is the organic growth opportunities. We're very focused on driving organic growth in the business. We've mentioned that it's been a little bit slower than we expected. We have -- we actually have a reasonably good portfo
componenttext: Yes, so on TLLP, 2 key points. One is the organic growth opportunities. We're very focused on driving organic growth in the business. We've mentioned that it's been a little bit slower than we expected. We have -- we actually have a reasonably good portfolio of ideas that we're looking at right now, and we're encouraged by those. So we'll talk more about those as they develop on that, but that organic growth has a key part of Tesoro Logistics growth. It's actually our preferred way to grow the company. The second is around acquisitions. And the market for acquisitions is -- probably hasn't changed a lot of what we've seen over time. So the -- there's a number of things that we're looking at that we're encouraged by. So both the combination of the organic growth and the acquisitions look very encouraging to us.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's probably a good follow on for my second question, which is around building cash in the second half and the drops and running well, and we'll see what margins do. But there's, obviously, how much do you buy back, how much do you build cash to ba
componenttext: And that's probably a good follow on for my second question, which is around building cash in the second half and the drops and running well, and we'll see what margins do. But there's, obviously, how much do you buy back, how much do you build cash to basically build up to being able to do something on the M&A side in whichever segment it makes most sense?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was that a question or a statement?
componenttext: Was that a question or a statement?

componenttext: Sorry, the question was buybacks versus [indiscernible].
