headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, Vice
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our third quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. The earnings release which can be found on our website at tso
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our third quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. The earnings release which can be found on our website at tsocorp.com includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP financial measures that should help you analyze our results. Our comments and answers to questions during this call will include forward-looking statements that refer to management's expectations or future predictions. They are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations. Please refer to the earnings release for additional information on forward-looking statements.
Now I will turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our third quarter 2016 financial performance, and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported third quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $170 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our third quarter 2016 financial performance, and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported third quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $170 million attributable to Tesoro or $1.43 per diluted share compared to $759 million or $6.13 per diluted share a year ago.
Consolidated net earnings were $201 million for the third quarter compared to $799 million for the same period last year, and EBITDA was $577 million compared to $1.5 billion a year ago.
Operating income in the third quarter grew year-over-year in Logistics, but was lower in refining and marketing due to a stronger than normal market environment in 2015.
Turning to our business segments. 
Refining operating income was $52 million for the third quarter compared to $899 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $204 million versus $1 billion last year. Operating income and segment EBITDA for the quarter include a pretax inventory benefit due to a lower cost or market valuation adjustment of $20 million, offset by a $14 million charge related to a contract dispute with the supplier.
The Tesoro Index was $12.45 a barrel for the third quarter, with a gross refining margin of $9.08 per barrel or 73% capture of the Tesoro Index. This compares to the Tesoro Index of $23.09 and a gross refining margin of $19.43 or 84% capture for last year. 
Refining margins in the third quarter were negatively impacted by the following 3 items: first, an overall lower refining margin environment; second, rise in RINs prices. Let me remind you that our refining sales to our marketing business are based on spot prices less the full RIN costs. So in a quarter where RINs costs rise, we reflect the higher obligation in refining and the benefit from blending in our marketing segment. It is important to note that we run our business in the integrated manner. This does not have a material impact on total company results. 
And lastly, we continue to look for ways to drive improvements in our business and capital allocation. One of the ways we do this is by driving improvements in working capital. In the third quarter, we successfully reduced inventory and generated approximately $150 million in cash as a result. This inventory reduction had a positive impact on cash flow, but a negative impact on refining margins in the quarter.
Total refining throughput for the quarter was 873,000 barrels a day or 98% utilization, which was at the high end of our expectations.
Manufacturing costs in the third quarter increased $0.27 per barrel over the same period last year to $5.11. This year-over-year increase was largely due to the addition of the Dickinson refinery and the Tesoro Great Plains assets acquired in 2016.
Moving to Logistics. 
Operating income increased to $133 million in the third quarter from $106 million a year ago and segment EBITDA grew to $181 million from $153 million last year. This performance was driven by the following factors: year-over-year growth in TLP's crude oil gathering, terminalling and transportation throughput; growth from the acquisition of the Los Angeles Storage and Pipeline Assets last year; and growth from the Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets acquisition made during the quarter.
The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $65 million during the third quarter. This is an increase of $27 million or 71% versus 2015.
Turning to marketing. 
Operating income was $273 million compared to $379 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $285 million compared to $390 million last year. The fuel margins were $0.149 a gallon in the third quarter versus $0.205 a gallon last year. 
During the quarter, we saw a continued strong fundamentals and favorable business conditions, including growth in consumer demand and an increase in vehicle miles traveled. We are pleased with our operating results in the quarter as we continue to execute our strategy of optimizing the placement of our refined products through the most valuable channels for market consumption.
Now I'd like to take a moment to discuss our balance sheet, cash flow and our strategic priorities for creating long-term shareholder value.
Our balance sheet remains strong. We ended the quarter with the consolidated cash balance of $1.4 billion compared to $942 million at the end of 2015. Total debt to capitalization was 36% at the end of the quarter. Excluding TLP debt and equity, our debt to capitalization ratio was 19%.
We have made significant progress in strengthening our balance sheet, investing for growth and returning cash to shareholders. And we continue to progress towards our goal of obtaining investment grade credit ratings for Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics.
As you may be aware, at the end of the quarter, Tesoro entered into a new $2 billion senior secured revolving credit agreement. This new 4-year cash flow credit facility replaces our $3 billion asset base credit facility. The new credit facility will become unsecured upon Tesoro achieving an investment grade rating from either Moody's or S&P. Additionally, on October 14, S&P upgraded TLP's credit rating by 1 level to BB+, with a stable outlook. This new rating is now the same as that as Tesoro in just 1 notch below investment grade.
Turning to cash flows. 
Tesoro generated cash flow from operating activities of $1.2 billion for the first 9 months of 2016, including $573 million in the third quarter. 
I'd like to discuss how we continued to deploy cash to create long-term shareholder value.
First, we invest in high return capital projects and improve returns on invested capital. For the first 9 months of the year, we invested $296 million in income and growth capital projects at Tesoro and TLLP. Our combined capital expenditures were approximately $624 million. And we now expect full year 2016 capital spending of approximately $900 million. This is a reduction from our previous expectations of approximately $1 billion.
Next, we ensure that we maintain a strong balance sheet to give us the flexibility to make strategic investments and also return cash to shareholders. For the first 9 months of the year, we spent approximately $412 million on accretive acquisitions. We executed $3.2 million in share repurchases for approximately $250 million, including 1.9 million shares for approximately $150 million during the quarter. We also paid dividends of $186 million and distributed $155 million to third-party LP unitholders.
Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our fourth quarter outlook in our earnings release that was issued yesterday.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steven, and good morning. We are pleased with our results for the quarter, which can be attributed to our integrated business model and the continued execution of our operating improvements. Our operational reliability was very strong. Comb
componenttext:
Thank you, Steven, and good morning. 
We are pleased with our results for the quarter, which can be attributed to our integrated business model and the continued execution of our operating improvements. 
Our operational reliability was very strong. Combined with our continued growth in Logistics and our integrated marketing business, we generated strong operating cash flows. Also, this quarter, we returned $215 million to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
Turning to our operations. 
Let me start with refining. As Steven mentioned previously, total refinery throughput for the quarter was 873,000 barrels per day or 98% utilization and gross refining margin was $9.08 per barrel. 
In our California region, we continued to see product demand growth. We operate in our refineries well with a utilization of 98%, which was at the high end of our guidance. 
In our Pacific Northwest region, throughput was higher than our expectations, but our operating performance was impacted by a lower refining margin environment, wins pricing and products mix due to an impact of a reduction of inventory. 
In the Mid-Continent, throughput was within our expectation. However, operating results were impacted by a lower refining margin environment and a charge related to a contract settlement with a supplier. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect overall refinery utilization to be between 90% and 96%.
Moving to Logistics. 
We continued to execute on our strategy of growing this business through organic investment, strategic acquisitions and acquisitions by Tesoro. TLLP delivered strong operating income growth in the quarter. TLLP's quarter results were driven by the terminalling and transportation segment, which generated record revenues, operating income and EBITDA. During the quarter, TLLP completed the acquisition of the Alaska storage and terminalling assets from Tesoro, and this contributed to the segment's operating performance.
Crude oil gathering volumes increased to 206,000 barrels per day versus 199,000 barrels per day last year despite a challenging commodity price environment. While this headwind still exists in our gathering and processing operations, we continue to invest in attractive organic projects, such as interconnections on the High Plains System and compression projects in our natural gas gathering system.
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP the opportunity to acquire the northern California terminalling and storage assets in the fourth quarter of 2016. The assets could add $28 million to $33 million of annual net earnings and $45 million to $50 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. Looking forward, TLLP remains committed to achieving its goal of $820 million of annual operating income and $1 billion of EBITDA by 2017.
Now shifting to marketing. 
Our performance in the quarter was strong. During the quarter, we saw a continued favorable trends in the market, including strong consumer demand with U.S. gasoline demand up 3% year-over-year through September, and an increase in vehicle miles traveled of 3.2% year-over-year in the U.S. and 4.8% year-over-year in California through August. Also, we increased our branded store count by 178 stations year-over-year to 2,467. We continue to successfully execute our strategy of optimizing the placement of our refined products through the most valuable channels for market consumption.
We see continued favorable market fundamentals driven by a strong economy and growth in consumer demand in the regions in which we operate. We remain excited about the organic growth prospects in our marketing business. These include implementing improvements in our stations, expanding our network of stations and investing in our brands.
Now let me discuss the acquisitions we made during the quarter and also provide you an update on major capital projects. 
On the acquisition front. In September, we acquired Virent Incorporated, an innovative renewable fuels and chemicals company. This acquisition supports our renewable fuel strategy of developing high-quality, low-carbon renewable feedstocks and blend stocks that can be either co-processed in our existing refineries or blended seamlessly with traditional fuels. Also, by generating valuable renewable fuels credits, we could lower our compliance costs with both the federal renewable fuel standard and California's low carbon fuel standard.
During the quarter, we closed both portions of the sale of the Alaska storage and terminalling assets to TLLP for a total consideration to Tesoro of $444 million, paid as $400 million in cash and approximately $44 million of TLLP common and general partner units.
To give you an update on our Vancouver Energy project. The energy facility Site Evaluation Council concluded adjudicated hearings in September with the filing of all parties post hearing briefs. On October 6, Vancouver Energy submitted its revised permit application to EFSEC in keeping with the council's hearing rules and regulations.
In the revised permit application, Vancouver Energy offered many conditions that are well above regulatory requirements. This includes a performance-based throughput structure by which EFSEC could limit the project's initial throughput to 180,000 barrels per day or 50% of the originally proposed 360,000 barrels per day. This structure includes the ability to incrementally increase the facility throughput by 90,000 barrels per day after 12 consecutive months of acceptable safety and environmental performance. Two consecutive performance periods would result in their originally proposed 360,000 barrels per day facility. EFSEC is now deliberating its recommendation to the Governor of Washington.
We are committed to the proposed crude oil rail to marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the state of Washington in the entire West Coast.
Regarding the Los Angeles refinery integration and compliance project. The South Coast Air Quality Management district is making progress on preparing the final environmental impact report. A certified environmental impact report will allow the main permitting entities to approve the project. We expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of this year and begin construction shortly thereafter.
To update you on our progress to deliver improvements in our business. You will recall that at our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out our expectations for 2016, which were based on 3 things: 1, the Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel; 2, marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon; and 3, crude oil differentials that reflected the cost of transportation.
Through the first 9 months of 2016, the Tesoro Index and marketing fuel margins are in line with our expectations. Crude oil differentials continued to be significantly narrower than our expectations. This has resulted in lower capture rates and lower refining profitability than our original expectations for this year.
Tesoro continues to expect year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiencies of $400 million to $500 million. We also committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income in 2016, consisting of $200 million to $250 million in refining, $175 million to $200 million in logistics and $25 million to $50 million in marketing. Even in the current challenging market environment, we are confident that we will deliver the $400 million to $500 million of total annual improvements to operating income.
Through the first 3 quarters of the year, our estimated refining and marketing improvements are trending above the range. However, estimated logistics improvements are trending slightly below the range, primarily due to the weak commodity price environment, which has impacted organic growth and volumes.
Before I conclude, I would like to remind you that we will be hosting our 2016 in Investor and Analyst Day on December 6 in New York City. My leadership team and I look forward to updating you on the company strategic outlook and outlining our plans for 2017. For additional details on this event, please follow-up with our Investor Relations team.
To conclude, we have built a strong integrated refining, logistics and marketing business and have a competitive position in our markets. This enables us to drive significant operational improvements, create sustainable earnings growth and deliver long-term shareholder value.
Thank you. And with that, we'll take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question comes from Spiro Dounis from UBS Securities.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to start off around I guess the RDR structure at TLLP, just given recent events by your peers. And I guess you just want to ask in 2 ways. So first, how should we be thinking about maybe lowering the cash -- capital there and then will come
componenttext: I just wanted to start off around I guess the RDR structure at TLLP, just given recent events by your peers. And I guess you just want to ask in 2 ways. So first, how should we be thinking about maybe lowering the cash -- capital there and then will come sit in TSO for its GP interest? And then 2, you're trying to obtain investment grade rating at TLLP and TSO. TLLP just got upgraded to a notch below. How, I guess, if at all, would any sort of IDR buy-in or relief give you'd buy the credit agencies? Is that a factor at what you end up deciding to do?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are good questions. Let me ask Steven to comment on both of those.
componenttext: These are good questions. Let me ask Steven to comment on both of those.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've talked before, we're in logistics business because we see substantial opportunities to continue to grow the business, both organically and through acquisition. And as you mentioned, we're in MLP because we need access to low-cost capital to
componenttext: Yes. As we've talked before, we're in logistics business because we see substantial opportunities to continue to grow the business, both organically and through acquisition. And as you mentioned, we're in MLP because we need access to low-cost capital to do that. Over time, as we've grown the business substantially, the IDR structure does have an impact on the cost of capital of the MLP. We see that, we acknowledge it and understand it. As we look forward, it's critical because we do see continued opportunity for high return investment within the logistics business, for the MLP to have very attractive cost of capital, for our unit holders to have significant accretion opportunities as we grow the business, and for Tesoro to continue to receive cash, and MLP to be a source of cash for Tesoro to reduce our cost to capital over time. And so we absolutely view that as part of our ongoing and long-term strategy. And we'll as always continue to look at all the options that are out there to allow us to continue to both grow the business and have a low cost to capital. And on your second question about investment grade, if you look at Tesoro and TLLP's balance sheet, if you look at what we've done with cash flow and capital allocation and leverage, we think the companies are very high quality and meet most, if not all, investment-grade ratings, and think that managing cost of capital and options that are there only support that and it wouldn't take away from that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Appreciate that color. Just second question around the retail growth. I think expectations maybe were there, you would have acquired something I guess at this point of year, and I think you looked at something earlier, but maybe the valuations wer
componenttext: Got it. Appreciate that color. Just second question around the retail growth. I think expectations maybe were there, you would have acquired something I guess at this point of year, and I think you looked at something earlier, but maybe the valuations were just hard to justify. I'm curious if that's still the case and if valuations are getting any more attractive.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Spiro, on our marketing strategy, the way you laid out pretty clearly at the end of last year was to substantially improve the integration between our refining and marketing, both the quality and the overall performance of our marketing business, and w
componenttext: So Spiro, on our marketing strategy, the way you laid out pretty clearly at the end of last year was to substantially improve the integration between our refining and marketing, both the quality and the overall performance of our marketing business, and we've made very, very good progress this year. As I stated in some of the comments that I just made, we were -- we have been able to grow our wholesale marketing business through our brand stations by almost 200 stations year-on-year, which is probably a little bit ahead of what we expected to be able to do going into the year. And we've been able to drive other improvements in the business. And you're exactly right, we have looked at opportunities to acquire assets that would fit into our integrated business model. There hasn't been a lot available in the marketplace this year. And so we will continue just to evaluate opportunities as they become available. But  probably more importantly, we're seeing really good growth in our underlying business, that's probably a little bit ahead of our expectations from what we thought we were able to do last year.

componenttext: Yes, it's an excellent question, Neil. As we progress through the year, we've continued to manage all of our capital projects, first, by trying to find improvements in the execution at the projects would allow us to have lower total capital spend on the projects that we're executing. And we've had good success on that through our supply, sourcing and other programs like that, so with that, we're very excited about. And as the actual change from our revised guidance of $1 billion down by about 10%, primarily is some movements in our Logistics business, just more of a lesser timing impact moving things into next year and then just other small improvements across the whole system. Last year in December, that we gave guidance for 2017 that would have had Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics for a combined spending of about $1.7 billion. We are in the final stages of completing our planning for '17, and '18 and '19 as we go out and look at our plans to execute on the various projects that we're undertaking. And it looks preliminary that we'll probably be down somewhere between say 27% to 33%, somewhere in that range versus what we said last year, so down by about another $400 million to $500 million of capital spending. But we'll -- as you clearly stated, we'll be specific about that when we get together in December.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, as we've spoken in the past, our fundamental analysis of the West Coast market is very constructive. We see good fundamentals from the demand outlook. As we just stated, in the marketplace, the refineries operating at a relatively high utilization r
componenttext: Neil, as we've spoken in the past, our fundamental analysis of the West Coast market is very constructive. We see good fundamentals from the demand outlook. As we just stated, in the marketplace, the refineries operating at a relatively high utilization rates. Still, export activity going into Mexico and a little bit into Chile and Peru. So overall, our view of the West Coast is a very constructive view, up from a fundamental market analysis standpoint, and so that's kind of how we see that continuing into 2017.

componenttext: One of the key criteria that the rating agencies have talked about was the need to eliminate secured debt, which we did effectively with the new revolver finance. componenttext: Well, I think from the Tesoro perspective, we feel very good about where we are positioned. componenttext: Well, just to maybe reiterate what I said earlier, Doug, is that we are having very good success in driving some fundamental improvements in our overall marketing business. So in addition to the growth in our wholesale marketing business with the almost 200 branded stations, they've been able to drive continued improvements in our overall portfolio, and so we feel really good about the improvements. They are ahead of what we expected to be able to do in the business for this year, because you're exactly right. When we laid out our plan last year, which we clearly gave a run rate EBITDA of about $650 million, and you pointed out very accurately that we're running in excess of that this year, so the margins are slightly better as a result of the improvements that we've been driving in the business, and as so we'll talk more about it in a month or so when we get together, but the outlook to us is very, very encouraging without any growth.

componenttextpreview: They have not. So let me just be clear about our thinking. When we laid out our plans, we basically stated that our business is highly integrated, and you've heard us say that, probably ad nauseam, but our business is highly integrated. And as a result, w
componenttext: They have not. So let me just be clear about our thinking. When we laid out our plans, we basically stated that our business is highly integrated, and you've heard us say that, probably ad nauseam, but our business is highly integrated. And as a result, what we want to be able to do is 3 things: 1, continue to strengthen that integration around each of our refineries so that we drive that integration to a very high level; 2, improve the quality of our marketing business around each of our refineries, so that as we actively manage the portfolio of marketing assets, we are able to high grade that portfolio, which part of our thinking there was around potential acquisitions over time, and we said we would do that over about a 3-year period of time that if we identified opportunities, we would make those -- try to capture those opportunities in an effort to high grade our marketing portfolio; and the third thing was, we said that we needed to strengthen our convenience store offering. We felt that, that was a critical variable in our overall offering to our customers, and that's a third thing that we're working on.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when we acquired it, we made some brief comments on the facility. And relative to the things that we've identified at the front-end before we closed the transaction, our people have been incredibly successful capturing those benefits. And so
componenttext: Yes. I think when we acquired it, we made some brief comments on the facility. And relative to the things that we've identified at the front-end before we closed the transaction, our people have been incredibly successful capturing those benefits. And so relative to our outlook, we're basically on target with what we thought we would do. We've done some interesting things with it. For example, in the quarter, we just completed a turnaround in Salt Lake City on the crude unit just within the last few days. And one of the things we're able to do is is we're able to take the resid from the Dickinson refinery and run it through the cat cracker in Salt Lake and make gasoline to supply the market during the downtime in the refinery which worked extremely well. And we've similarly done that by taking some of the resid to Anacortes to run through the cat cracker in Anacortes, and so the benefits -- the additional benefits in that we're seeing are working out really, really well for us. And so what we do not see anything materially different than when we first talked about it. Now it wasn't -- it doesn't have a significant impact on the company overall, but those -- even though small little things that I talked about are very attractive to what we're trying to do. So no surprises and good execution with what we set out to do.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping for a little color on Virent since the release came out between quarters and this is the first time we've had a chance to talk about it. And just a little background information, if they were a vendor of yours, if this changes anything from a
componenttext: I was hoping for a little color on Virent since the release came out between quarters and this is the first time we've had a chance to talk about it. And just a little background information, if they were a vendor of yours, if this changes anything from an operational standpoint volumetrically. And then on the compliance side, the California Carbon standard isn't something people talk about very much, but it seems like it's material here. And so anything to flesh that out a little bit would be really helpful.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Virent is a company that's existed for probably around 15 years. It's based up in Madison, Wisconsin. And they have been doing development on producing both -- different types of renewable fuels and renewable kind of petrochemicals, almost like a
componenttext: Yes. So Virent is a company that's existed for probably around 15 years. It's based up in Madison, Wisconsin. And they have been doing development on producing both -- different types of renewable fuels and renewable kind of petrochemicals, almost like a renewable mixed xylene that could be used to make polyester. So that company has had actually very good success over time. And when Tesoro got involved in the business, within the last couple of years, we acquired an option with the potential to ultimately acquire the business, which we did during the quarter. And like I said in the brief statements that I made about Virent, we -- the ability to make the product that they're targeting is very, very well developed. There Is not a lot of uncertainty about that, so that part we feel really good about. We are working to progress that on a scale up basis, and that's very advanced to being able to scale up the production of that. And our primary interest is to be able to supply with our fuel, the renewable component of it and particularly to be able to meet some of the requirements in the state of California, and so we will continue to work on the scale up of the business. And then within probably a couple of years, make a decision on how you go about executing the business as far as the construction of a facility to make the renewable a material.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my second question is probably for Steve. Now thanks for the disclosure about the RINs impact between segments. I am just curious if -- I know it doesn't necessarily affect the business on an enterprise level, but to the extent that things like
componenttext: Okay. And my second question is probably for Steve. Now thanks for the disclosure about the RINs impact between segments. I am just curious if -- I know it doesn't necessarily affect the business on an enterprise level, but to the extent that things like capture aid and other operating metrics are talked about in the investment community, if you have any options as far as how you account for those, if there is a way to reduce the volatility and the refining side, and just kind of smooth it out, especially in the context of people asking about the marketing segment valuation, and a part of that valuation premium is the fact that it's the more stable business, and having the moving piece in it kind of makes it confusing too. So just curious about if you have observed any options that you have with respect to that accounting.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first of all, when you look at the way we transfer price, we take spot price to marketing minus the cost of RINs. And so our view is that the full obligation of the RIN is born within the refining business. When you think about gasoline, the va
componenttext:
Yes. Well, first of all, when you look at the way we transfer price, we take spot price to marketing minus the cost of RINs. And so our view is that the full obligation of the RIN is born within the refining business. When you think about gasoline, the value of being integrated, which is the key to us is, that we're able to, on the gasoline side, blend and get a lot of credit against that obligation. And so I don't think, on a company perspective, there is a lot of noise around that. Most companies, and us included, it's access to cellulosic and diesel, biodiesel RINs and credits where -- that's where the challenge is. And you see that mostly within the refining business as our marketing business has a lot more of its earnings tied to gasoline. 
Point taken in terms of metrics and clarity on that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess to add a point, if RINs prices were to ever come down, the marketing segment, it wouldn't necessarily be a hit against the underlying business in the marketing segment, but you might see it in the results and it could be confusing to people.
componenttext: Yes. I guess to add a point, if RINs prices were to ever come down, the marketing segment, it wouldn't necessarily be a hit against the underlying business in the marketing segment, but you might see it in the results and it could be confusing to people.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. Thank you.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. Thank you.

componenttext: Yes. I think on a -- if there was an average product mix, you're right, you wouldn't see anything. But this quarter, it was more heavily weighted towards fuel oil. We can actually have the negative EBITDA on the actual transaction itself.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And in terms of your overall financing strategy, given the volatility in the marketplace and uncertainty, Steven and Greg, should we assume a TLLP net debt going up as go forward the investment and drop-down and all that, that the TSO C Corp
componenttext: Okay, great. And in terms of your overall financing strategy, given the volatility in the marketplace and uncertainty, Steven and Greg, should we assume a TLLP net debt going up as go forward the investment and drop-down and all that, that the TSO C Corp net debt will come down so that on a consolidated basis, total net debt will be flat to down, or that's not really the way how you look at the business?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I really think because our Logistics MLP is relatively large and continuing to grow, you need to think about the components of our capital structure together, but also separately. We've said that in our MLP, that we want to target leverage below 4x.
componenttext: Yes. I really think because our Logistics MLP is relatively large and continuing to grow, you need to think about the components of our capital structure together, but also separately. We've said that in our MLP, that we want to target leverage below 4x. And at Tesoro, we've targeted on an unconsolidated basis and been showing less than 20% debt to capital, even investment grade ratings would allow you to go higher than that. But we tend to not want to leverage the refining business, but the Logistics business being at 4x or less given the growth and given the stability of the earnings is a very comfortable place to be from a leverage perspective. So you have to build that up from that perspective, Paul, to get to a consolidated number.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we should not assume on a consolidated basis that your net debt will be flat to down, that your net debt will actually go up on a consolidated basis?
componenttext: So we should not assume on a consolidated basis that your net debt will be flat to down, that your net debt will actually go up on a consolidated basis?

componenttext: As we grow the Logistics business, absolutely.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A final question, Greg. When you're looking at your business, over the next couple of years from the organic investment or sales standpoint, what is the area that you see the biggest opportunity set at this point?
componenttext: A final question, Greg. When you're looking at your business, over the next couple of years from the organic investment or sales standpoint, what is the area that you see the biggest opportunity set at this point?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we see very good opportunities in our Logistics business. We've been very clear that we want to support our integrated refining and marketing business. We believe in Logistics, that we have an opportunity to start to expand our presence geographically,
componenttext: So we see very good opportunities in our Logistics business. We've been very clear that we want to support our integrated refining and marketing business. We believe in Logistics, that we have an opportunity to start to expand our presence geographically, which will provide more opportunities for us in the Logistics area. That's the first thing. Second, in marketing, our outlook is not a lot different as far as we are targeting to continue to increase our integration between refining marketing, improve the quality of the integration that we have between refining and marketing, and then also to be able to strengthen our convenience store offering. So we see that also as a second area of growth after Logistics. And then we always continue, as you're very aware, Paul, that as a company, we like our business model, we like our geographic area. And we would look at opportunities in our geographic area if they were available and they fit into our business model and our ability to create value from a refining standpoint.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: First question is probably going to be tying together a lot of the questions about the quarter, but so I apologize if you've done it. But I know on the last call, you are expecting capture rates to kind of be in the low 80% range for the quarter and then they came in at 73%. So it sounds like what you said is that the 3 main factors are RINs, the inventory reductions and the contracts. I just want to clarify that if there is anything else at play here, meaning that if -- going the next quarter, the inventory reductions in the contracts, some of them won't be there and you expect to have a more normalized capture again.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I think in terms of -- you exactly got it, the 3 drivers this quarter that affected the gross margin. I think in the fourth quarter, the capture rate, if you will look historically, just it depends on where you've got to start with where is the index, the effect of seasonality. But if you ignore that and you just think about this quarter on a more normalized basis, the 3 things you highlighted are things that you should think about when you look forward as being related to the third quarter.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. And then the second question, just following up on the CapEx discussion for 2017. Greg, would you say that most of that reduction in capital is just the timing around projects or have you found opportunities to lower the sustaining capital req
componenttext: Sure, okay. And then the second question, just following up on the CapEx discussion for 2017. Greg, would you say that most of that reduction in capital is just the timing around projects or have you found opportunities to lower the sustaining capital requirements as well? Because I know actually, from your last Analyst Day, the sustaining CapEx is actually expected to be higher in '17 than '16, if I recall it correctly.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, we go back every year and we look at our work plans and what we're doing regarding our sustaining capital, which includes both our -- the money we spend to comply with the regulatory requirements and then our maintaining the integrity of our assets
componenttext: Phil, we go back every year and we look at our work plans and what we're doing regarding our sustaining capital, which includes both our -- the money we spend to comply with the regulatory requirements and then our maintaining the integrity of our assets and then our income capital on top of that, and we do that for both Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics. And so as we've gone through the budgeting and planning process, we've been able to go in and optimize how we spend capital, which impacts sometimes the timing, just programs that we have that we may alter the timing on. And in some cases, we've seen improvements in our ability to lower the cost in our capital programs. And then it's just the overall impact really from the major capital projects and how we will sequence those into our spend is primarily what drives the change. And we'll talk more about that when we do our investor and analyst meeting next -- and December.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. If I could just ask one last one. In your last Analyst Day, you talked about $850 million of proceeds from the asset sales to TLLP, and obviously, you had one in the third quarter, you had one in the fourth quarter here. I mean do you think there's
componenttext: Sure. If I could just ask one last one. In your last Analyst Day, you talked about $850 million of proceeds from the asset sales to TLLP, and obviously, you had one in the third quarter, you had one in the fourth quarter here. I mean do you think there's any real change to kind of the dropdown approach at this stage longer-term?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when we came in to the year, we actually -- if you look at the Investor Day, I think the $850 million was actually over a 3-year period, because given where the MLP markets were at the time, and in order to support our Logistics business through tha
componenttext: Well, when we came in to the year, we actually -- if you look at the Investor Day, I think the $850 million was actually over a 3-year period, because given where the MLP markets were at the time, and in order to support our Logistics business through that environment, we have made an assumption that we would only get about 50% of our cash from -- or 50% of the proceeds from drop downs in cash versus units. And given the strength of the TLP's business, investor interest in participating in that growth, we've been able to actually get a lot more cash out of Logistics business. And I would think more about the 90%/10% as a basis for cash flows. So when I -- based on everything we know now assuming there is not major changes to the market, we see potentially more cash flow than we expected back earlier this year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The 90 is 90% cash, 10% equity.
componenttext: Yes. The 90 is 90% cash, 10% equity.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you'd expect that on a going forward basis as well?
componenttext: So you'd expect that on a going forward basis as well?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Based on where the way things look today, that would be our assumption versus the 50-50 cash and equity.
componenttext: Yes. Based on where the way things look today, that would be our assumption versus the 50-50 cash and equity.

componenttext: Well, 2 or 3 things. So that accounts for a significant part. I mean we were up about 4% year-on-year, so the volume growth is 1 area. 2 is, we continued to invest in our brands and in the quality of the stations which helps overall sales in there. And then the third is just our overall drive to improve how we operate the system, which includes lots of different changes to the business.

componenttext: Well, I think over a long period of time, if you look over the last 18 months, you highlighted the Bakken differentials, but that hasn't changed in the third quarter. componenttext: All right. That's helpful. And how is -- I know you don't like to break the 2 segments -- the 2 units apart within the sector, but how has Alaska have been running? You had a big turnaround I think a year ago there. And then the market dynamics have changed a little bit up there. Just curious how that's performed. componenttext: So Alaska has been running extremely well after the turnaround, and what we tried to achieve there worked out for us. And the fuel oil portion of it is primarily in Anacortes, but there is a little bit of an impact on how we manage the system between Alaska and Anacortes, but it's primarily Anacortes.

componenttext: I think, Brad, we've been clear for quite some time on how we see the market. First, our interests are in our geographic area because that supports our integrated business model. That's very, very important to us. Second, if we found an opportunity to acquire something, if we did, we'd have to be able to create value from that business because we -- our only purpose to acquire anything really is where we feel like we can capture value from it. And so we are very much focused and driven by being able to do those 2 things. Like you said, there is some talk that there are a few assets across the country up for sale. And we just -- we would look at anything that would meet our criteria and our market, but it's not that active in our geographic area really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, Vice
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sam Ramraj, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our third quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. The earnings release, which can be found on our website at ts
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our third quarter 2016 earnings. Joining me are Greg Goff, Chairman and CEO; and Steven Sterin, Executive Vice President and CFO. The earnings release, which can be found on our website at tsocorp.com includes financial disclosure and reconciliations for non-GAAP financial measures that should help you analyze our results. Our comments and answers to questions during this call will include forward-looking statements that refer to management's expectations or future predictions. They are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations. Please refer to the earnings release for additional information on forward-looking statements.
Now I will turn the call over to Steven.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our third quarter 2016 financial performance, and then turn the call over to Greg. Yesterday, we reported third quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $170 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Sam. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. I'll review our third quarter 2016 financial performance, and then turn the call over to Greg. 
Yesterday, we reported third quarter 2016 net earnings from continuing operations of $170 million attributable to Tesoro or $1.43 per diluted share compared to $759 million or $6.13 per diluted share a year ago.
Consolidated net earnings were $201 million for the third quarter compared to $799 million for the same period last year, and EBITDA was $577 million compared to $1.5 billion a year ago.
Operating income in the third quarter grew year-over-year in Logistics, but was lower in refining and marketing due to a stronger than normal market environment in 2015.
Turning to our business segments. 
Refining operating income was $52 million for the third quarter compared to $899 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $204 million versus $1 billion last year. Operating income and segment EBITDA for the quarter include a pretax inventory benefit due to a lower cost or market valuation adjustment of $20 million, offset by a $14 million charge related to a contract dispute with the supplier.
The Tesoro Index was $12.45 a barrel for the third quarter, with a gross refining margin of $9.08 per barrel or 73% capture of the Tesoro Index. This compares to the Tesoro Index of $23.09 and a gross refining margin of $19.43 or 84% capture for last year. 
Refining margins in the third quarter were negatively impacted by the following 3 items: first, an overall lower refining margin environment; second, rising RINs prices. Let me remind you that our refining sales to our marketing business are based on spot prices less the full RIN costs. So in a quarter where RINs costs rise, we reflect the higher obligation in refining and the benefit from blending in our marketing segment. It is important to note that we run our business in the integrated manner. This does not have a material impact on total company results. 
And lastly, we continue to look for ways to drive improvements in our business and capital allocation. One of the ways we do this is by driving improvements in working capital. In the third quarter, we successfully reduced inventory and generated approximately $150 million in cash as a result. This inventory reduction had a positive impact on cash flow, but a negative impact on refining margins in the quarter.
Total refining throughput for the quarter was 873,000 barrels a day or 98% utilization, which was at the high end of our expectations.
Manufacturing costs in the third quarter increased $0.27 per barrel over the same period last year to $5.11. This year-over-year increase was largely due to the addition of the Dickinson Refinery and the Tesoro Great Plains assets acquired in 2016.
Moving to Logistics. 
Operating income increased to $133 million in the third quarter from $106 million a year ago and segment EBITDA grew to $181 million from $153 million last year. This performance was driven by the following factors: year-over-year growth in TLLP's crude oil gathering, terminalling and transportation throughput; growth from the acquisition of the Los Angeles Storage and Pipeline Assets last year; and growth from the Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets acquisition made during the quarter.
The total general partner and limited partner distributions received by Tesoro were $65 million during the third quarter. This is an increase of $27 million or 71% versus 2015.
Turning to marketing. 
Operating income was $273 million compared to $379 million a year ago and segment EBITDA was $285 million compared to $390 million last year. The fuel margins were $0.149 a gallon in the third quarter versus $0.205 a gallon last year. 
During the quarter, we saw a continued strong fundamentals and favorable business conditions, including growth in consumer demand and an increase in vehicle miles traveled. We are pleased with our operating results in the quarter as we continue to execute our strategy of optimizing the placement of our refined products through the most valuable channels for market consumption.
Now, I'd like to take a moment to discuss our balance sheet, cash flow and our strategic priorities for creating long-term shareholder value.
Our balance sheet remains strong. We ended the quarter with the consolidated cash balance of $1.4 billion compared to $942 million at the end of 2015. Total debt to capitalization was 36% at the end of the quarter. Excluding TLLP debt and equity, our debt to capitalization ratio was 19%.
We have made significant progress in strengthening our balance sheet, investing for growth and returning cash to shareholders. And we continue to progress towards our goal of obtaining investment grade credit ratings for Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics.
As you may be aware, at the end of the quarter, Tesoro entered into a new $2 billion senior secured revolving credit agreement. This new 4-year cash flow credit facility replaces our $3 billion asset based credit facility. The new credit facility will become unsecured upon Tesoro achieving an investment grade rating from either Moody's or S&P. Additionally, on October 14, S&P upgraded TLLP's credit rating by 1 level to BB+, with a stable outlook. This new rating is now the same as that as Tesoro in just 1 notch below investment grade.
Turning to cash flows. 
Tesoro generated cash flow from operating activities of $1.2 billion for the first 9 months of 2016, including $573 million in the third quarter. 
I'd like to discuss how we continued to deploy cash to create long-term shareholder value.
First, we invest in high return capital projects and improve returns on invested capital. For the first 9 months of the year, we invested $296 million in income and growth capital projects at Tesoro and TLLP. Our combined capital expenditures were approximately $624 million. And we now expect full year 2016 capital spending of approximately $900 million. This is a reduction from our previous expectations of approximately $1 billion.
Next, we ensure that we maintain a strong balance sheet to give us the flexibility to make strategic investments and also return cash to shareholders. For the first 9 months of the year, we spent approximately $412 million on accretive acquisitions. We executed $3.2 million in share repurchases for approximately $250 million, including 1.9 million shares for approximately $150 million during the quarter. We also paid dividends of $186 million and distributed $155 million to third-party LP unitholders.
Looking ahead, you can find details of our planned throughput, manufacturing cost per barrel and other elements related to our fourth quarter outlook in our earnings release that was issued yesterday.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steven, and good morning. We are pleased with our results for the quarter, which can be attributed to our integrated business model and the continued execution of our operating improvements. Our operational reliability was very strong. Comb
componenttext:
Thank you, Steven, and good morning. 
We are pleased with our results for the quarter, which can be attributed to our integrated business model and the continued execution of our operating improvements. 
Our operational reliability was very strong. Combined with our continued growth in Logistics and our integrated marketing business, we generated strong operating cash flows. Also, this quarter, we returned $215 million to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
Turning to our operations. 
Let me start with refining. As Steven mentioned previously, total refinery throughput for the quarter was 873,000 barrels per day or 98% utilization and gross refining margin was $9.08 per barrel. 
In our California region, we continued to see product demand growth. We operate in our refineries well with a utilization of 98%, which was at the high end of our guidance. 
In our Pacific Northwest region, throughput was higher than our expectations, but our operating performance was impacted by a lower refining margin environment, RINs pricing and products mix due to an impact of a reduction of inventory. 
In the Mid-Continent, throughput was within our expectation. However, operating results were impacted by a lower refining margin environment and a charge related to a contract settlement with a supplier. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect overall refinery utilization to be between 90% and 96%.
Moving to Logistics. 
We continued to execute on our strategy of growing this business through organic investment, strategic acquisitions and acquisitions by Tesoro. TLLP delivered strong operating income growth in the quarter. TLLP's quarter results were driven by the terminalling and transportation segment, which generated record revenues, operating income and EBITDA. During the quarter, TLLP completed the acquisition of the Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets from Tesoro, and this contributed to the segment's operating performance.
Crude oil gathering volumes increased to 206,000 barrels per day versus 199,000 barrels per day last year despite a challenging commodity price environment. While this headwind still exists in our gathering and processing operations, we continue to invest in attractive organic projects, such as interconnections on the High Plains system and compression projects in our natural gas gathering system.
Tesoro expects to offer TLLP the opportunity to acquire the Northern California Terminalling and Storage assets in the fourth quarter of 2016. The assets could add $28 million to $33 million of annual net earnings and $45 million to $50 million of annual EBITDA to TLLP. Looking forward, TLLP remains committed to achieving its goal of $820 million of annual operating income and $1 billion of EBITDA by 2017.
Now shifting to marketing. 
Our performance in the quarter was strong. During the quarter, we saw a continued favorable trends in the market, including strong consumer demand with U.S. gasoline demand up 3% year-over-year through September, and an increase in vehicle miles traveled at 3.2% year-over-year in the U.S. and 4.8% year-over-year in California through August. Also, we increased our branded store count by 178 stations year-over-year to 2,467. We continue to successfully execute our strategy of optimizing the placement of our refined products through the most valuable channels for market consumption.
We see continued favorable market fundamentals driven by a strong economy and growth in consumer demand in the regions in which we operate. We remain excited about the organic growth prospects in our marketing business. These include implementing improvements in our stations, expanding our network of stations and investing in our brands.
Now, let me discuss the acquisitions we made during the quarter and also provide you an update on major capital projects. 
On the acquisition front. In September, we acquired Virent, Inc., an innovative renewable fuels and chemicals company. This acquisition supports our renewable fuel strategy of developing high-quality, low-carbon renewable feedstocks and blend stocks that can be either co-processed in our existing refineries or blended seamlessly with traditional fuels. Also, by generating valuable renewable fuels credits, we could lower our compliance costs with both the federal renewable fuel standard and California's low carbon fuel standard.
During the quarter, we closed both portions of the sale of the Alaska Storage and Terminalling Assets to TLLP for a total consideration to Tesoro of $444 million, paid as $400 million in cash and approximately $44 million of TLLP common and general partner units.
To give you an update on our Vancouver Energy project. The energy facility Site Evaluation Council concluded adjudicated hearings in September with the filing of all parties post hearing briefs. On October 6, Vancouver Energy submitted its revised permit application to EFSEC in keeping with the council's hearing rules and regulations.
In the revised permit application, Vancouver Energy offered many conditions that are well above regulatory requirements. This includes a performance-based throughput structure by which EFSEC could limit the project's initial throughput to 180,000 barrels per day or 50% of the originally proposed 360,000 barrels per day. This structure includes the ability to incrementally increase the facility's throughput by 90,000 barrels per day after 12 consecutive months of acceptable safety and environmental performance. Two consecutive performance periods would result in their originally proposed 360,000 barrels per day facility. EFSEC is now deliberating its recommendation to the Governor of Washington.
We are committed to the proposed crude oil rail-to-marine terminal and remain confident that a thorough evaluation will demonstrate that we can design, construct and operate a safe environmentally responsible facility that offers benefits to the state of Washington in the entire West Coast.
Regarding the Los Angeles refinery integration and compliance project. The South Coast Air Quality Management District is making progress on preparing the final environmental impact report. A certified environmental impact report will allow the main permitting entities to approve the project. We expect to have the necessary permits and approvals by the end of this year and begin construction shortly thereafter.
To update you on our progress to deliver improvements in our business. You will recall that at our Investor and Analyst Day last December, we laid out our expectations for 2016, which were based on 3 things: one, the Tesoro Index of $12 to $14 per barrel; two, marketing fuel margins of $0.11 to $0.14 per gallon; and three, crude oil differentials that reflected the cost of transportation.
Through the first 9 months of 2016, the Tesoro Index and marketing fuel margins are in line with our expectations. Crude oil differentials continued to be significantly narrower than our expectations. This has resulted in lower capture rates and lower refining profitability than our original expectations for this year.
Tesoro continues to expect year-over-year improvements from higher utilization and operational efficiencies of $400 million to $500 million. We also committed to delivering $400 million to $500 million of annual improvements to operating income in 2016, consisting of $200 million to $250 million in refining, $175 million to $200 million in logistics and $25 million to $50 million in marketing. Even in the current challenging market environment, we are confident that we will deliver the $400 million to $500 million of total annual improvements to operating income.
Through the first 3 quarters of the year, our estimated refining and marketing improvements are trending above the range. However, estimated logistics improvements are trending slightly below the range, primarily due to the weak commodity price environment, which has impacted organic growth and volumes.
Before I conclude, I would like to remind you that we will be hosting our 2016 Investor and Analyst Day on December 6 in New York City. My leadership team and I look forward to updating you on the company strategic outlook and outlining our plans for 2017. For additional details on this event, please follow up with our Investor Relations team.
To conclude, we have built a strong integrated refining, logistics and marketing business and have a competitive position in our markets. This enables us to drive significant operational improvements, create sustainable earnings growth and deliver long-term shareholder value.
Thank you. And with that, we'll take your questions. Operator?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question comes from Spiro Dounis from UBS Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question comes from Spiro Dounis from UBS Securities.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to start off around I guess the IDR structure at TLLP, just given recent events by your peers. And I guess, I just want to ask in 2 ways. So first, how should we be thinking about maybe lowering the cash -- capital there and then will come s
componenttext: I just wanted to start off around I guess the IDR structure at TLLP, just given recent events by your peers. And I guess, I just want to ask in 2 ways. So first, how should we be thinking about maybe lowering the cash -- capital there and then will come sit in TSO for its GP interest? And then two, you're trying to obtain investment grade rating at TLLP and TSO. TLLP just got upgraded to a notch below. How, I guess, if at all, would any sort of IDR buy-in or relief reviewed by the credit agencies? Is that a factor at what you end up deciding to do?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are good questions. Let me ask Steven to comment on both of those.
componenttext: These are good questions. Let me ask Steven to comment on both of those.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've talked before, we're in logistics business because we see substantial opportunities to continue to grow the business, both organically and through acquisition. And as you mentioned, we're in MLP because we need access to low-cost capital to
componenttext: Yes. As we've talked before, we're in logistics business because we see substantial opportunities to continue to grow the business, both organically and through acquisition. And as you mentioned, we're in MLP because we need access to low-cost capital to do that. Over time, as we've grown the business substantially, the IDR structure does have an impact on the cost of capital of the MLP. We see that, we acknowledge it and understand it. As we look forward, it's critical because we do see continued opportunity for high return investment within the logistics business, for the MLP to have very attractive cost of capital, for our unit holders to have significant accretion opportunities as we grow the business, and for Tesoro to continue to receive cash, and MLP to be a source of cash for Tesoro to reduce our cost of capital over time. And so we absolutely view that as part of our ongoing and long-term strategy. And we'll, as always, continue to look at all the options that are out there to allow us to continue to both grow the business and have a low cost of capital. And on your second question about investment grade, if you look at Tesoro and TLLP's balance sheet, if you look at what we've done with cash flow and capital allocation and leverage, we think the companies are very high quality and meet most, if not all, investment-grade ratings, and think that managing cost of capital and options that are there only support that and it wouldn't take away from that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Appreciate that color. Just second question around the retail growth. I think the expectations maybe whether, you would have acquired something I guess at this point of year, and I think you looked at something earlier, but the valuations were jus
componenttext: Got it. Appreciate that color. Just second question around the retail growth. I think the expectations maybe whether, you would have acquired something I guess at this point of year, and I think you looked at something earlier, but the valuations were just hard to justify. I'm curious if that's still the case and if valuations are getting any more attractive.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Spiro, on our marketing strategy, the way we laid out pretty clearly at the end of last year was to substantially improve the integration between our refining and marketing, both the quality and the overall performance of our marketing business, and we
componenttext: So Spiro, on our marketing strategy, the way we laid out pretty clearly at the end of last year was to substantially improve the integration between our refining and marketing, both the quality and the overall performance of our marketing business, and we've made very, very good progress this year. As I stated in some of the comments that I just made, we were -- we have been able to grow our wholesale marketing business through our brand stations by almost 200 stations year-on-year, which is probably a little bit ahead of what we expected to be able to do going into the year. And we've been able to drive other improvements in the business. And you're exactly right, we have looked at opportunities to acquire assets that would fit into our integrated business model. There hasn't been a lot available in the marketplace this year. And so we will continue just to evaluate opportunities as they become available. But probably more importantly, we're seeing really good growth in our underlying business, that's probably a little bit ahead of our expectations from what we thought we were able to do last year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: On capital spending, you guys have been tracking very well here. I think you're now guiding to $900 million at 2016. Can you talk about the delta relative to the previous guidance that you laid out last quarter? And then pluses and minuses going into 2017
componenttext: On capital spending, you guys have been tracking very well here. I think you're now guiding to $900 million at 2016. Can you talk about the delta relative to the previous guidance that you laid out last quarter? And then pluses and minuses going into 2017, recognizing we're going to get more flavor on this at the December Analyst Day, but just how you're thinking about the '17 CapEx would be helpful.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's an excellent question, Neil. As we progress through the year, we've continued to manage all of our capital projects, first, by trying to find improvements in the execution at the projects would allow us to have lower total capital spend on the p
componenttext: Yes. It's an excellent question, Neil. As we progress through the year, we've continued to manage all of our capital projects, first, by trying to find improvements in the execution at the projects would allow us to have lower total capital spend on the projects that we're executing. And we've had good success on that through our supply, sourcing and other programs like that, so with that, we're very excited about. And as the actual change from our revised guidance of $1 billion down by about 10%, primarily is some movements in our Logistics business, just more of a lesser timing impact moving things into next year and then just other small improvements across the whole system. Last year in December, that we gave guidance for 2017 that would have had Tesoro and Tesoro Logistics for a combined spending of about $1.7 billion, we are in the final stages of completing our planning for '17 and '18 and '19 as we go out and look at our plans to execute on the various projects that we're undertaking. And it looks preliminary that we'll probably be down somewhere between say 27% to 33%, somewhere in that range versus what we said last year, so down by about another $400 million to $500 million of capital spending. But we'll -- as you clearly stated, we'll be specific about that when we get together in December.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Neil, as we've spoken in the past, our fundamental analysis of the West Coast market is very constructive. We see good fundamentals from the demand outlook. As we just stated, in the marketplace, the refineries operating at a relatively high utilization rates. Still, export activity going into Mexico and a little bit into Chile and Peru. So overall, our view of the West Coast is a very constructive view, up from a fundamental market analysis standpoint, and so that's kind of how we see that continuing into 2017.

componenttext: One of the key criteria that the rating agencies have talked about was the need to eliminate secured debt, which we did effectively with the new revolver finance. But as we look at the business, all of the fundamentalist that we've talked about, the ratings targets and the leverage targets that we've talked about, we're either a head up or we're on track with those. So that's something we'll continue to evaluate, but we feel like we're continuing to move in the right direction on it.

componenttext: Well, I think from the Tesoro perspective, we feel very good about where we are positioned. TLLP, as you know, is a notch behind, with the exception of S&P, so that's going to take more time. And so I think when we're ready for that, and we lay out our plans, we think that we should be investment grade. componenttext: Greg, I wonder if I could ask a little bit about the marketing EBITDA trend. I mean, obviously, there is some RIN distortions in there. But I think you touched on it in your prepared remarks. But the run rate year-to-date appears to be well above the $1 billion target you had laid out originally with acquisitions for 2018. I don't want to get in front of your Analyst Day, but can you just talk about how you feel about that target given your relative performance year-to-date?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Well, just to maybe reiterate what I said earlier, Doug, is that we are having very good success in driving some fundamental improvements in our overall marketing business. So in addition to the growth in our wholesale marketing business with the almost 200 branded stations, they've been able to drive continued improvements in our overall portfolio, and so we feel really good about the improvements. They are ahead of what we expected to be able to do in the business for this year, because you're exactly right. When we laid out our plan last year, which we clearly gave a run rate EBITDA of about $650 million, and you pointed out very accurately that we're running in excess of that this year, so the margins are slightly better as a result of the improvements that we've been driving in the business, and as so we'll talk more about it in a month or so when we get together, but the outlook to us is very, very encouraging without any growth.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to clarify. So the $200 million to $300 million I think acquisitions that were embedded in that original target, have any of those taken place?
componenttext: So just to clarify. So the $200 million to $300 million I think acquisitions that were embedded in that original target, have any of those taken place?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: They have not. So our -- let me just be clear about our thinking. When we laid out our plans, we basically stated that our business is highly integrated, and you've heard us say that, probably ad nauseam, but our business is highly integrated. And as a re
componenttext: They have not. So our -- let me just be clear about our thinking. When we laid out our plans, we basically stated that our business is highly integrated, and you've heard us say that, probably ad nauseam, but our business is highly integrated. And as a result, what we want to be able to do is 3 things: one, continue to strengthen that integration around each of our refineries, so that we drive that integration to a very high level; two, improve the quality of our marketing business around each of our refineries, so that as we actively manage the portfolio of marketing assets, we are able to high grade that portfolio, which part of our thinking there was around potential acquisitions over time, and we said we would do that over about a 3-year period of time that if we identified opportunities, we would make those -- try to capture those opportunities in an effort to high grade our marketing portfolio; and the third thing was, we said that we needed to strengthen our convenience store offering. We felt that, that was a critical variable in our overall offering to our customers, and that's a third thing that we're working on.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: No. We continued to look at everything in our business. And we are fundamentally focused on creating value with all the assets that we have, Refining, marketing and logistics.
