componenttext: Greg, I'm just going to throw one question at you. I was curious, Pacific Northwest margins, I mean I know we're dealing with a narrower Bakken differentials, but has there been anything else? I mean Q2 was obviously impacted by some turnaround activities and Q3 wasn't really. I mean, directionally, margins were lower, indicators were at least as we looked at on fairly similar. Kind of what's going on in that region? Is there anything that's transitory? Or is it -- it is differentials, and that's just what we're going to deal with until transportation comes back into the system?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think over a long period of time, if you look over the last 18 months, you highlighted the Bakken differentials, but that hasn't changed in the third quarter. The third quarter, as I mentioned earlier, that's where we mentioned the reduction in in
componenttext: Well, I think over a long period of time, if you look over the last 18 months, you highlighted the Bakken differentials, but that hasn't changed in the third quarter. The third quarter, as I mentioned earlier, that's where we mentioned the reduction in inventories and the negative impact that have on margins from the sale of those products, and a lot of that is attributable to Pacific Northwest.

componenttext: Okay. So it was over weighted to that region?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: All right. That's helpful. And how is -- I know you don't like to break the 2 segments -- the 2 units apart within the sector, but how has Alaska have been running? You had a big turnaround I think a year ago there. And then the market dynamics have changed a little bit up there. Just curious how that's performed. And is that where we should think about the IMO having a significant impact as well?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Alaska has been running extremely well after the turnaround, and what we tried to achieve there worked out for us. And the overall business, with the acquisition early this year in Alaska from an integrated standpoint is delivering exactly kind of what
componenttext: So Alaska has been running extremely well after the turnaround, and what we tried to achieve there worked out for us. And the overall business, with the acquisition early this year in Alaska from an integrated standpoint is delivering exactly kind of what we expected it to be able to do. And the fuel oil portion of it is primarily in Anacortes, but there is a little bit of an impact on how we manage the system between Alaska and Anacortes, but it's primarily Anacortes.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, we talked a little bit about M&A on the marketing side already. I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about it on the refining side. It seems like there are a lot of assets in the market right now, a couple that would seem to be in your neck
componenttext: Greg, we talked a little bit about M&A on the marketing side already. I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about it on the refining side. It seems like there are a lot of assets in the market right now, a couple that would seem to be in your neck of the woods. So I'm curious how you think about the options that you see in the refining M&A market versus other uses of capital.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Brad, we've been clear for quite some time on how we see the market. First, our interests are in our geographic area because that supports our integrated business model. That's very, very important to us. Second, if we found an opportunity to acq
componenttext: I think, Brad, we've been clear for quite some time on how we see the market. First, our interests are in our geographic area because that supports our integrated business model. That's very, very important to us. Second, if we found an opportunity to acquire something, if we did, we'd have to be able to create value from that business because we -- our only purpose to acquire anything really is where we feel like we can capture value from it. And so we are very much focused and driven by being able to do those 2 things. Like you said, there is some talk that there are a few assets across the country up for sale. And we just -- we would look at anything that would meet our criteria and our market, but it's not that active in our geographic area really.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just thinking about your geographic area, I mean there are still a lot of places where you have pretty high concentration. So are a lot of the assets that may be would be attractive to you precluded from an antitrust standpoint? Or do you feel like maybe there is more freedom than might be perceived?

componenttext: Well, if you're talking about the state of California, we have the position we want in the state of California and we're working to strengthen and continue to improve that position, so we won't be interested in anything in the state of California.

componenttext: Okay, got it. That's clear. And then last one from me, on the drop Q, I was just wondering if you could give an update on how much of the EBITDA is available to drop today given the large number of drops you've already had this year?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had -- we've only had one drop, and we're going to do a second drop. And the first drop we did was a little bit of the Alaska assets, but the other part of it came from our acquisition up in Alaska. And then we do have, as I stated, a drop whi
componenttext: Well, we've had -- we've only had one drop, and we're going to do a second drop. And the first drop we did was a little bit of the Alaska assets, but the other part of it came from our acquisition up in Alaska. And then we do have, as I stated, a drop which has between $40 million to $50 million of EBITDA attributed to it. And so you can almost back in to the amount of inventory we have remaining from what we previously said. And off the top of my head, I don't recall what that is. It's probably in the $500-ish million range of EBITDA remaining, and you can see that we've done -- we have one upcoming and a little bit of Alaska, so that kind of gives you a pretty good idea, Brad, of what we have left to do.
